35477413.review:
Holy Sh#t – was für ein großartiges Spiel. Ich liebe jede Minute. Ohne Zweifel eins meiner Spiele-Highlights 2017. Ich weiß gar nicht, wo ich mit der Lobhudelei anfangen soll.

Eigentlich möchte ich auch gar nicht zu sehr auf das In-Game-Geschehen eingehen, je unvorbereiteter und planloser man hier in den Wald stolpert umso „schöner“ wird das Erlebnis. Keine Ahnung wann ich – gemessen an der Spielzeit – zuletzt so oft in einem Spiel verreckt bin.

Was für mich hier besonders hervorsticht, ist die Tatsache, dass in Darkwood der Horror nicht billig über ein paar Scarejumps erzeugt wird, sondern in erster Linie durch die Atmosphäre - insbesondere in den Nachtabschnitten des 
Spiels – kontinuierlich auf einem ansehnlichen Level gehalten wird.
Es wird nicht mit dem Holzhammer draufgezimmert, sondern durch ein in meinen Augen brilliantes Zusammenspiel von Umgebung und Geräuschkulisse auf subtile Art ein permanent ungutes Gefühl von nervösem „ auf den Zehenspitzen sein“ geschaffen. „Was schleicht da grade um´s Haus“ und „ Was zum Teufel passiert jetzt schon wieder“ fasst das, ohne zu viel zu verraten, ganz gut zusammen. Und auch wenn man das ein oder andere mit zunehmender Spieldauer einzuschätzen
versteht – durch die Unvorhersehbarkeit der nächtlichen Ereignisse stellt sich zu keinem Zeitpunkt ein Gefühl der Sicherheit ein. Man kann sich bis zu einem gewissen Grad auf die Nacht vorbereiten, eine Garantie für´s Überleben selbiger gibt es allerdings nie. Großes Lob und Dank an die Entwickler - genau so macht man das. So hat sich 1996 das erste Durchspielen von Resident Evil für mich angefühlt.   

Auf was ihr Euch hier einstellen müsst ( ohne Spoiler ):

1.) Ihr werdet sterben. Oft. Echt jetzt Junge.
2.) Wenn Ihr die Finger von der (guten )Wiki lasst, nimmt Euch niemand an die Hand. 
3.) Wenn Ihr´s gern kuschlig weich habt und Ihr gerade ein Spiel sucht, dass jeden Fehler mit einem Lächeln verzeiht, empfehle ich die Sims. Darkwood ist der Horror-Clown der nachts an Eurem Bett steht. Also mehr so das Gegenteil. 
4.) Wenn Ihr das in der Nacht mit Kopfhörern spielt, Euch im Nachtzyklus befindet und Euch dann plötzlich jemand von hinten an die Schulter fasst, solltet Ihr gute Herzkranzgefäße haben. ( Das zahl ich Dir übrigens noch heim Frau! Du wirst nicht wissen wie und Du wirst auch nicht wissen wann - aber die Rache ist mein spricht der Herr..)   
5.) Hatte ich schon erwähnt, dass gehäuftes Ableben zum Spiel gehört?

Fazit: Klare Kaufempfehlung von meiner Seite. Als Survival-Horror-Freund kann man hier keinen Fehler machen.
Kleiner Tip am Rande: Unbedingt mit Kopfhörern spielen. Wenn Ihr nicht alleine wohnt vorher die Tür verbarrikadieren. 
Wenn ihr alleine wohnt auch..   

Have a nice day.

35459351.review:
Likes

1.Very dark and atmospheric
2.Fantastic animation
3.Well designed crafting and inventory system
4.A dark plot with great characters
5.Minimal punishment for killing NPC's
6.Great sound design

-Dislikes
1.too Scarce of ammo ( I love the gun mechanics and felt they could have been more prevalent)
2.A lot of the collectible photos or objects in game seem to do nothing at all, nor contribute to the story. 
3.No mention of how to save. You just go to the "Oven" in any of the hidouts, Click on it, then close out and it will save. Kind of silly in my opinion. 

Beat the game in 24 hours (spread over a few weeks). Very Impressed with the game overall. I Killed most of the NPC's in the beginning of the game without really doing too many quests and thought I might have fudged it. Appearantly you can do this without spoiling the main content of the game. 35455068.review:
Surviver: 27 nights.

Darkwood is survival-horror, par-excellence.  It reminds me most of games like Resident Evil 1-3, or more accurately, Silent Hill 1-3.  Add to this the fun of trying to secure your hideout each night and survive whatever unnamed horrors, or paranormal events, that come to visit. This game will leave you guessing.

The gameplay cycle breaks down into 3 parts. Explore during the day and gather supplies to help you survive. Bolster your defences and refine your weapons to last the night. Finally, take your best loot, build high power weapons (because you've been making it through the night, right?) and unravel the main quests that let you progress to the next map.

You might not think that a game with a fixed overhead camera can be that frightening, but between the sound design and the brutally limited view, I can honestly say it's been ages since I've felt that kind of panic playing a game.

The game can feel incredibly unfair at times, especially when dealing with the full monster-type enemies. But dying only truely sets you back in time; there are enough resources to be found in the game that you can't truly screw yourself long-term.  The game is also brutal about not warning you when you're taking a fork in the story; don't assume there is only one way to advance. I tried to do a 'good' playthrough and during the epilogue I discovered I didn't even come close to doing it perfectly 'good'.  So on top of all that, the replayability is very high.

It's a fantastic little gem of a game with a very unique take on the survival horror gameplay. The game oozes atmosphere and the lore is suprisingly deep and interesting. It's one of very few games that I've replayed right after completing it. Can't think of a better way to give it my recommendations.

This game has all kinds of the crap that I hate in games.  Never makes much sense, all the way through the end.  Clicking the wrong thing messes up the game forever, and you never get an idea what the wrong thing will be,  Combat controls are an absolute mess.

35323783.review:
The first survival horror game in a long, long time that maintains that feeling of tension even for a little while after you understand the game and how to play it.  No game can maintain tension forever after that point, but Darkwood makes it last longer than most.

You wouldn't think that a top-down perspective would lend itself to horror well, but the developers clearly know what makes and breaks a survival horror game.  The combination of limited perspective, sound design, and ponderous (but never imprecise) movement and controls creates a perfect feeling of tension.  While never scary, Darkwood is often tense.

While I'd say the game feels best in its permadeath form, it comes with two other modes that are somewhat forgiving (you have a limited number of lives, and you can get more by consuming a very rare item) or very forgiving (you have an unlimited number of lives.)  As far as I'm aware, none of the different modes adjust how difficult or not the actual gameplay is, only how forgiving (or not) the game is about player death.

The game is separated into two chapters and tells the tale of a sort of plague in a Soviet-era Poland, or at least seems to.  While it's not on the level of something like Dark Souls or Hollow Knight, the narrative is a bit vague and the player is never quite sure if what they're seeing is real or not.

Gameplay largely consists of exploring during the day, gathering supplies and fighting monsters while pursuing your ovearching goals, then seeking shelter in Hideouts to survive against the monsters until dawn.  While you're constantly going to be scavenging to improve your available weapons and even produce some simple armor, as well as repair those weapons, food and drink are never a concern for you, which is a pleasant break from one of the typically more annoying and less interesting aspects of most survival games.

For anyone even vaguely interested in the survival horror genre, Darkwood is a must-have.  For everyone else, it's still absolutely worth a look, especially at its price point.

35266768.review:
Darkwood is a beautiful, unique product of Polish culture. It's also mean, ugly and foreboding. 

 It bristles with mood and panicked energy- the game tells you that you have a curfew. Just try to stay out after dark, it says, I fucking dare you.  Nothing is ever entirely clear. The survival mechanics compliment, rather than detract from the gameplay. Every character you talk to is crazed, cruel, ugly, monstrous, or a combination of such traits-- and yet they're profoundly memorable; through crisp, brutal dialogue, and sharply designed and animated portraits. WIth so little, the good folks at Acid Wizard have done so much. The combat in this game is a messy affair; I'm reminded of the combat in Silent Hill 2, except in Darkwood, it's harder and deadlier. You must charge your attack to full before releasing it, which forces you to kite, to strategize, and to attempt to remember that you can dodge. If I have one criticism w/r/t the combat, it's that the weapons degrade at a pace that's just a little too fast for me. 
However, like any other horror game worth its salt, it is the sound of Darkwood that what makes it shine. Whispers in the forest, your heaving breath, the growl of things that were dogs, the music that's so subtle you can barely call it that, all thrust you deep into the forest. There are few moments in this game that make you almost sick with panic, and one is stepping into the bear trap that you set yourself, as you flee from something, as night has begun to fall, to get home in time. 

There are some aspects that make the game at times frustrating; and that's when you're playing on the easy mode, where dying means you drop a portion of your inventory, so you go out to recover it and are killed along the way because you were missing vital tools you kept in your inventory, so you go out to recover it and because the map doesn't show your exact location and you've go to use landmarks and navigate that way, you get lost, and wander into a field of poisonous mushrooms and die yet again. 
It's great. I don't like it, but it's great. 

In all, Darkwood is worth your time. The developers are wonderful people in that they took the huge risk of releasing a torrent version of this game, but nonetheless, you should buy it, ideally at full price, so that they can go make more excellent, fucked up Polish content.

35190386.review:
I've gotta say, this game packs an emotional punch I did not expect from it at first. 
I'm leaving the thing with the free torrent to the side, since that should not reflect on the quality of the game.

Darkwood is a beautiful game. 
The atmospherical buildup is amazing, ambient sounds and layered environments make the relatively simple top-down perspective feel alive. You'll especially notice this in a few specific places like the giant hole in the Silent Forest, the ravine running south of the Doctor's house, and a canyon in the swamp. 

The gameplay is solid, combat doesn't feel slow or draggy, but takes time to get good at. 
The game forces you to choose how to approach a given problem. Be it a monster, preferred tactics for night defense, or moving along the plot of the game proper. 

Once you get the hang of if, the game becomes [i]really[/i] fun to play, the whole scavenge at day defend your base at night thing isn't original, but Darkwood gives it such a good spin that that doesn't particularly matter.
I love the plot elements, the feeling of being trapped in a place that's so much greater than you, the dramatic reveal if you manage to get the True ending, the sense of dread you get when you're lost, or when you won't make it back to your hideout before nighftall. The real sense of desperation that comes in when you realize you're basically standing in a dead wasteland but with more trees.

I delved deep into Darkwood's lore and am a wiki editor and forum roamer, and I honestly want more.
That's my complaint, there's not enough darkwood.
Oh, and Acid Wizard should definetly release the official soundtrack.

35181315.review:
This game is absolutely amazing especially considered it's mostly headed by a three man team. Good work Acid Wizard

-The good- 

The art direction of this game is phenomenal, I wish I could meet the artistic mind behind the game. The artist has managed to draw very realistic back drops that blend together seamlessly making the player really feel like he's in a decaying land taken over by trees and roots. So much thought and attention to detail went into the art direction of the game it's astounding. Everything feels realistic and believable. Anything from how roots peak out from below the grass, twist and devour everything around them, to the way settings feel dirty and gritty, and how bodies appear realistically decayed.

To compliment my previous statements about art direction this game has one of THE MOST ORIGINAL setting concepts I have seen in a very long time. The protagonist finds himself in a decaying eastern European land being devoured by trees. The way the trees and roots twist together to create an impassable expanse, split open the earth into twisted valleys, and consume the living is incredible. Those who are responsible for the creation of this concept are truly persons to be emulated. The art and setting are executed so well, that the game will leave you feeling absolutely immersed in the setting, and biting at your fingernails as you contemplate how to escape! 

The gameplay is challenging but fair once mastered, the player will spend most of his time scrounging through the filthy environments for anything he can use to stay alive. Once night falls you'll have to be smart about how you set up your shelter to survive the brutal nights. The combat is difficult and is akin to dark souls. Each attack is very deliberate and must be timed well. The reach of weapons and their swing speed must be well understood. Swift footwork is necessary to avoid being hit. 

HORROR DONE RIGHT! This game has been referred to as a horror game without jumpscares. It's true when you break it down. The developers of this game really understand how to do horror the correct way. They put you on the edge of your seat by creating a highly believable dismal environment. They create a sense of unease that sticks with you for the whole way. In your subconscious you know that nowhere is safe. The immersive environment then backs that feeling up through it's eerie visuals. It takes even something like a decaying body and makes it unnerving with it's realistic appearance and presentation. Instead of lunging something out at you with a loud sound to make it "scary", they present the thing to you that is suppose to be scary and let it be scary on it's own. Your understanding of what it is, and what it can do, and the emersion that sets it up is what makes it scary. This is horror done the proper way!

-The 'bad'-
In the nature of being an indie game the game does have some minor bugs

The game doesn't hold the player's hand (Which is a good thing!) however some concepts go unexplained. It is easy for a new player to misunderstand that a firearm turning red isn't it's condition degrading but it just running out of ammo as firearms do not have health. As well as not knowing that fuel can be poured on the floor ala Postal style to create a fire trap leading to an explosive. 

The two endings are not exactly what I expected... I wont spoil anything. However they are still good endings in the grand scheme of things. 

This game will leave you feeling empty and yearning for more of it's dismal environments when it's over! 

-In Summary-

I give this game very high marks in gameplay, art direction, and settings and story. This is a highly underrated game and easily stands apart in an industry of carbon copy games. This game truly is a diamond in the rough. I strongly believe the creative mind behind this are people that we should all take lessons, and inspiring from, in our own game development endeavors. Whatever is going on inside of their heads really works, and the results are clear. I highly recommend you purchase this game and play it for yourself. It's highly original setting is something I will remember for a very long time, and may even draw inspiration from in the future. If the creative minds at Acid Wizard continue to apply themselves like this they will go on to do absolutely great things in an industry of shriveling creativity. 

So buy it buy it buy it. Don't take my word for it, let the game show you for itself.

35117108.review:
Pros:
- Great atmosphere. The way light works and the limited field of vision makes things very tense
- The setting is weird and interesting
- Sound design is top notch
- So far there have been no jump scares, but there have been many freaky things that made me go nope nope nope. It's more of a tense, unsettling game than a scary one though.

Cons:
- Can get a bit grindy when you're unsure how to progress due to the day/night cycle 
- It's quite difficult, so deaths can sometimes be annoying and feel rather unfair (and I do mean feel, because the game's combat system does allow for quite a bit of skill once you've grasped it). For example, it's easy for certain enemies to stunlock you if you're not paying attention. Also some actions can be finnicky until you get the timings down (ie reloading a weapon during a fight).

Overall it's one of my favorite horror games, but I think some people might bounce off due to the difficulty (plus the harder you find the game, the more likely it is to become a grind for you and ruin the atmosphere).

This is a great game. I bought it back in 2015 and now I finished it in 2017 when they released the full game, boy am I glad I waited for them to finish it.

The game's strongest aspects are the visuals and sounds foremost. Its high definition pixel art with a touch of hand frawn art. When you speak to a major npc the game pulls you into this dialogue screen, when you talk to the "wolfman" You literally see him up close and the twisted artwork can be jarring yet intriguing 

The game really rewards exploration. You need to go out and scavenge for supplies while pursuing the main storyline and then hide out in your base during the night. 

The combat mechanics for melee can get some getting use to (ya gatta wind up an attack and swing or use a quick, but weaker attack) Gunplay is pretty straightforward.

Its one of the few horror games that rely on visuals and sound vs jumpscares if that helps.

If there ever has been a game deserving the title [i]"Survival Horror"[/i] then Darkwood is definetly it.

You wake up in the middle of these twisted woods with no memory. You must find a way out and figure out what is going on. There will be clues, but it's up to you to decipher them.

Explore, scavenge and meet the inhabitants of the woods by day, then hunker down in your hideout and survive the night. Pray it's a peaceful one. 
You really can't tank hits, so use everything you have at hand to survive. Run. Hide. Observe and learn. Set up traps. Fight if you must.

Also, hands down, has to be one of the fucking scariest tutorials I have ever played.

I never thought a game could intrigue me and scare the ever loving shit out of me at the same time. For it's price, this game is a fucking master piece. If you have the money please support this game. I can't stress enough how amazing this game is if you can handle the tough learning curve. The devs even uploaded their own fucking game up onto PirateBay for people who wanted the game but couldn't afford it, thwarting illegal key sellers in the process. They truly do care about both their game and the community surrounding it and by god does this game deserve every single bit of praise that comes its way. 

On it's own the game if absolutely fascinating, with no expostion at all apart from a mad doctors thoughts introducing you to the game, it makes you want to learn about the game and discover its "darkest" (kill me) secrets. If you want to jump into the game, do it totally blind if possible, as it's best experienced on your own. However, if you are intent on watching a decent youtuber run through the game or see what its like, I highly reccomend checking out "The Lone Grey". He makes sure to explain whats happening as things progress, gives amazing advice and stratigies on how to actually make it to the end (yes, there is an end point) and is just generally a great guy and fun to watch (he's also played darkwood since its earliest stages which helps).

All in all, even if you can't stand horror, please consider trying this out. Even just watching someone play and getting involved in forums, etc is enough to support the game if you don't have the cash. <3

p.s. As suicidal as it sounds... play it on the hardest difficulty once you're confident enough, mediocore tasks become so much more thrilling.

35076766.review:
Awesome game lots of good elements so far!!! So I'm about an hour or two in after getting controller set up and used to controls in the games prologue.

Reasons to get:
 + Story implementation-I have experienced the beginning of what seems to be a interesting story line, there is some journal reading and short in game cut scenes that don't really break emersion that i hope continues.

 + Base defense elements- Not to spoil but there is barricading and trap placement involved as you find out very early on

 +No hand holding- to be fair their is a little bit of a learning curve (at least on hard mode Idk about normal yet) the game tells you just enough you have to figure out what to do and the consequences of how you spend your time on your own which is challenging but rewarding after you figure it out (huge helpful hint: there are days and nights to the game so be careful)

 + Wonderful and situationally appropriate suspenseful music- considering the art style, psychological horror vibes, and top down view point the music fits exceptionally well and adds to the game in a way that expresses the feeling of worry and adds unseen detail even when only able to view in 3rd person. that being said i feel the intentional obscurity is welcome as that is something i love in some of my favorite horror games
 
 +day night cycles

 +crafting traps, weapons, items, medical supplies, etc.

 +obtainable skills

 +NPC interaction and choices with consequences
 
(all for a $15 price point guys)

I praise the subtle elements like intelligible sounds at creepy moments and doors opening with nothing there, and also the light/dark field of view thats surprised me already a couple of times as you never know whats making that sound or lying in wait until you shine some light. The vague map is cool too. It shows critical points but doesn't hold your hand.

 My only current wish is for more interaction with obtainable objects like flavor script for checking environment and interacting/checking inventory objects. Understandably not a necessary feature but a welcome one for the depth it adds to emersion and detail for those like me that those optional things interest.

35065519.review:
Short version: Pretty epic game, play it :p

---------------------

I'm not great at writing reviews so I'll just throw a few thoughts about Darkwood in here.

The sound design / ambiance is awesome, and combined with the twisted, often surrealistic imagery (especially when you get to see an object / NPC up close), they create a really dense, creepy atmosphere, which is the strongest point of the game (as probably pointed out by everyone and their grandma already :p )

The game actually feels like a survival horror, most of the time it feels like you're barely surviving (on your first playthrough anyway), making through each day (and night) feels really satisfying.

The figting while simple it's kinda skill based, every enemy is deadly, but you can take out any of them with whatever crappy weapon you can get your hands on, provided you're gud enough :p

I haven't finished the game yet (28 hours in), but the story is great.. I guess...? :D I'm still trying to figure things out; the devs were admittedly inspired by Dark Souls, the narration is pretty vague, but it's all there if you pay attention to details, there are plenty of secrets to find  and mysteries to figure out for yourself. Anyway, it's interesting enough for me to just want to go on, play through one more day, find out a litte more.

The game generally is very polished, everything works smoothly, haven't encountered any bugs yet.


Two things that I personally don't like in the game:

I really liked the thing that you can board up doors / windows and move furniture to baricade yourself, but pretty soon I realised they don't do all that much, it fells like a noob trap more than anything to waste resources and time on it.

Normal mode is a little too forgiving, but on hard difficulty you have limited lives, and potencially facing a 'game over' screen 10-20+ hours into the game is not really the kind of challenge I like in games. There could be something in between.


I might add some more thoughts once I finished the game....

35056233.review:
Wow. I originally bought Darkwood 2 years ago in its alpha phase and have been playing it on and off with almost every update. I genuinely enjoyed the gameplay that changed with each update and found myself entranced in the atmosphere and general creepiness of Darkwood. Now with the final release, I still have those nervous ticks and ambitious sparks of curiosity that lured me in like the first time. 

Today I finally beat the game and I am overall very satisfied. Darkwood does what a lot of other modern horror games fail to do. It doesn't go for the sucker punch known as "jump scares"; and instead replaces it with a forboding and intriguing dark atmosphere. Don't get me wrong this game still has jump scares, but they're never forced and the game allows 'you' the player to interpret your own fear of the unknown. Much like what the  Silent Hill series does.

    Darkwood's story takes place in a ever changing forest that swallows everything in its path and you play as an unnamed protagonist who sets out to find a way out. The story is something else and recquires the player to explore the game as much as possible to tie together the clues. There is a shroud of mystery that awaits you at every new turn and boggles your mind; making you question just what the hell is going on in Darkwood's world. I can't say much as the experience of finding out on your own is that much more satisfying than having someone tell you. 


     The gameplay is overall solid and easy to get into. Nothing too crazy that takes away from the game and turns you into a one man killing machine. For some people though the game can feel slow If you don't take in the atmosphere and lore that Darkwood throws at you.

    You spend your time during the day scavenging for items, answers to questions, and fending off  anything that wants to kill you. If you think that's bad, the game ups the ante by throwing  even crazier otherwordly enemies at you during the night. You'll have to board your hideout with 2x4s, fill your generators with gas to help illuminate your enemies, craft new weapons/items, and set traps to ward or kill them off. When the sun rises, you're free and set out to do it all over again. It's a simple objective that recquires you the player to 'grow' with it. You want better/more gear and items? Go deeper into the woods. You want to progress the story? Go deeper into the woods. It's a great incentive to get players to take on the unknown and explore the wonders that Darkwood has in store for them. At times it can be unforgiving and recquires you to learn its fiendish ways, but it is well worth it in the end. 


  This game is overall just amazing and hits all the right marks. I really don't want to give too much away from this game as I feel like it would ruin some of the magic for first time players. So let me just say that if you like Survival Horrors and want a challenging game with a great story, give Darkwood a try. It's weird, it's creepy, it's unsettling, it's mesmerizing and it's fun.

Donde la trama es perturbadora y nos mantiene al borde de la silla, acompañada por una banda sonora y efectos salidos de la peor de nuestras pesadillas. 
 
La historia cuenta la epopeya de algunos sobrevivientes en lo que parece ser una distopía donde la naturaleza volvió a tomar el control de la tierra. Sin embargo, algo siniestro surgió entre las ramas, hojas y raíces, infectando y convirtiendo a los hombres en seres indescriptibles. Los pocos que lograron evadir el contagio y la muerte luchan por escapar de los oscuros bosques que no parecen tener fin y las horrendas pesadillas (¿o realidad?) que los acechan por las noches. 
 
Darkwood es el perfecto ejemplo de un juego indie que logra avivar nuestras emociones de la peor manera, aunque se siente deliciosamente bien. La creación de Acid Wizard Studio, un pequeño estudio polaco de 3 personas, logra lo que muy pocos títulos han conseguido en los últimos diez años: estremecernos desde las entrañas. Sin golpes bajos, sin gore, sin litros de sangre, sólo desde una historia intrincada y violenta, con matices psicodélicos e industriales (al estilo de clásicos como Darkseed y I have no mouth and I must scream) donde el entorno gráfico y los textos duelen más que una puñalada.

En cuanto al género y mecánicas, Darkwood es un juego de survival y crafteo, con ciertos puzzles de aventura tales como descifrar códigos y enigmas siguiendo pistas desparramadas en todos los escenarios. A pesar de elegir la vista cenital (lo que recuerda a los primeros RPG) Darkwood no pierde un ápice de encanto y morbo. Los detalles son justos y no sentimos la necesidad de una mayor resolución o un punto de vista más abarcativo.
 
Hay un mix cuidadosamente seleccionado entre RPG, survival, crafteo y rogue-like que hacen de Darkwood un juego hecho por y para jugadores hardcore. Esto quiere decir que la dificultad es altísima, y une lo más complejo de todos los géneros mencionados para congeniar en un entorno que por momentos parece imposible de superar. No es difícil frustrarse en Darkwood, de hecho, los desarrolladores nos lo advierten en todo momento: "Este es un juego lento, que requiere que pienses y no te perdona. Respeta al bosque", es la frase que aparece en la pantalla de carga, en la página oficial, y hasta en el mail donde recibimos la key de prensa. 
 
Esta idea de pensar cada movimiento y cada decisión como si fuera la última, se refuerza con conversaciones que tendremos con diversos personajes (todos muy surreales) cuyas respuestas definirán el futuro del juego. Las historias de los personajes que crucemos se mezclarán con la nuestra en la medida que lo permitamos, y cada decisión tendrá siempre consecuencias inesperadas (spoiler: generalmente malas). Incluso hay un pequeño sistema de skills que nos darán ciertas ventajas (o desventajas) y que también tendrán consecuencias indefinidas. No hace falta ser un genio para deducir que este juego intenta hacernos perder con todas sus fuerzas.
 
Recomendamos absolutamente Darkwood, por todo lo que genera, por su originalidad y porque apostamos a que se convertirá en un clásico indie de terror. Advertimos su descarga a jugadores novatos, con poca experiencia en rogue-like o survival, y con poca paciencia. Éste es un juego para transitarlo paso a paso, muy lentamente, a pesar de que nuestro instinto nos dice que corramos sin parar.

35033165.review:
I see it has been too difficult for some people to read this review, so let me paraphrase it, and get this straight again (probably for simple-minded fanboys to understand too):

You cannot sleep at night, nor even cook. Which makes nights a boring waste of time. Unless you're out for a fight, or well-prepared to let enemies into your house.

Also, let's check the condition of a hideout here:

-There's a bed.
-There's a workshop for all kinds of traps.
-You have options to barricade all windows and doors.
-You have a working stove that repels invaders with whatever the mess is in it.

But nope, sleep is forbidden. you have to be awake all night like you're outside.

Sorry, not my cup of tea. Refunded.

35030848.review:
I'm going straight to the point: this game is just amazingly good. 
The interesting gameplay mechanic together with the astonishing and dark art style create a perfectly sinister atmosphere. 
The game succeeds perfectly with shaping every single night into a new dark nightmare.
It can be a bit frustraiting from time to time (especially if you got stuck into your own trap with only moments of night time left and 6 huge dogs after your ass) but I don't see any other flaws in it.
I'll give it 97/100 points, would recommend it to anyone who enjoys playing a good horror game.

Also the sound design is just f***** creepy (=perfect for this game).

34999302.review: Had Darkwood on my radar for a while. It's hard to tell what this game actually is just from Youtube videos so I made use of the free download offered by the devs. After six ingame days I was fully convinced and bought it. I would call it a mix of Hotline Miami and Diablo 2, with a heavy dose of Lovecraft. For each "act" there's a base and you explore the locations and quests around that base. Combat is slow and dangerous and often it's better to avoid fights, although there are some creatures worth looting. The night invasions are too hard for me, not gonna lie. I wouldn't make it past Act2 without the "normal" difficulty. My favorite part so far has been "The Village" with the chickens and pigs... one of the most creepy/unsettling locations in horror games ever. The sound design in Darkwood is excellent. Definitely got my money's worth.

34996719.review:
Наверное, одна из лучших игр выходивших в последнее время. Сразу видно когда силы создателей тратятся не на то чтобы заработать, а на то чтобы сделать хорошую и интересную игру.

О плюсах и минусах:
+ Пронизана насквозь интересным сюжетом, персонажами, историей.
+ Потрясающая атмосфера, просто НЕВЕРОЯТНАЯ атмосфера. Пример того, когда не только графикой, но и звуками и механикой игры вас затягивает с головой прямо "в монитор". Именно атмосфера делает эту игру хоррором: забудьте про скримеры и про подобные глупости.
+ Хороший и выверенный дизайн (изображения не игровых предметов предметы, локации, персонажи, монстры...).
+ Вариативность (у вас не всегда, но всё же есть выбор).
+ Разработчики плевать хотели на то, понятны ли вам те события которые происходят вокруг, или не понятны. Никто не разжёвывает происходящее, никто не пытается ЗАСТАВИТЬ вас поверить в таинственность и загадочность происходящего. Никто не считает вас глупым, или неспособным самостоятельно докопаться до чего-то, и явно ни на что не намекает. Я считаю что это плюс, и именно он делает эту игру шедевральной.
+- Не самая плохая игровая механика, но есть вещи которые мне не понравились. Например, персонаж может отпрыгнуть только назад от того направления, куда направлен курсор.
+- Немного сломанный баланс - вам сложно до тех пор, пока вы не найдёте "грозное оружие". 
+- Уровень сложности тут скорее про хардкорность, а не про усложнение игровых механик. На нормале вы ничего не теряете, и можете умирать сколько угодно. Дальше вы начинаете терять вещи при смерти, у вас становится меньше жизней (3), ну и самая высокая сложность: одна смерть. Для кого-то это наверняка плюс, для кого-то минус.
- Игра затянута в конце первой главы. Становится действительно скучно, и этот момент нужно перетерпеть.

Темнолесье была пройдена приблизительно за 28 часов, на самом "лёгком" уровне сложности. Из-за вариативности игры в ней присутствует множество "концовок" для первых двух глав, и две концовки для эпилога.

На момент написания обзора игра стоит 299 рублей, что я считаю крайне справедливой и скромной ценой.

Если внешний вид игры не отпугивает вас, если вы любите странные и запутанные сюжеты, если вы любите атмосферные игры - почему вы ещё не поиграли в Darkwood?...

34992125.review:
Отличная игра. Отдаю дань уважения разработчикам, выложили игру в бесплатный доступ и я смог её опробовать. я решил обязательно её купить, даже если играть в неё уже не буду. 

Это наверное единственная игра на моей памяти с видом topdown которая не кажется сырой, а чувствуется как полноценный проект. 
Это тот хоррор в котором тебя пугают не скримеры, а давящая жуткая пост-апокалиптическая атмосфера, хотя пока гуляешь по лесу, всё же боишься что сейчас какая нибудь неведома зверушка на тебя вылетит. 
Звуковое сопровождение в этой игре отдельная тема. Довольно атмосферные саундтреки, звуки вроде ночного гула, ветер, шелест листвы, всё это дополняет и без того тяжёлую атмосферу. 
Ночи жуткие, первые дни я просто запирался и сидел в углу с доской наперевес, но потом это стало невозможно [spoiler]так как появились красные чомперы которые выносят всё к херам на своём пути[/spoiler]. 

Сейчас я поведаю вам свой опыт игры. 
Я не планировал в неё надолго залипать когда запустил её в первый раз, хотел всего лишь проверить что она из себя представляет, из за этого даже включил самую высокую сложность при которой смерть - перманентна. Я не жалею что так поступил, страх потерять всё то время впустую(а прожил я тогда 25 дней) давил на меня ещё больше. Да, как вы уже поняли, я всё таки не дожил до конца, с первого раза это сделать по моему невозможно. 
Было 4 случая когда я был на краю пропасти в небытие, но каждый раз выходил из ситуации полумёртвым. На пятый раз выжить не получилось, смерть была довольно глупой, это наверное был баг, от чего я очень расстроился. 
Дело было так: [spoiler]очередная ночь, я придумал новый способ как подпереть дверь так, что бы упыри не смогли войти. Это сработало, дверь открылась, но раскрыться до конца ей помешал диван который упёрся в угол, так и долбился головой упырь об дверь пока не пришёл мутированный шакал. Он меня покарал за то что я воспользовался не то багом, не то фичей. Он просто проскочил насквозь дверь и диван, а в руках у меня была лопата с долгим замахом(а про быстрый удар я совсем забыл из за паники),[/spoiler] так меня и отодрали...

В этой игре много плюшек которые я бы перечислил если бы не моя лень, а так, очень рекомендую хотя бы ознакомится, такую годноту не каждый день встретишь...

34984160.review:
This game is boring, one of the most boring games I have played. Others have said why, I will say why in point form. I have played this enough to make this post fact.


- You have to go back every time to the hideout for the night, that right there makes the game boring. That makes the exploration not good also, and the area is small for the exploration to be fulfilling as well. (This right here the first point is the main problem)

- You can't run for very long, this also makes the game boring.

- Some doors you can't find the code to open the door, searched everywhere. Had to go to youtube to find out. Might be a bug. And when you find the code you don't need the items because, you are way past the point of needing them.

- The dodge is stupid, you move back when all enemies lunge

- All enemies do to much damage

- For surviving the night you get little credits 100 every time, takes to long to get enough credits to complete an item. For example a gun or shotgun, and you have to buy other items as well. For example wood or gas.

- There are no people helping you explore, it would be nice to have while exploring people you come on. Travel with you for some time, then decide to plan out something that they split up. Or decide to leave, choices to be made. Would make the game way better.

- Controls need looked at they are clunky



There might be one or two more but these are the major ones, with the first one being the major major one. Right now it's not worth getting, if you do decide get it on sale. I waited to post because, I was busy with other games and other things.

This game is hard to review. On one hand, the atmosphere and the story is really good, but on the other hand the combat is really annoying for the simple reason that the dodge mechanic only work in one direction: Back.

But I still recommend this game. The gameplay is simple: Go looting the area during the day, and defend your place during the night. The progression is through areas: Once you feel comfortable enough or you are following the story, you can move from hideout to another.

So, in short: I do recommend the game. The atmosphere is paranoia inducing, but the combat gameplay is annoying.

34946159.review:
[h1]Darkwood is a nerve-racking masterpiece, indie horror game like no other. [/h1]

It delivers a truly unique thrilling experience to the player, elegantly combining several elements and mechanics from other genres and mixing them up all-together to create an absolutely phenomenal and original gameplay.

Elements and mechanics such as:
[list]
[*]Exploration
[*]Resource gathering
[*]Crafting
[*]Stealth
[*]CQC Combat
[*]Firearms Combat
[*]Fog of war
[*]Limited peripheral vision
[*]Day/Night cycle 
[*]Weather cycle
[*]Trading and resource management
[*]Gear maintenance (both improving and repairing)
[*]Safehouse maintenance (both improving and fortifying)
[*]Trap deployment
[*]Moving furniture to create blockades
[*]Moving light sources to create an advantage
[*]Planning you overall "productive hours".
[/list]
And more...

Everything is perfectly put together and handed to you in a very hardcore "deal with it" fashion. No tutorials. No help whatsoever. It is up to you to investigate, discover and use your wits, logic and survival instincts. 

After the first night, you will quickly realize how vulnerable you actually are. There is constant sense of urgency in Darkwood, you are essentially and, most literally, against the clock. And this is exactly how the game puts you under permanent fear and tension.

The 2D graphics are beautifully terrifying.
The music is spot on.
The sound effects are just brilliant. 

(I highly recommend playing with a good pair of headphones and the volume all the way up, also turning the lights off in your room is a must.)

Overall, I think Darkwood is a hidden gem and a future classic. It absolutely deserves your attention and your support. Play it.

Hats off and congratulations to the DEV. (He even uploaded the game to a torrent site so people could play this for free... I mean, come on! This guy leads by example!)

Did I mention that it supports 21:9 aspect ratio? Because it does.

I'm playing it @3440x1440 with a GSYNC monitor in all its glory.

34942880.review:
A few years ago, I saw a video of someone playing this game on youtube not really knowing anything about it. Due to it being in early access, i never really looked more into it. A few years later is see that the game is fully released and out on steam. After debating if it was going to be worth it (didn't think top-down was going to be very good) i ended up buying it. 

Boy oh boy was I wrong to judge the top-down style of this game. Not only did it give the game a very interesting perspective that limits what you see yet still show you what is around you. This is used in a exellent way to keep you on your toes as well as make you think every twig snap is a monster ready to kill you. 

The game uses that psychology to bring you disturbing images, creepy NPCs and a haunting enviorment. Yet, they no cheap jump scares which shows that fact that the game developers really know thier horror. To compliment this, the game also has a really good soundtrack and sound effects that add another layer to the spooks. 

Gameplay wise, I found the game to be quite enjoyable even if there were time i was completely lost. The hide and fend off enemies was always tense and never got boring for me. You also seemed to always be rewarded with exploting with either loot or lore. The story unflods in a very non linear manor so it can be easy to skip NPCs or even major story/lore segments. I personally found it quite enjoyable to find everything i could about the story and the stories within the forest. 

Overall i highly recomment this game to any survival horror fan or even people who like hard challanges. If you invest time into this game you will be greatly rewarded with a very intense experience. Good jod Acid Wizard and hope to see your guys next game.

34928746.review:
I've only played about an hour and a half, but I'm so thrilled about my experience with it that I'm writing my first review. 

Woven between the eerily haunting sounds and music, to the foreboding and often claustrophobic atmosphere, there is the gripping storyline and solid and reminiscent gameplay that manages to tie you in knots the further in you go.

This top-down piece of gnarled and beautiful artwork is a pleasure to experiences. I don't feel led by the hand. I feel on my own and that's refreshing.

I highly recommend this game.

34902934.review:
The Sun is going down now.
I rush back to my safe house.
Double check that I gassed up the generator.
Go inside and get the barricades up.
Shit. I'm out of boards, can't make that last window barricade.
Do I tear down my door barricade to go out to the power saw to make more boards
Or, do I take my chances inside with one less barricade between me and them?
Screw it, I'm already inside, I'll just set up some traps by the window and move the lamps away from it.

It's night time now, something knocks at the door.
I hear twigs snapping and leaves crunching as something paces outside in the pitch black forest.
It's assessing my defenses.
Curiousity gets the better of me, I look out the unblocked window.
It looks right back at me and moves toward me with unholy determination.
It gets in through the window and moves right around my traps.
I'm backed into a corner, another one just followed it in.

@#$%.

I wake up alone in my safehouse, the day has started over; looks like I lost this time.

10/10 great to play in the dark with headphones.

34879512.review:
[h1]G'day here's my quick review summary [b][i][without spoilers][/i][/b][/h1]

[b]TL;DR: Should you buy it?[/b] [When on Sale]✓

[h1][b] ϟϟ Ratings ϟ ϟ [/b][/h1]

[b]Estimated Playtime Value: Over 60 Hours[/b]
[b]My playtime: 2 hours[/b]
[b]Refunded: [Yes][/b]
[b]Gameplay: 5/10[/b]
[b]Sound: 8.5/10[/b]
[b]Story: 6.5/10[/b]
[b]Controls 5/10 [Controller not recommended!][/b]
[b]Replay Value: [High] (Unless you follow a guide)[/b]
[b]Price at time of review: 14€[/b]
[b]Bugs: [Some][/b]
[b]Overall Value: 6/10[/b]

[h1][b] ϟϟ First Impressions ϟ ϟ [/b][/h1]

[b]Best thing:[/b] It's immersive and terrifying
[b]Liked:[/b] Art style, environment sounds, opening prologue, scare factor, developer attitude towards customers/players

[b]Disliked:[/b] Basically everything else, item quanity, too much that needs managing, slow build up, story seems to just drop off after the prologue
[b]Worst thing:[/b] No ability to attack/defend without a crafted weapon

[h1][b] ϟϟ Funny ϟ ϟ [/b][/h1]

You're trapped in a forest, but wood is one of the most scarce resources...

[h1][b]2 Paragraph Full Review:[/b][/h1]

Initially I really liked Darkwood a lot. I also really liked the developer's attitude towards their customers/players and that they also released the game for free on torrents to let people test and play it, in the hopes that they would contribute to its development and eventually end up purchasing it. I applaud the devs for basically releasing a full demo of the game just like in the old PS1 days for people to see whether or not they like it enough to buy it.

Sadly however the game falls short of [i]enjoyable[/i] in almost every regard for me. There is just way too many game mechanics that stand in the way of me being able to enjoy the game. You can't defend yourself without a weapon, you can only sprint for 7 seconds every 4 seconds. There's no information on what items have value and what don't. Using a controller is not at all recommended as you cannot properly interact with some objects (dragging & placing) and you also cannot effectively fight off enemies. A huge amount of backtracking is required to unlock containers/doors when you finally acquire the codes. The first few nights just involve you sitting in the dark for 8 minutes just waiting for the next day and the story just sort of disappears after the prologue.

[h1][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h1]

The game needs an overall balance and more thought needs to go into object quanity in the game world. Perhaps some useful tips for starting out could be suggested. I'm all for hardcore games but throwing you into a game that requires so much micro management and giving you no hints makes me feel like any enjoyment I would get out of it, would only come after tens of hours of fighting game mechanics. The worst part is that I feel like with a guide written out, you could exploit all of the mechanics as soon as someone writes out how to most efficiently get the best items and zig-zag through the game areas safely.

Buy it when it is on sale (even just 33% off) or when (if) balancing changes to the game have been made, where it will definitely be worth the full asking price.

34871692.review:
I quite like Darkwood. Have been playing it since it was in Early Access, far before even Alpha 8.1 (as thats my last save before it came out of EA). There have been fantastic moments in this game that have not been replicated by any other game. The sheer dread that this game brings is nothing short of fantastic. 

I have one gripe with the game, and that is simply one that not many users will ever encounter a problem with. The default gamepad controls are garbage. The tutorial does not indicate what buttons you're supposed to press to interact with anything, and the way they're implemented also seems like an afterthought. This game (from my understanding) was built from the ground up with Mouse and Keyboard in mind, so remember that if you prefer using a gamepad. 

Apart from that, it has been a pleasure to have been a part of this game's journey to release, and it still holds up as a fantastic game!

34870761.review:
I've been using Steam since 2006, and this is the first time i actually bother my lazy ass to sit down and write a review. 
It's hard to surpirse and old gamer, this is why "Darkwood" is such a refreshing breeze. It's not happens very often that you encouter a game so original, creative, and masterfully crafted. It's not happens very often when you acutally get to play something different. It's been a while since a computer game was able to glue me to the screen for so many hours.  It is quite obvious that this is a game made by people who love games, for people who love games. 

I would like to mention that i only played this game on "nightmare" diffeculty ever since i bought it in it early access phase. My gamplay count is 50+ hours and day 8 in the old woods is as far as i got. Thankfully, the game keep surprising me with every new run. Playing on "nightmare" means that once you die, it's game over. And i believe that this is how this game meant to be played. It seems that the other diffeculties settings is there just to appeal to more casual players. 

The amtmosphere in this game is pretty much like a dream (well, a nightmare to be more precise) - everything is too strange and surreal to be considered reality, but than again, reality to you and everyone else. The sounds of the forest, it strange inhabitants, the feeling of been hunted and the fact that everything can end in seconds - all of that just top notch. 

All of that being said - darkwood is not a game for mouse mashers, the impatience, or gamers without imagination. But for those among you who think they seen at all - your in for a dark surprise. 
Can't recommend this game enough. Can't wait to see what "Acid Wizard" will come up with next.

34866067.review:
I bought this game thrice- the first time I refunded was because the constant micro-stuttering after around 5 hours of game time frustrated me and I decided to wait until further optimisation. The second time Acid Wizard updated the game to 1.1 and I thought the stutter is fixed but it turns out the issue prevails, so I go back and play the torrented version because the gameplay quality persuaded to remain attached until the endning.

And despite the stuttering issue remains unfixed (as of 1.1 hotfixed 3), after reaching the true ending, I decided to buy it for the third time and plan not to refund it anymore.

Could a horror game still be a horror game even if there's no jumpscares whatsoever? Wouldn't be a "thriller" game instead? Darkwood provided an answer of "yes, it can be". Darkwood is not just an action adventure game with horror elements like Bloodborne, but a truly horrifying experience in and of itself. With the absence of jumpscares, it instead provides subtle and astonishing good visual and audio effects to not only give you some chils, but also anxiety, fear and pressure. From small but spikey plank cracking sound when you explore certain abandoned werehouse, to highly detailed and gruesome body horror pixel art, the three devs of the game may been rookies in programming, but have solid skills at poking the nerves and sentimentality of their audience. The epilogue futher exemplify such craftsmanship.

I consider Darkwood to be the world's first real "survival horror game". Despite Resident Evil is the game that coined the term, the survival element is weak, since with good enough skills, level pattern memorising and ample ammunition, not only can you speedrun it efficiently, but also dance around the enemy with your knifing mastery. But with Darkwood, since the environment is semi randomly generated- with same amount of key locations but at different directions from your hideout each time you start a new playthrough, caution and thourough exploration of every corner becomes a must. Adding daytime limit, you will be forced to stay in your hideout and fend off enemies mutiple nights instead of skipping them. You are constantly being hunted by enemies and by both resource and time scarcity, and at occations forced to be defensive and stationed, therefore you are trying to "survive".

That is not to say the game doesn't have flaws. The micro stuttering I encountered are not only frequent, but also often occured at vital moments such as the beginning of mine or enemie's attack animation, leading to misjudgement of spacing and timing of dodging, which could be lethal. The dodging mechanism is also over clunky. Not only does it spend stamina and has cool down, you can only jump backwards regardless which direction key you hold with the dodge button, leading the skill to be mostly unused but by minor skillful player. It would be great if the dev could allow your character to dodge in accordance to each WASD key you press. Fortunately the purchasability of ammunition and firearm in late game reduced the necessity for this mechanism.

as of right now, I give it a 9/10. When the stuttering is fixed, it will become 10/10

34856915.review:
[h1]QUICKIE: [b]DARKWOOD[/b][/h1]

L' horror è un genere videoludico che non ha i requisiti di, per esempio, un gioco d'azione per riuscire nel proprio intento e Darkwood ne è la prova, grafica abbastanza semplice in 2d con visuale dall' alto, meccaniche di combattimento estremamente basilari... eppure credo sia uno dei migliori horror degli ultimi 10 anni... mi ricorda tantissimo il primo Silent Hill, punta poco sul gore e molto più sull' atmosfera generale e lo fa in modo esemplare.
Un particolare elogio va a chiunque si sia occupato del sound design e del reparto musicale, le canzoni sono stupende, un ambient perfetto che accompagnerà i luoghi che visiterete ed i momenti che vivrete nel gioco e che cambierà in base alle situazioni, mentre il suond design riesce a mettere la giusta ansia, soprattutto quando siete nella vostra casa/base, rinchiusi per bene nella vostra stanza (che non sarà mai sicura al 100%) e sentite dei passi all' esterno... poi sentirete qualcuno bussare... cosa fare, andare alla porta e trovare un regalo da parte di uno sconosciuto (oppure un mostro in attesa del vostro arrivo) o aspettare e vedere che succede? ... altri colpi alla porta e poi... silenzio. Vi assicuro che raccontata così non rende l' idea della tensione del momento, ma se doveste decidere di giocarlo capirete di cosa sto parlando.
Altro elogio va alla scelta grafica e stilistica dei developer (che sono solo 3 ragazzi!), il 2d con la vista dall' alto è stata una scommessa, soprattutto per un gioco horror, ma la visuale limitata del protagonista (praticamente potete vedere solo un cono nella direzione verso cui siete girati) rende l' esplorazione un continuo guardarsi le spalle, soprattutto quando si ha l' impressione ci sia qualcosa dietro di noi (dovuto a qualche rumore, a volte quasi impercettibile). Inoltre i personaggi principali che incontrerete avranno delle vignette disegnate a mano che li rappresentano e sono tutti stupendi da vedere (almeno per un horror) ed hanno tutti un carattere particolare, alcuni vi saranno amici, altri meno, ma tutti hanno delle storie personali che potete completare (e che influenzeranno, in parte o no, il finale del gioco).
La storia è alla Dark Souls, la linea principale non è esattamente chiara mentre quelle dei personaggi che incontrerete hanno un inizio ed una fine e si intrecciano fra di loro, inoltre un finale vi lascerà con tantissime domande mentre l' altro (a quanto pare, visto che io ho concluso il gioco con il primo) ne chiarirà una buona parte.
Darkwood è un horror che mi ha sorpreso, un horror vecchio stile in cui si abbandona la moda degli ultimi (la vista in prima persona, i jumpscare gratuiti che alla lunga diventano solo una noia ed il gore senza senso) e si fonda sulle caratteristiche che rendono un horror ciò che è, la paura dello sconosciuto e dell' inquietante, quel continuo guardarsi alle spalle e l' aguzzare occhi ed orecchie ad ogni suono sconosciuto.

[b][i]++ La visuale dall' alto usata in modo magistrale
++ Lo stile grafico (sia del gioco che delle vignette dei personaggi)
+ La storia (o meglio, LE storie)
+ Un vero videogioco horror che trae ispirazione da ottime fonti

- Lo svolgimento della storia avviene per lo più tramite testo scritto, non essendoci una traduzione ita potrebbe essere un problema per i non anglofoni[/i]

https://davedarkomusic.wixsite.com/videogamando/darkwood

34838345.review:
Video review with more depth: https://youtu.be/kkLquJcFyEA

[b]PROS:[/b]
-Incredibly well-done horror aspect
-All enemies can kill you easily
-Safe houses aren't necessarily safe
-Random supernatural events during the night make you question your own sanity
-Dynamic music provides an atmosphere of dread and tension
-While some weapons can OHK enemies, they're usually expensive and can be lost forever
-High difficulty curve adds to the horror aspect
-Very little hand-holding; you learn most of the game through trial and error
-Weapons take practice to use properly
-Resources do not respawn in the game world - once you take them, they're gone
-Survival part isn't as good as the horror aspect, but still great nonetheless
-Most of your time is spent searching the forest for supplies just to survive the night
-Supplies are extremely valuable and are often crucial to your survival
-Mysterious and well-developed game world
-Game's backstory is intentionally kept vague to add a sense of mystery
-Destroyed tanks, burned houses, and absorbed corpses give off a sense of despair
-Interesting and unique characters, such as the wolfman and the trader
-The setting of the game itself seems like the enemy here
-Lots of gameplay to be had, since completing missions takes a lot of preparation
-Vision is done very well for a top-down game - 90 degree cone shows enemies and items
-Beautiful animation for a 2D game
-Overall art style is very nice, showing forest and fields in black, white and color

[b]NEUTRALS[/b]
-The game is very slow, typical for most survival games

[b]CONS[/b]
-AI sometimes glitches out, tries to run through walls
-Lots of aliasing in-game and in the menus


This could be one of the best games of this decade, up there with Limbo and Metro in terms of atmosphere. Also it's only 15 dollars. However, if you don't like survival games, then I'd stay away.

Score: 10/10 (Perfect)

34836599.review:
Просто потрясный инди-хоррор-выживалка! Прошел на одном дыхании.
- Интересный сюжет. Как общий, так и локальные истории тоже порадуют. Здесь у каждого дома, у каждого персонажа есть своя история, которую хочется раскрыть.
- Шикарная атмосфера леса полного неизвестности и опасностей. Атмосферу держит хорошо обыгранный свет, зона видимости и отличное звуковое сопровождение.
- Это не самый страшный хоррор, в который я играл, но тех, кто банальным скримерам предпочитает нагнетающую мощную атмосферу, жуткие сюжетные повороты и отчаянные попытки продержаться живым еще одну ночь, - точно аденалином не обделит.

Полученный игровой опыт с лихвой перехлестывает затраченную на игру сумму, по личным ощущениям. Редкий бриллиант среди инди-игр, слаженный и цельный. Быть может мой обзор покажется слишком "положительным", но я до сих пор нахожусь под впечатлением от игры.

Разработчикам успехов и жду новых шедевров!

34833496.review:
5 años han tardado los chicos de Greenlight en crear este juego... y se nota. Muy buena ambientación, un apartado gráfico/artístico buenísimo y gran jugabilidad. Llevo jugando a esto de los survival horror desde que recuerdo el Amstrad cpc, y entre tanto juego casual, y tanto survival pasillero (layers od fear, outlast 2...), nos hacía falta ya un juego que pone nervioso de verdad y que deja opciones a como enfrentar las situaciones. 
Recoger cosas y que cada una cuente, comerciar, reforzar los refujios, temer la noche... el juego te mantiene en constante tensión y hay momentos de acojone vivo in the night.  

Contras: Los españoles somos los únicos del mundo que nos vamos a quejar de que no esté en nuestro puto idioma, a joderse y a aprender, pero lo que si me parece un fallo del juego es que los subtítulos son un pelín rápidos, unos segundos más, o la opciones de pasarlos a demanda no hubiera estado mal. 

Habrá a quien no le guste por ser un juego un poco lento, es pausado, hay que ser paciente en mas de una ocasión, pero esto se compensa por su intensidad.

A cascarla.

34815692.review:
The game Darkwood has been sitting in my library for a long time. It was only after the full release recently that I decided to sit down and allocate some time to try it. I am new to this genre of game (top down survival horror). 
I didn't expect it can be so addictive afterwards. 

All I could say was, this game is awesome. The environment, creatures, and other sort of sounds are simply amazing. If you played Amnesia: The Dark Descent or Alien Isolation for example, then you will remember how sounds plays so much role in setting up the mood, tension, fear, and relaxation.

Of course game play will be just as important as sound. First comes the prologue which lets you get some taste of its control scheme and top down style. I got to admit that at the beginning, I was skeptical whether a top down survival horror game would be as good as the first or third person kind of survival horror game. After playing for 20 hours (at hideout 2), I would like to say yes, the sound, game play, control scheme (some people may express opinion that its movement are a little bit clunky, but I'd like to say that it is more towards getting used to it) are right on point. In fact, now I am more proficient in dealing with the Savages. 

You got to appreciate the details the developers put in into the world of Darkwood.

There's more to say, but right now, I just wishes that Darkwood will have many more content in the future. Perhaps even Darkwood II and so on!

34806468.review:
"Darkwood" is a top-down survival horror where you run around a particularly bad patch of the woods and try not to get mauled to death by the unrelenting horrors that wait for you as you try to escape the woods. Now before I say anything more about the game I have to give credit to this game's sound design, most often in this game it is not what is immediately visible that causes fear but more so what is heard. Unfamiliar footsteps, the door to your hideout being opened, or just anything you generally can't recognise audibly, because more often then not whatever it is doesn't want to make friends. It is utterly terrifying to be boarded up in one of the hideouts at night because of how well the sound goes along with the horror aspect of the game. Sometimes the longest nights are the ones where nothing happens, simply because something COULD happen at any time and letting your guard down won't help your survival odds. 

There is quite a bit of mystery and lore to be found during the endearing attempt at survival in these woods, which compliments just how foreign the woods actually feel as a location. Things simply do not work the way they should and the game expects the player to try to learn and adapt to this, all the while dropping hints at what may have occured during when the woods was turned into the horrible thing it now is. This ties things together quite well seeing as while the player is trying to stay alive they are also encouraged to explore the worse-off areas to either find supplies or even to just try to comprehend the woods itself, through the small trinkets they find throughout the woods.

Overall if any games like "Silent Hill" or perhaps the older "Resident Evil" titles have any of your interest I would suggest giving "Darkwood" a go, as its one of the better horror titles that I have personally enjoyed in quite some time.

34769608.review:
[h1] Уважай Лес![/h1] 

Survival horror'ы не назовешь популярным жанром, а потому каждый новый тайтл привлекает внимание к себе. Сегодня пришла очередь поговорить о Darkwood.

[h1] Графика:[/h1] 

Детализированно-пиксельная графика. Смотрится очень хорошо...детализация для такой графики просто удивительна...а ее оживление анимацией добавляет стиля и атмосферности...Представьте себе некую отвратительную смесь плоти и растительного мира, которая вечно движется...пульсирует будто гоняя по своим венам кровь.

[h1] Звук:[/h1] 

Божественный для игры такого типа ОСТ...здесь есть буквально все, что нужно мрачной игре с элементами хоррора: угнетающие мотивы одиночества, мрачные заунывные звуки мистики и даже "спасительный" эмбиент нового дня. Солидную часть атмосферы игры составляют "случайные события и связаннные с ними звуки"...но о них я поговорю отдельно.

[h1] Геймплей:[/h1] 

Выживастик во всем великолепии...
Итак, каждый наш день в игре делится на 3 фазы - утро/день, сумерки и ночь. Утром обычно готовишься к выходу на поиски припасов, торгуешь с неписем...А дальше привет основная часть - поиски всего, что плохо лежит и что продлит Вашу жизнь еще на денек...Найденные поленья превращаются в доски, так необходимые для крафта и баррикадирования убежища, канистра бензина обеспечит на ночь светом и дополнительной защитой от ночных тварей, а какие-то грибы позволят ширнуться очередной дозой сомнительной гадости.
В сумерки же все найденное утаскивается обратно для переработки и укрепления своего временного пристанища...
А дальше ночь...и вот это самое напряженное время суток...но об этом в "Атмосфере". 

Тут важно понимать, что ресурсов мало, для спасения себя всегда что-то надо...хоть наш ГГ жрать не просит...и на том спасибо. Так или иначе - игра вынуждает постепенно двигаться дальше...ресурсы не восстанавливаются, находятся новые места для убежища, а местный алкоголик-велосипедист за бутылку самогона готов перевезти весь хабар из одного убежища в другое.

И так постепенно, перемещаясь все дальше...знакомясь с местными "жителями", отбиваясь от фауны и читая лор проходит все приключение.

[h1] Атмосфера:[/h1] 

Да-да...отдельным пунктом.
Игра заслуживает того, чтобы ее атмосфера была рассмотрена таким образом. Начнем же с того, что Darkwood не совсем хоррор...точнее будет сказать, что игра умеет создать атмосферу длительного напряжения...особенно ночью.

Вот Вам пара примеров: ночь за окном...вдруг слышны шаги где-то возле дома и открывается входная дверь...пойдя и проверив ее можно никого не найти...но вдруг в окно влетает камень, а свет ламп предательски угасает...Дальше больше - так старательно прикрытая шкафом дыра будет открыта какой-то тварью, которая с оглушительным рыком бросится на Вас....доживете ли до утра - еще вопрос....Другая была ситуация - пол ночи кто-то стучал в дверь...выглянув в окно я увидел убегающего голого мужика...думаю...ну и хрен с тобой...чуть позже прилетели какие-то духи и отрубили генератор. Пришлось выбегать на улицу, отмахиваться какой-то палкой от обезумевших собак и пытаться врубить генератор...так он еще зараза - кряхтел и не включался.

Вторая часть атмосферы создается стилем....это пульсирующее и двигающееся окружение, эти измененные лесом мутанты...это мрачные закутки и темные рощи...эти пока еще сохранившие остатки разума жители.

Я бы еще рассказал немного о сюжете, но смысла не вижу...интереснее в сюжет и лор вникать самому.

[h1] Итог:[/h1] 

Отличная игра, с великолепной атмосферой, хорошим стилем и понятным геймплеем. Выживешь ты или выживут тебя-все просто.
Моя оценка - 9 из 10.

P.S. ах да, стоит отметить забавный способ борьбы с пиратством от разработчиков...Они выложили на торрент-трекер полную лицензионную версию Darkwood...это из разряда - "Вот вам, подавитесь" xD

Очень классная и атмосферная игра, с детально проработанным сюжетом и проработанными персонажами, концовку нашел только одну, но к ней можно дойти разными способами, после прохождения от ваших действий будет зависеть история этих персонажей и в дальнейшем Вам ее расскажут. 
Графика крайне приятная, интерфейс не мешает, управление замечательное и к нему быстро привыкаешь. 
Музыка и звуки погружают тебя в игру еще сильнее, особенно понравилась музыка утром, когда пережил тяжелую ночь. 
И что самое классное от игры не устаешь, с каждым разом все сильнее противники и все интереснее и запутаннее истории. 
На прохождение потратил, примерно, 20 часов изучив все территории. 
Советую к прохождению, еще одна хороша инди игра в список.

Otherwise, it was a great game that had me intrigued for many hours. 

It was difficult enough that I kept playing in short sprints.

It truly is creepy... Every night. ;)

I wish I had not ruined the storyline by killing NPCs due to frustration of not knowing what to do and having walked the maps many times over for clues.  That is one thing... whereas vastly popular games can be Youtube researched, walk throughs and guides for DW are sparse.

I gave up right before Chapter 2 (due to my inability to find the doctor or code to train wreck) and watched the endings on Youtube. I think once you play through much of Chapter 1, you've pretty much experienced the overall feel and mechanics, however, The Endings are worth a play through if you havent ruined the potential to progress by killing off the NPCs.

34758977.review:
This is the best game I've played in a long time. The story is interesting and mysterious. The atmosphere instills a sense of dread in increasingly intense ways. The enemy design is great. Nothing feels overly repetitive. The choices you make actually change the course of the game too. I felt as if my play-through was unique to how my personality was affected by the games characters and horrors. 
I'm not usually into scary games. The jump scares feel cheap and the excessive gore isn't scary. This game had neither. It uses sounds to put you into an unsettled mood. It uses limited visibility to instill a sense of paranoia. It uses ever increasing threats to make sure you don't get comfortable. 34751112.review:
This game is absolutely fantastic. It nails it's aesthetic and offers a creepy as heck atmosphere complete with a killer soundtrack. The gameplay is actually quite compelling to me, the long stretches of navigation, that lead into rather intense confrontations between Savages, Beasts, and Monstrosities that litter the Darkwood. It combines exploration and resource gathering during the day, with a survive the night style of base defense. (Think a real time The Last Stand y'know, the Flash game. With less enemies, but they all pose a greater threat.) The game is quite generous on Normal, and a proper nightmare on Nightmare. The artwork is incredibly detailed and down right haunting in some instances. The characters in the game all feel varied, and all feel as if they belong in the world. Overall, for fifteen dollars I cannot sing this game's praises enough.

The artstyle is just amazingly scary and disturbing, and the audio design is just magnificent.

Oh. Don't forget. Always answer the door.

34739244.review:
Really, really wish I could recommend the game, but the devs spent way too much effort on hobbling the player for a very forced, clumsy level of difficulty, and not enough time on figuring out the difference between "challenging" and "tedious".  Here's a short list of the lazy design items: very narrow player cone of vision, consistently poor lighting (even when carrying your own light), your view is CONSTANTLY obscured by foliage, very low player health, and TERRIBLE combat design.  After the first few hours, the spookiness was completely replaced with annoyance at just never being able to reliably see, and constantly getting smacked from behind by critters slipping past you while fighting.

It's bad gameplay design masked as "challenging".  The final nail in the coffin for me was a story sequence where the game outright STEALS FROM THE PLAYER, which is an inexcusably lazy piece of design.  Even worse, it's completely avoidable but only IF you know about the event ahead of time (which means looking things up, defeating the point of experiencing the game yourself), and the items can be lost PERMANENTLY based on an event requiring the use of the terrible combat gameplay.  Massively frustrating when the items are especially valuable and you've been holding onto them for hours, only to have them taken (and lost) IMMEDIATELY before being able to actually use them.  I could recover from the loss, but honestly, I just don't have any kind of desire to slog through any more of the game to do it.

The atmosphere of the game is fantastic, actually PLAYING the game is not even remotely worth the time.

Story and setting are unique, interesting and wierd at the same time. The atmosphere and creatures can be very creepy at times.

During the day you explore the area surrounding your safe house(s), scavenge and bring the story forward. During the night you should not venture from the relative safety of your abode.

That safety is relative, as you will get uninvited visitors with murderous intents. Being outside during the night however WILL lead to certain death.

I recommend starting with normal difficulty until you've mastered the mechanics.

34701563.review: Darkwood is a top down perspective horror survival game that is by far my favorite horror game so far. I love everything about this game. It has a extremely unique pixelated art style that gives off a beautiful and creepy atmosphere. The storyline is very intriguing because you get to decide how the story progresses throughout the game by doing certain quests and actions. I love the survival aspect of this game where it lets you craft weapons, supplies, and traps using resources that you scavenge from the many abandoned houses and areas in the game and then defending your hideout at night. Its very satisfying to have the best guns and melee weapons in the game in your inventory, having hideouts full of loot, and taking down the many hostiles you come across ingame. I have followed development of this game for the longest time and have loved seeing the progress it has made. There used to be a single hideout in the whole game in the past where you would just explore around the map, now you're able to go to many different hideouts and areas of the game and follow its amazing storyline. I loved playing all the way through the game and hope to play through it again for the achievements and the great experience. I have 75+ hours on my other account and i'm hoping that this game will continue to get more popular because it is such a unique and fascinating game.

34701373.review:
Dark, twisted, and terrifying. Survival is the name of the game and it gets pretty treacherous at times. Very interesting way to present a narrative which plays out kind of like a Dark Souls storyline. The lore is pretty interesting, and there is a surprising amount of it. The vibe is a strange mix of Evil Dead/Silent Hill: spooky, supernatural, and haunting. The visuals are dark and beautiful, but what really shines is the sound design. Bone chilling music top this game off as a memorable experience that will shake you to your core and make you wary of the shadows. 

Super cool of the devs to release a torrent version. I would buy this game again to support them. I hope there is more content to come!

34683122.review:
Such an awesome game. It's a lot of fun and at the same time exciting and creepy. I can definitely recommend  it :)

edit: I realized that sadly it's not as random as I thought it was. Locations like houses, trees etc are at different spots on the map and sometimes rotated, but they're still all the same and the same events occur. So if you play the game for the second or third time you can make different story related decisions (e.g. kill somebody you didn't kill last time), but besides that there's really not much variation, the radomness is very superficial, you pretty much know what's coming.
It seems like the inner core of this game is the story, which forces the exploration & survival part to be kind of shallow and repetitive. That again makes exploring the story in different ways a bit dull, because there's all this predictable gameplay in between. Don't get me wrong, it's still a gripping game, but really only the first time you play it. I really whish they'd  either focused completely on the story or made a true random survival game. In my opinion, this fusion of both doesn't add up to some grate combination, it only subtracts and there's a lot of wasted potential.

34680545.review:
I never liked this new wave of survival games that are coming out in the last years like mushrooms. You just have to focus on repetitive actions of a repetitive gameplay, aimed to keep you busy with a high difficulty, while hiding the total lack of storytelling or innovation.

I can say now that this is different because of Darkwood.

The game has a powerful storytelling, especially in the prologue, and a nice atmosphere thanks to great sound effects. Listening to the creaking of the wood, the creatures moving in the darkness, knocking and searching is a really terrifying experience. It is the true example of how often the environmental effects are more important than the graphic to generate a sense of oppressive fear.

The game alternates exploration of a creepy and mysterious forest during the day, and pure survival and horror moments during the night. During the exploration you will meet mysterious, creepy and weird characters, inhabitants of Darkwood. The characters are really one of the best feature of the game, innovative creepy and original. The lore is also unique and intriguing, with every building or village hiding a new interesting environment. 

If you want to try a survival game but also a complete game, with an interesting and deep lore, a surreal storytelling and an oppressive atmosphere, you should try Darkwood.
