34676814.review:
So Darkwood is pretty spooky, which is good seeing that it's a big part of the game. For a while I've been searching for a horror game that doesn't just use jumpscares and loud noises to freak the player, and I'm pleasantly with Darkwood. I think it's better in a horror game to be afraid of what you think is around the corner, rather than it running out at you. The closest part to an actual jumpscare is in the prologue when a guy runs at you, but it isn't a "jumpscare;" there isn't a loud noise to startle you. Overall I've been enjoying it very much, although I do have to take breaks because the game is [i] immensely[/i] stressful.

tl;dr

Pros:
- Very good psychological horror
- No jumpscares so far
- Very spooky
- Nice story
- Interesting characters
- Very unforgiving; doesn't hold your hand
- Amazing soundtrack; fits well with whatever is happening
- Controls are nice and responsive

Cons: (Mind you that I haven't played the whole game, therefore haven't been able to experience some potential glitches and exploits)
- Every now and then inside of one of my houses, I will hear loud footsteps near me. Not sure if this is intentional, but it doesn't seem like it because it happens during the daytime
- Sometimes the combat can be unresponsive or unclear, however it isn't game breaking
- I feel very stressed for time at certain points, mainly when I'm at the village, since it is so far from my hideout
- Very rarely, the AI can be dumb i.e. I can walk in a straight line from a monster and it will turn 
around
- Can feel repetitive at times

Overall, very nice game, good horror, 8.4/10

34674450.review:
Ну что тут скажешь...
Замечательная игра, которая с EA валялась у меня в загашнике, и попробовал я ее только после релиза.
Ничуть не пожалел, кстати.

Довольно высокий - как по мне, - порог вхождения.
Первые два-три часа я получал люлей от каждого встречного бомжа с палкой, оказывался покусан за мягкое и выступающее каждой шелудивой псиной, с завидным постоянством влипал в поросль ядовитых грибов и с упорством, достойным лучшего применения, собирал жэппой собственные же капканы, в панике мечась посреди ночи по домику. А еще обожал покупать всякую срань, в данный момент мне совершенно не требующуюся.
Но. Стоило положить чутка сил, прикрутить немношк внимательности, чуточку сосредоточенности и освоиться с боевой системой (то есть, просто соблюсти подсказанные правила: уважай лес, сосредоточься, запасись терпением), как - вуаля! - сезон охоты на бомжей, лосей, собак и чомперов открыт!

Сводясь к списочкам.

Плюсы:
- стиль. От звука до картинки, от мобов до НПС, от крафта до исследования. Чувствуется буквально во всем, составляя очень цельную картину.
- атмосфера. Загадочно, мрачно, пугающе. Все происходящее пронизано давящей, осязаемо безысходностью, в которой правильным решениям не место.
- ощутимая сложность. Касательно и самого порога вхождения (честно предупреждают - за ручку никто водить не станет), и далее, включая столкновения с противниками, менеджмент ресурсов и эксплоринг. Да, конечно, сложность варьируется при старте новой игры, но.
- ощущение времени. Черт, это прелестная черта любой игры (конечно же, не касается миссий на время ГОРИТЕ В АДУ), но в данном случае, это - явный дамоклов меч, постепенно опускающийся к твоей шее. Порой, замечтавшись, несешься домой, сшибая все деревья на своем пути.
- неоднозначность и вариативность. Начинка карты генерируется процедурно при старте новой игры. Сюжетные линии НПС переплетаются под неожиданными углами, оставляя поводы для раздумий перед решающим шагом.
- разрабы. В том смысле, что взяла у меня игра такая и крэшнулась. Я отправил им репорт об этом деле, и через пару часов мне и пишут - ПеКу обнови, днищще ты такое. То есть, поблагодарили за репорт, объяснили, в чем беда, и пожелали всего хорошего. Не вспоминая уж о том, что они сами разместили игру на торренте для тех, у кого нету денежков на ее приобретение.

Из минусов:

- нуууу, пожалуй, я бы сказал, что хотелось бы чего-то более крипового. Не то что бы не крипово бродить в этом Темном Лесу, просто мне бы хотелось покриповее.
- иии, наверное, все.

Объективно, со своими задачами игра справляется на "ура". Въехав в процесс, оторваться становится сложно.
Чего и вам желаю. Спасибо за внимание.

34672960.review:
Ich habe nun ca. 90% des Story content gesehen und bin somit der Meinung ein vernünftiges Review abgeben zu können.

Ich gehe nicht auf die Grafik ein, schaut euch 1-2 Videos an und ihr wisst bescheid.

Die Atmosphäre,
davon lebt Darkwood, es ist düster kalt und einsam. Man spielt hier wahnsinnig gut mit Licht und Schatteneffekte. Habe bisher kaum ein Spiel gesehen das die Schatten und Lichteffekte sogut nutzt. Diese Effekte sind ein Hauptkriterium des Spiels und vieles dreht sich um die Nutzung dieser "Ambiente". Es kommt ein sehr gutes Gefühl der Angst und des Verloren sein rüber.
Die Musik/Musikalische Effekte sind wirklich gelungen, das Spiel lebt wie erwähnt von seiner düsteren und beängstigenden Atmosphäre. Ein ganz klares Daumen hoch dafür.

Die Story,
ist ebenso wie die Atmosphäre natürlich ein Kernpunkt des Spiels. Grundsätzlich dreht sich das Spiel darum, dass man in einen Walt auftaucht und nicht weiß wie man dahin kam aber wieder raus will. Dieser Wald ist nicht wirklich einladend und sehr ..menschlich ebensowenig. Es gibt einige Quests und einige Charaktere die eine eigene teils widerlich erschreckende Geschichte mit sich führen. Die Storys der einzelnen primären Charaktere wird gut und glaubwürdig erzählt.

Der Spielsinn,
es geht darum, dass man tagsüber Dinge sucht und findet, seine "Basis" ausbaut und verstärkt, Schränke hin und her schiebt um Türen zu versperren. Natürlich auch die Map zu erkunden und der Storyline zu folgen. Seine basis ausbauen hat den Sinn, weil man sich Nachts in der verbunkern muss. Nachts sollte man sich nicht draußen bzw. außerhalb seines Haus aufhalten. 
Man kann Waffen aufwerten und bauen. Sich gewisse Heilgegenstände herstellen und Öl finden/kaufen (es gibt Händler) um seinen Generator zu starten um für die Nacht Licht zu haben. Man kann seine Fähigkeiten auch Aufwerten. Das ist aber eher marginal.


Fazit:
Das Spiel vergibt dir nicht. Du hast kein Tutorial und keine Erklärungen du wirst reingeworfen und musst klarkommen. Das ist erfrischend aber gleichzeitig auch sehr hart. Das Spiel hat ne sehr verstörend (geile) Storyline der man gerne folgt (nichts für Hasenfüße).
Es hat verdammt viel Potenzial für einen nachfolger, viele Dinge kann man erweitern / Verbessern.
Das Spiel hat von mir eine eindeutige Kaufempfehlung und sollte jeden "Survival Horror" Liebhaber zufrieden stellen. 
Kauft es und testet es! :)

------
Weiter unten sind Spoiler, die sich aber nur auf einen angenehmeren Start beziehen. Weder Story spoiler noch Cheats oder Hilfen im Sinne von "wo finde ich was".
------






Spoiler (Nur Hilfen für den START):
Der Einstieg kann unter Umständen echt schwierig sein daher hier ein paar Tipps.
Mit Q könnt ihr eure Fähigkeiten nutzen die ihr durch die Spritze aktiviert (sie sind nicht! automatisch aktiv)
Mit M öffnet ihr die Karte.
Mit J öffnet ihr eure Journey, die tw. wenn man mal nicht weiterkommt sehr Hilfreich ist.
Wenn Ihr die rechte Maustaste mit einer Waffe gedrückt haltet dann "zielt ihr" (sozusagen) währendessen könnt ihr euch bewegen. Wartet den Schlag des Gegners ab und schlag dann zu.
Wenn ihr eine Nacht überlebt, ist in eurem Zuhause direkt vor euch ein Händler. Wo ihr diverse Sachen kaufen und verkaufen könnt. Dieser Händler kommt nur wenn ihr die Nacht ÜBERLEBT.
Das sollte für den Start ausreichen :)

34634330.review:
I should start with the fact that I avoided the early access phase of the game, which is something i never do, i was recommended by several of my subs to play and compile a full video review of the game a couple years ago, and still, to this day get requests, so if that's any indication of how much fans of the genre love this game, idk what is. 

Aesthetically i love what they have done here, they created a drab, depressing and oppressive environment! Isometric games have always been a favorite of mine going all the way back to the original Legend Of Zelda on NES, and this genre is starting to see a fair share of isometric games. Don't Starve comes to mind, though more survival than horror, Project Zomboid is another fine example, these are good times for our niche demographic, that's for damn sure!

The sound design is also fantastic, obviously it features a lot of tense music but also has a few, very 80's, John Carpenter inspired tracks. Something most of us have no doubt begun to recognize in the industry, many games are doing this, and you won't find me complaining! Synth inspired music is pure ear candy to a child of the 80's! The monsters all have unique and terrifying sound effects, weapons sound crisp and clean, everything from tossing down traps to opening doors is spot on and they also seem to be making use of dynamic music that changes tone depending on your location/progress through an area. 

Both of these things, aesthetics and sound, come together flawlessly to deliver the kind of survival horror experience MANY of us have not had since the Silent Hill series was in full swing (Team Silent age) rather than relying on cheap jump scares, the game elevates the tension slowly, and relentlessly! Forcing the player to move through environments that, they much rather avoid. 

That's not to say the game is without it's "OH SH#%!" moments. It has those, but it doesn't clobber you over the head with them! 

The story thus far has me absolutely intrigued and wanting to learn more, where am i? Why am i here? How do i get out? Wtf is with that village!? Did i make the right decision... is this all a dream!? WTF IS GOING ON!? 

You couple this with the pace of the game and the way it transitions from day time explore/gather to night time, trap/base defense, with some slight puzzles, gathering of key items to progress and consumables to survive... and you have one hell of a game! I've seen a few jokes about Home Alone and setting traps, it's appropriate! Especially if you played the Sega Genesis version of Home Alone...  which you totally should if you were too young and missed it, because emulators!!!!... but i digress. This is a fantastic title and well worth the ticket price.

"Buy the ticket, take the ride" 
Hunter S. Thompson.

34630553.review:
+/ Unnerving atmosphere.
+/ Outstanding artistic direction.
+/ Flawless sound design.
+/ An unique take on survival horror, without any jumpscares.
+/ Simple but efficient gameplay.

-/ Hard and unforgiving, to the point of frustration.
-/ Can be repetitive after a while. 
-/ Not for everyone.

/I have been waiting for Darkwood's release for a few years now. I'm really happy to say it's been worth the wait. 

Scary, mysterious, intriguing and beautiful, Darkwood is a really original take on horror mixing elements of survival, tower defense, action and pure terror all of which without any kind of jumpscares.

From its unsettling art direction to its sound design and music, the game is beautiful and unique. It's mindblowing that an indie game with an isometric view succeed in being more immersive and chilling than most horror games through the sheer strength of its artistic merits. Exploring the woods, meeting with its inhabitants and unveiling its mysteries is both terrifying and exhalting. 

The only real issue I personally have with that game is its gameplay loop; Basically one has to defend a hideout during nights to protect themselves from the horrors roaming around. Nights are the most terrifying parts of the game, with some tense moments, and to survive, you need to make sure to put barricades and traps up. 

You basically spend your days scavenging for ressources, exploring and discovering new places to advance the plot and scavenge for more, carefully avoiding the creatures in the forest, and running back to your hideout to spend the night there (And probably cower in fear while SOMETHING roam inside your house.) . While it is fun, this loop can sometimes feel really repetitive, and the difficulty of the game can make some of your days feel like nightmares. 

If you don't mind this gameplay approach, I totally recommend Darkwood. Its mysterious, foreboding, and unique approach to horror makes it a must have .\

I bought this game a long time ago, and haven't played all of it, but I feel obligated to really write a review.
Darkwood is one of a kind. Top-down Horror RPG. That's something. It's incredibly unique. Everything in it is something unlike anything I've ever seen before, from the vision cone, to how light is handled, and more. It's fun, too, though extremely difficult.

The devs though, are probably one of the best parts of this game. They're not in it for the money. They caught people reselling Darkwood game keys at higher prices, and responded by uploading a torrent for people to play the game who don't have the money to buy it. They're good people.

34613031.review:
Incredible game with a very foreboding atmosphere, intriguing story and satisfying gameplay mechanics.

Explore and scavenge in the relative safety of the daylight, slowly unravelling the mysteries of the forest and it's strange inhabitants. At night, bunker down and barricade yourself in your hideout. Try and ignore the strange lights and the knocking at your door, it can't be real, can it?

Pray for the coming of the dawn but know the respite is only temporary. It won't be long before the night comes again. Remember to fuel your generator this time...

An absolutely unique experience which is best played without too much knowledge in advance. Go in dark and blind and let the forest become your home.

34613030.review:
총점 8.0/10

앞서 해보기 이외에 정식 출시 이후 평가가 안 보여서 평가 남깁니다.
18시간만에 엔딩을 봤습니다. 
결론부터 말하자면, 가격값은 그 이상은 합니다. 로그라이크, 공포물을 좋아하는 유저 분들에게 추천합니다.

장점
실체를 알 수 없는 숲의 공포에 대한 묘사
게임의 주 배경은 게임의 타이틀처럼 숲입니다. 그런데 이 숲의 공포를 굉장히 잘 살린 것이 일단 탑뷰 방식을 취하고 있고 주인공의 시야는 한정적입니다. 평지대를 벗어나 자원 확보를 위해 커다랗게 솟아난 거목들 사이에 들어가다보면, 주인공의 시야는 더욱 더 제한되고, 보이지 않는 곳에서는 알 수 없는 존재들, 들짐승의 소리나 혹은 더 불길한 것들이 내는 소리가 발길을 멈추게 하곤 합니다.
시간적 배분의 영리함
프롤로그가 지나면, 게이머에게는 매일매일 숲에서 생존하기 위해 하루하루가 주어집니다. 이 하루는 주간과 야간으로 크게 나뉘는데요 주간에는 주로 숲을 탐색하거나 퀘스트를 해결하고 자원/물자를 모으는 게 중점이라면 야간에는 한치 앞도 보이지 않는 어둠 속에서 괴물 혹은 돌연변이들을 대상으로 해가 뜰 때까지 버텨내야 합니다. 은거지(hideout)에서 문과 창문을 수리하고, 바리케이드를 치고 동이 트길 버티는 거죠. 이러한 시간 배분은 플레이어로 하여금 오금을 저리게 하는 공포를 느끼게 하기도 하는데요, 깊은 숲속에서 길을 헤맨 사이 밤이 찾아올 때 정말 심장이 쫄깃쫄깃했습니다. 즉 지속적으로 시간적을 어떻게 배분해서 오늘 하루는 얼마만큼의 탐사를 하고 어디까지 다녀올 것인가, 자원은 확보되었는가, 집까지의 거리는 얼마인가를 재게 하며 긴장을 늦출 수 없게 합니다.
딥 다크한 포스트 아포칼립스 세계
다크우드의 세계는 핵전쟁 혹은 핵폭발 이후의 세계입니다. 이러한 설정에 맞춰 등장하는 NPC들도 늑대인간이라던가 각종 돌연변이가 많이 등장하는 편인데 그 모습이 참 그로테스크한 편이 많아 섬뜩한 편입니다.
아이템 수집과 제작
이 거친 세계에서 주인공은 제대로 된 생존 물품 하나 없습니다. 각종 위험에서 버티기 위해서는 아이템을 수집해야 하고, 수집한 아이템에 따라서 작업대를 업그레이드 하고 추가 물품을 제작하여 생존 확률을 높여야 합니다. 그런데 이러한 아이템 수집 제작 시스템이 꽤 잘 짜여져 있어 재밌는 편입니다. 작업대에서 더 좋은 물품, 이를테면 총기류를 제작하려면 작업대를 업그레이드 해야 하고 이 특정 물품들은 주로 퀘스트에서 등장하기 때문에 숲을 모험하게 하는 기회가 됩니다. 총은 구하기도 어렵고 만들기도 어렵습니다. 게다가 만든다 해도 비싸고 구하기 어려운 총알을 계속 써야 하기 때문에 근접 무기를 지속적으로 구비하게 하는 등 밸런스도 잘 짜여진 편입니다.

단점
진행의 불친절함
다크우드는 크게 프롤로그, 챕터 1, 챕터 2로 나뉘어져 있는데요. 챕터 1에서 2로 넘어가면서 다른 지역으로 이동하게 되는데 이 때  소지품 외에 어떠한 아이템도 가져갈 수 없는데다가, 기존 지역의 퀘스트도 다 취소되는데요.. 그런데 이걸 제대로 설명을 안 해줍니다. 그래서 처음에 굉장히 당황했어요. 
이외에도 퀘스트의 진행을 직관적으로 보여주는 시스템이 없습니다. Journal이 존재해서 일기장처럼 펴서 볼 순 있는데요 글씨체도 엉망이고 직관성도 부족해서 무엇을 요구하는 것인지 집중해서 살펴보지 않으면 이해가 어렵습니다. 이렇게 유저가 직접 알아가는 것도 매력이라고 하신다면 뭐...
전투의 어려움
근접 전투가 굉장히 어려워요. 특히 삽이나 도끼는 공격 전에 준비 동작이 긴데 이때 공격 받으면 공격이 취소됩니다. 그런데 공격준비 중에는 걸으면서 움직임도 느려지고 전체적인 스테미나도 굉장히 부족해서 몹 하나 근접무기로 잡으려면 그 순간부터 피지컬갓겜이 됩니다. 총기류도 정면 일정 각도 이외에는 시야 확보가 안되서 절대무기로 쓸 수가 없습니다. 보통 2마리, 3마리가 동시에  나오면 거의 죽습니다.
이야기의 난해함
엔딩을 봤는데요.... 게임 중의 떡밥들이 좀 풀리나 했더니 더 이해가 안됩니다.
비한국어화
네 전부 영어입니다. 그래서 스토리 이해가 안되는 걸 수도 있어요.
짧은 플레이타임
노말 난이도로 18시간만에 엔딩을 봤는데... 진행이 그리 빠르다고 생각도 안했거든요. 어려워서 엄청 죽었고. 그런데 갑자기 엔딩인 거에요. 어 뭐지? 이게 끝이야? 했더니 진짜 끝입니다 네...
폰트
폰트가 말 그대로 정말... 스팀 상점 페이지에 등록된 영상 보시면 알겠지만 뭔가 어울리지도 않고 가독성도 후져요. 네 말 그대로 후집니다. 읽는데 진짜 눈 빠지는 기분이에요.

34599886.review:
I was initially hesitant about the topdown perspective, given it's not something I'm familiar with in relation to horror games. Despite that, I took the dive after a friend told me it was good. Boy were they right. This game is an excellent example of what horror games really can be when they aren't trying to follow the Amnesia formula.

The sprites are wonderfully animated, the music is immersive and subtle, and the artwork is all sorts of unnerving. This isn't a game for people that want big scary monsters but rather people that want to get consumed in an atmosphere of dread. The sound design is also incredible and there are dozens of tiny touches that leave me with my nerves shot.

Buy this game. It's worth your time regardless of if you're a horror junkie or a first timer into genres more focused on the mind than twitch reflexes. It will mess with you in the best ways.

34593719.review:
I got this game because it was offered up for free on a torrent on a site called Imgur. I had never heard of the game before i saw it there. I watched the trailers after I saw the post and I decided it was not something I couldn't justify getting for free to myself. I bought the game because it seemed like it was definatly something I would enjoy.

Pros- The game does not hold your hand. I shotgunned a charcter that was supposed to tell me something. I guess he was making a spaceship according to the stuff I read. He is dead now. 

-It is tense I wouldn't say scary. (don't get me wrong here the game has some very disturbing characters I have played too many jump scare games.) I love this because the game gets that a quick jump scare is not what I want. Instead seeing a new enemy who effects my vision when I look directly at it and adding a new mechanic I was not expecting worries me. I don't know if someone is an enemy right away. The person may just be defending their house and want you gone. 

-The game gives you lots of paths to choose from and you might not always see the path offered right away. (in example I spent a lot of bullets shooting an enemy cause I thought well this can't move to hit me at all but seems dangerous. I should burn it to a crisp.) Turns out I didn't have to use all those moltovs and there was an easy way to do that if i choose to.

- I don't know who I should be working with. Should I work with the wolf man or go with crazy chicken lady or maybe the musician who fancies the monster lady and wants to meet her privately.

Cons- The controls are tough to pick up. I could change them but it doesn't seem like anything else works quite as well with the options given. 

- lack of hand holding good. not knowing how to reload your freshly made gun with all your ammo clips until you look it up not so good. ( I think this one is on me though. I never look at the controls.)

- dieing doesn't seem to matter much. more of a slight inconvienence. I don't know if things change at the end due to number of deaths at the moment but it seems to change nothing other than you drop half your items that you can easily go find in a backpack where you died. 

overall 9/10 mostly cause of the control issues. To clarify I use a controller and every so often I die because it doesn't respond well due to the way it is designed. The keyboard mouse combo may work better but I would be surprized. Even with that issue this is easily one of the most entertaining games I have played and I am excited to explore some of the different paths that can be taken on new playthoughs.

34590794.review:
An atmospheric, jarring, and sonically stunning piece for a sphere of gaming (indie developers) that has seen a plethora of bad outcomes, Darkwood offers players a small chance at survival... if you're worthy. 

My first time playing this game I sat at my computer for a good 5 hours just trying to survive, I found some corpses with wooden planks and nails, made a nail-board, and pushed a wardrobe in front of the gaping hole in my safe-house in an effort to keep the baddies out. night came, and with it a sense of overwhelming isolation that left me hoping, pleading, praying for dawn to come. I was hooked. The nights got worse, however, as more and more terrifying creatures came knocking (or bursting into) the safehouse, giving only the slight, horrifyingly distinct screech of a wardrobe sliding across a wooden floor as a warning.

By day, you will scavenge and craft your way to slightly stronger levels of self-defense and safehouse-reinforcement, but by night, all bets are off as the things that literally go bump in the night will try to claw their way not only into your haven, but also into your sanity.

Tips:
1. Buy a watch and lantern if you can't find them. you'll thank me later, when you're out and dont know how long you have left until nightfall, or need to fight when the lights go out because you forgot to fuel up the generator.

2. USE YOUR GAINED REPUTATION. reputation is the currency of the woods, and each dawn you get an allotment to spend at the trader who visits your house. But the Wolf does not grant you more reputation, you must trade him for it... Choose your relinquished items wisely. A couple bottles of alcohol and a tank of gas might be worth it in the short term for a toolbox to upgrade your workbench, but you might also find that monsters have a great advantage in the dark, night vision, while you need torches and adequately fueled generators to see them and fight back. Which reminds me, TURN OFF THE GENERATOR IN THE DAYTIME... I've forgotten more than once.

3. If you don't have to fight, don't fight. Things in this game are FAR more mobile than you, and will exploit that advantage at every possible opportunity. plus your weapons have durability, which will deplete with each swing. 

4. Read. This is a psychological horror, and has quite a cast of characters that become important, which means that it's vital to read what they have to say in order to progress and get the story elements.

5. Learn to value the fine cloth. (I think that's what it's called) It's the item that allows you to expand your inventory space or hotbar, and it's amazing. You'll find tons of items, and it gets dangerous when you have to make a couple trips to get a bunch of nice things back to your homebase and into your workbench, which doubles as a storage cabinet.

6. Listen intently to your surroundings. This game makes impressive use of sound as an immersion factor: twigs snap as you explore the woods, enemies will sometimes alert you to their presence with their noisy (and sometimes disturbingly nonsensical) behavior, and it is much better to rely on your sense of hearing than your sense of sight when the sun goes down. But keep the lights on in the house, anyway. It'll save you a huge headache. 

This game is great, and serves as a reminder to all indie developers of what can be achieved when you put in the work. I had the game since alpha, and never saw the devs give up on making the game better. Well done, Acid Wizards, well done.

34581505.review:
Honestly. This game actually geninuely scares me. I haven't ran into any straight-forward horror in a long time. (Let me clarify with straight-forward). The thing about horror is not about jumpscares. It's about the enviroment, the grey darkness, the sounds you hear besides a fan, the wind, or any sound that gives you the courage to walk through an eerie forest that never sees the sun. A lot of horror games and movies usually don't understand it's maximum pontential because they think that children can play a great role (It's upsurd). Horror isn't just something you can expect. It's something that drives you towards it's greatness. Horror takes time to adjust to your level where you eventually go insane. 

The only reason I played an hour of this because the game matches up it's slow, and grind of time comsumption. It really makes up for its horror level because I find it to be quite irritating to find everything that I needed to survive through the forests darkest nightmares. Like this game understands what SHOULD be the instinct of horror and survival. Darkwood merges itself with both these genres so incredibly well, that my courage drops from 80%. The struggle to find materials to help me survive is very difficult which makes it closer to reality, or what would it seem to be in real life. Trust me, most of humans are terrified to live alone in the darkness and live like this character. We wouldn't just be terrified, we would lose our minds.

I underestimated this game big time. I thought it was going to be those other shitty horror games that always involve that same jumpscare that is just losing my horror fill. However this type of game instantly gave everything that I lost for horror in a long time. It gave me that spark of hope for horror again. Whoever the developers are, you are way ahead in the pedestal of horror and survival. Please continue to be who you are, a lot of developers who make their games with their own incredible ideas usually miss that one ingredient, [b] and thats being yourself [/b].

Fantastic job. Absolutely would love to see more of this in the future.

34565443.review:
Tenho acompanhado Darkwood desde 2014, joguei quase todas as versões beta, acompanhei com afinco o desenvolvimento do jogo e o trabalho da Acid Wizard, fico muito feliz que tudo tenha dado certo e o jogo tenha chegado tão longe.

Pense em Don't Starve, agora tire todas as coisas fofas do jogo, faça os inimigos 10x mais assustadores, os cenarios 100x mais macabros e os recursos 1000x mais escassos assim você vai ter uma boa ideia do que se trata esse jogo.

Apesar das mecanicas que lembram um jogo de sobrevivencia onde seu objetivo é montar uma base aos poucos e ser auto-suficiente Darkwood não se trata disso, é uma corrida pela sobrevivencia, cada noite, desde a primeira vai ser difcil, o jogo não vai te guiar pela mão, não é justo, você vai morrer muitas vezes sem nem saber o que aconteceu, você em momento nenhum vai se sentir "confortavel".

Os NPCS desse jogo são muito bem feitos, insanos pela praga e pela loucura da floresta, cada um com uma historia macabra , no fim cabe a você decidir em quem confiar ou não. 


Pontos Positivos em geral sobre o jogo:

- Rico em historia, com muitos caminhos diferentes que dependem das suas escolhas
- Desafiante
- Trilha sonora e efeitos sonoros impecaveis que ajudam bastante na imersão
- Loot/Localizações gerados aleatoriamente dando ao jogo um fator de replayability junto com os finais alternativos
- Muitos momentos de panico 
- Art style unico 
- Os desenvolvedores colocaram o jogo na internet gratuitamente para as pessoas sem condições de comprar, uma atitude louvavel vinda de um estudio independente, caso você tenha condições compre, são 25 reais por um jogo que facilmente te proporciona mais de 100 horas de gameplay 

Negativos

- Algumas mecanicas não são explicadas e você so aprende na marra morrendo
- Não tem muita variedade de armas, porem isso deixa o jogo mais tenso, eu pessoalmente não me importo
- Você precisa gerenciar seus recursos com muita atenção, por exemplo logo no começo você precisa de tabuas para barricar sua casa, porem transformar madeira em tabuas consome gasolina na serra mas o gerador que mantem as luzes funcionando e te protegendo da escuridão tambem precisa de gasolina, para alguns jogadores pode ser bem frustrante. 


Agora mais importante algumas dicas BEM UTEIS 

- SAIA DE PERTO DAS JANELAS DURANTE A NOITE É SERIO
- TÁ DE NOITE? FICA QUIETO MUITO QUIETO , VIRA UMA ESTATUA , A NÃO SER QUE TENHA ALGUEM ENTRANDO NA SUA CASA AI VOCÊ CORRE
- DESLIGA O GERADOR DE DIA É SERIO 
- NÃO PISE EM COGUMELOS OU CORPOS 
- CORVOS = CORPOS POR PERTO = LOOT
- ARMADILHAS DE URSO SÃO SEU MELHOR ALIADO E PIOR INIMIGO

34562726.review:
- Darkwood Official Release Review -

As a gamer with over 1500+ Steam games, and over 1000+ Physical Games, I have decided to review 2017's best Survival Horror game.

Let's start off with what Darkwood is, and isn't. 
Darkwood is NOT a 20+ hour, hand-holding tutorial with gameplay elements. Darkwood is = an unforgiving, challenging, unbelievably scary, top-down survival horror game with a slight RPG hint of flavor. In Darkwood, you gather resources, fight enemies guarding valuable gasoline and rope while trying to avoid devious traps and the monsters that haunt the forests.

You are a stranger with a key to the exit to the dark forest you are seemingly forever trapped in. You are found injured by another stranger who takes the invaluable key labeled with the numbers "21" and are locked into your kidnappers hideout. You must escape his home and retrieve your key and get the hell out of the forest. 

You soon wake up alone in the large forest with nothing but your wits and balls of steel to aide your escape. Your mission, should you decide to accept, is to get your bloody key back and survive to the best of your abilities while doing so.

It may seem like a simple task of staying alive and collecting anything not nailed down, however, you'll quickly learn that many have tried to leave the forests of Darkwood, and all have failed. You will be told by numerous "people" you encounter that leaving is impossible, and the best use of your time is to fortify your current hide out and pray that you make it to morning. 

Fear not, as you will have tools to help make surviving less of a figment of your imagination and more of a reality. Bear traps, chain traps, molotovs, gas bombs, nail-filled wood planks, rare pistols and shotguns, and even furniture will help you fight off the foes that will attempt to slaughter you in the night and claim your home as their territory. Expect to face 4-legged beasts, feral hounds, ghosts, supernatural events, angry Mooses, and more! 

During your travels through the forest, you will encounter the "Underground" (a cave with a large metal door at the end, only able to be opened with your stolen key), large fields of crops filled with dangerous wonder, burnt down and damaged homes, broken tractors, Wolfman and his camp site (a much needed ally), wedding ceremonies, hidden passages, forests of unimaginable horrors, and even a parallel universe begging to drink your blood through a straw. All of this and more stand in your way between the key to freedom and death. 

Darkwood is a game like any other I have ever played, especially horror/scary games. The atmostphere and ambiance is unmatched, the story telling is subtle yet impactful, the combat is risky and rewarding, and the creatures and locations that fill the game fit so perfectly with the type of game Acid Wizards have created. Each playthrough can be different and exciting, as no two playthroughs will be the same. Every time you create a new character, you will be given a randomly generated forest with different locations, loot, and encounters to keep the game fresh and interesting to discover again. Each and every night in the game is different and has the possibility to reward you handsomely, or rip apart your character with little to no remorse. One night you could be cowering in a corner while ghosts swarm your fortress, pounding away at your sanity. Other times you will be bombarded by hordes of frightening enemies while all the furniture in your home begins to move itself and go all weird on your ass. Or, you'll count your blessings are not a soul is to be seen, not a single footstep is heard, and the eerie silence taunts you into thinking you are safe. 

But you won't be able to stay in one place forever. While a trader will appear every morning to greet you with wares of utmost importance, you have limited "reputation" (basically the game's currency) and resources to barter with. If that wasn't enough, each night will test your defenses and use up resources faster than you can replenish them; and once you are all out of gasoline to fuel the generator keeping the lights on inside your hideout, trouble will come breaking down your door for a taste of your skin. It is this reason that you must scavenge and forage every day while the sun shines through the leaves of the forest, for you are doomed without traps to harm enemies and gas to keep the house safe. It's certain death to be outside at night. You'll either be eaten by a "worm" that lives under the surface, or surrounded by evil creatures with staffs beating you to death at every angle. 

For those who like a torturing experience, Darkwood has you covered. With 3 difficulty settings, every player of any skill set and experience will have a way to play. On Normal, you have unlimited lives and are more or less consquence free. On the Hard setting, you have a few limited number of lives. On Nightmare, you have one life to live, and to die. 

And how could I not mention one of the most important features of Darkwood? Line of sight. That's right, you can only see in the direction you are looking in. Fans of Project Zomboid will recognize this neat idea and adapt quickly. Others, however, will be thrown off by the constant need to be scanning your entire surroundings, turning around in circles over and over to find the source of those bloody howls in the distance; or the voices whispering songs of death in your ears. You're ability to see resources and enemies relies on a good eye and scanning the area heavily. With only a small sliver of screen being illuminated and in focus at any given time, you will find yourself looking behind yourself often, and peaking through small gaps in your barricaded windows for impending danger. It is this feature, combined with everything above that makes Darkwood truly terrifying.

But what about bugs, glitches, or bad design decisions, Fumferknuckle? Worry not, my fellow gamers and friends; Darkwood is a AAA experience created by a team of 3 highly talented individuals dead set on making Darkwood the best game it can possibly be. And they sure as hell deliver! In over 12 hours of gameplay, I have encountered zero errors, glitches, or game-breaking bugs (besides once when a grass texture was overlapping another texture causing a weird hazy effect), and have thoroughly enjoyed every moment I've spent playing Darkwood. This game is so awesome and polished that my save file from Alpha 7.2 from a pirated copy of the game still registers in my full purchased copy today. How wild is that! And speaking of pirating, Acid Wizard is the standard forward in my personal opinion; as they released the FULL GAME on The Pirate Bay for free, no questions asked. There was not sneaky coding done to alter the game or the way it plays, it is a legitamate, full version of Darkwood free for downloading. BUT! DON'T PIRATE THE GAME! Please do not. Acid Wizard has been developing this game for years, with easily 3 years of early access under their belt and they deserve every single penny they can get. This game is phenomenal, a true master piece, one of the best horror experiences out there, and it costs a quarter of a "full" AAA game of today. For a measily $15 (FIFTEEN DOLLARS PEOPLE, a Mc Donalds lunch price), you get the entire game in its beautifully programmed state, packed to the brim with replayability and unique content. This game could cost double or triple the current asking price, and I would still recommend it. It is THAT good.

If you want a horror experience you won't forget, and can play more than once, BUY DARKWOOD! It is one of the best games I've ever played, especially in this genre, and will continue to impress me for years to come. The sound design, the artwork, the gameplay, the developers, the story, the support from the devs, the entire game is worth every dollar and it is a purchase I can guarantee you WON'T regret.

My playthrough:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GkRTg4sfBfI

34558942.review:
I have been eyeing this game for awhile but didn't want to play another early access title. I was actually a bit shocked to see it released and jumped right in with what little free time I have these days (#dadlife) to see if it would scratch that survival, exploration itch I am always looking for.

It did, with a healthy dose of horror, immersion, and a nice set of gameplay mechanics to boot. 

The narrative is very much in the dark souls fashion where you can discover as much or as little as you like as you play through the game. Item scarcity is balanced well enough that the game rewards convservation but won't punish you for using your goodies. Exploration is thematically satisfying and mechanically rewarding, with those who are willing to look in every cranny often gaining access to equipment, upgrades, and items earlier than they may normally be available. Extra bonuses await the puzzle solving sorts if you want to figure out the combinations to the dozens of optional stashes scattered throughout the game.

The combat and survival balance felt solid in my one normal game run. Even when I was sporting a shotgun and a stack of shells, I never felt fully safe in the woods and the variety of night time encounters kept me on my toes no matter how well set up I made my hideout. It has a kind of difficulty that stays manageable so long as you are taking your time, but all it takes is a few panicked/rushed/complacent moments and things can go wrong quick. Bear traps will be your best friend and your worst enemy.

Also, fun fact: The most terrifying thing a monster can do is knock politely and persistently on your front door. I'm not home, please go away.

34555015.review:
You shouldn't play this game at night. But if you do, it would be wise to lock your doors and barricade the windows. And stay in the light. For they will come. But you should play this game. 

Darkwood is one of those few games that are genuinely scary. But it does not go for cheap scares and reflexes. Instead the darkwood is dark and brooding and strange. And scary and dangerous. And you yourself are pretty strange. But all this is part of the storytelling. Which is exceptional. 

If you play this game on hard - you can die a few times - you will find yourself unwilling to explore certain area's. Carelessness will kill. Grinding for rescources or experience is just madness and after the day comes the night. And in the night they will come. While on the other hand there is a need to explore because the map will change during different playthroughs. Play on normal and the character will respawn an unlimited number of times and every idiot can finish the game on normal difficulty. But playing on normal difficulty will allow a less dedicated player to enjoy the storytelling. And did I say this already ? The storytelling is exceptional.

Really. The storytelling is exceptional.
I will probably be playing this game for some time to come.

34549058.review:
[u]Spoiler-free review of Darkwood[/u]

[b]Info[/b]
[list]
    [*]Game is more disturbing and mysterious than scary. If you like jumpscares and/or have trouble losing yourself in a game world this may not be the game for you.
[/list]

[b]Good[/b]
[list]
    [*]Game is very atmospheric. If you can immerse yourself deeply in games then this is worth playing.
    [*]Game doesn't tell you much about anything, and the game world is full of mysterious things you must face through trial and error. Hand-holding is minimal.
    [*]Graphics are decent(art style is excellent), but I would have preferred some sharper graphics, but hey, indie studio.
    [*]Sound quality is excellent and really allows for great immersion in the game world.
[/list]

[b]Bad[/b]
[list]
    [*]Dragging/pushing objects is painfully slow, as if everything weighs 300kgs(or some ridiculous amount).
    [*]There is no actual minimap, so finding items again that you had to leave behind due to a full inventory might be a problem.
    [*]The low inventory space means lots of (slow)moving back and forth to store your loot. This can take up a lot of the ingame time, and may feel tedious.
    [*]Controlling the character has been slightly confusing at times, at least for me. Pressing W for example will move your character up no matter which way he's facing. Perhaps I'm used to things working differently in other games. This has resulted in some difficult situations.
[/list]

So there are probably more things to mention about the game, but I'll leave it at this for now. Might add more later. I would say these are some of the very few developers that actually deserve your support. Will definitely keep playing. This game has me in its hold.

34542391.review:
Dark wood is one of the more refreshingly different and clever games I have played in ages.
It leaves your feeling disturbed with imagery only that of like old-school games like Sanitarium, desperate for resources like Don't Starve, and gives you the gratification of growth like a solid RPG. 

Generally your run of the mill horror games are pretty unthrilling: only managing to get your heart pumping through a cheap jump scare. Outliers like Amnesia are great at creating a more atmospheric-type fear but do so by capitalize on first-person mechanics to play to the player's limited visibility. Darkwood manages to somehow capture this same element of helplessness from a top-down perspective, which in my opinion, is an incredibly impressive feat given the vast amount more control you have. 

Through the use of multiple map layouts and randomized events (particularly during the night phases of the game) the game keeps you from being able to enter a rote mindset. Moreover, the dramatic increase in difficulty from section to section force you to improve as a player or to utilize your oh-so-precious rescourses.  Seriously, I yet to reliably kill a chomper in melee with out getting hit, bery nearly getting hit, or letting out unmannly noises. 

My only gripe with the game is that there is little to no material to reference when learning about the games mechanics, enemies, or the purpose of some of the items you find. I find myself constantly referencing the wiki to figure out what the random doohicky I picked up is supposed to do or what the is purpose of a random location I stumbled upon. 

I don't write reviews because I always feel like someone can say what I mean to say but better and with fewer words. But with this game feels like it is going to be under a lot of people's radars despite feeling like a cult classic waiting to happen. With just a smidge more awareness it will be a source of good memories (or fearful ones) on everyone's steam list. I did my part.

If you can't punch, then there should be plenty of branches on the ground to use as weapons. It is a forest after all.

Edit:

A game can be challenging or frustrating for a couple of reasons. A good game is challenging in terms of needing to acquire skill or learning how to play. This gives a fulfilling experience and you feel rewarded when you can overcome the challenge. Then there's this lazy crap game that is frustrating because they don't give you anything to work with and code in stupid deaths that are unavoidable. 34521023.review:
通关了，2D恐怖游戏中我觉得最好玩的之一，具体游戏素质就不在阐述了，说一点基础需要知晓的。
1、游戏的主要目的是逃出森林，每天白天可以在庇护所之外的地方探索，完成任务，20点到第二天早上8点是天黑，最好待在庇护所里不然会死的很难看。
2、死亡并不会阻碍任务流程，但身上物品会随机掉落在死亡地点，所以死最好都离庇护所近一点，方便捡尸。
3、电子表很重要，能知道时间，前期最好早点找商人买到。
4、晚上没有死亡活到第二天会有声望奖励，声望就是钱，商人每天早上8点会在你工作台附近等你交易，注意，狼人的声望只能靠卖东西增加（但狼人那里的东西并没有什么必须买的）。
5、武器方面，前期木板加钉子可以用到Silent wood不用换，材料够了就赶紧做出手枪（不是那种一次性的），你会发现游戏简单了很多。
6、Undergruod一开始不要去看21号门，等有了铲子以后下去左手边可以挖掘出好东西，不然你看了门塌方了就挖不到了。
7、游戏总共有4个区域，每次游戏都会随机生成地图，但大方向不变，前3个区域是第一章。出了Undergruod的21号门以后是第二章地图，只有一个区域。每个区域怪物强度都有增强，相应的，晚上存活后的奖励声望也会增加。
8、工作台的升级工具随着你任务进程都能拿到，够用就行不用太纠结找材料，如果特别想提前升级就做做支线任务。
9、到了Silent wood的新庇护所以后工作台里有个自行车铃，摇一下会有个NPC出现，给他一瓶酒，他就可以帮你把老庇护所的东西拿过来，不用你亲自去搬运。
下面说下主线的流程吧：
[spoiler] 第一个区域就是让你搜集材料的，到了Silentwood后地图里会有几个比较重要的NPC，还有通往村庄的路。
先找到地图上有个小丑头像的地方，里面有个NPC卖电圈，这个是杀死猪圈里的猪妈妈的必须道具。杀掉猪妈妈后去村庄，杀掉地下室埋伏你的村长，找到鸡婆婆和小提琴男孩了解医生的下落。
第三个区域，去小提琴屋子里帮小男孩拿小提琴，屋子里是他半死不活的双亲，如果条件满足小男孩会给你一张乐谱，放在他妈妈身上，去拖衣柜拿小提琴他妈妈就不会追杀你了。
拿到小提琴后小男孩会告诉你医生的位置，找到医生后告诉医生出口的位置，跟着医生出21号门就到了第二章。
第二章主要任务是烧掉那个人面树，必要的任务物品是氧气罐，这个东西可以找有一家人都带着氧气面罩，妈妈会叫你找她丢失的孩子，找到以后就会给你。
找到蘑菇奶奶，小男孩就在她屋子里。
潜泳去大树根部，点火烧树以后要第二天才能烧完，需要去庇护所等一天。
第二天直接通过大树就可以回家了，完结撒花。[/spoiler]

游戏里每个NPC都有自己的故事和性格，很多时候的选择都有很多种，而且游戏的隐藏要素太多太多，我基本都没怎么发掘，比如婚戒，婚礼现场的铁门，蘑菇奶奶家的小男孩是否有其他方式可以救他等等，这些都要等你们和我探讨了。
有过不去的地方随时私信我~~

34515636.review:
tl;dr you like spooky horror that isn't boo your face, but more slow paced, with spooky environment, dog to maul your face and weird shit and people to discover an even more weird storyline. Go ahead and buy, a must have.




•Darkwood is a slow paced, top down, action and atmospheric horror. It's aim is to scare and disturb you without using the usual cheap trick of let's trow a spooky image along with spooky or high volume sound to make people jump of their chair. But instead, prefer to use just a bit of weird music, enough to keep you stressed and then.. a door open on it's own.. and so you shit your pants because why this door would open? i barricade the one after it, spooky ghost stop it, let me pass the night i just want to pass the night, as you repeat the word, curling and crying on the floor as someone bash at your window to get in and steal your face.
•The gameplay is cut in the 2 part with a day and night cycle. During the day you explore the "Darkwood" in search of answer after a man decided to punch you in the gabbler for not telling why you have a key, so you go after said man because, man, that's your key like, why he did this, this is mean.. So you explore, find creepy location, burned down house, a corn field to remake your favorite scene from Sign or any movie involving corn field. 
And at night, you hide in your hideout because you dont want to party with the potential monster face eating savage flying worm and big evil doggo. Night event can differ a lot from just nothing happening, to "monster" harrassing your defence to other spooky event.
•But let's not forget, this aint no amnesia or horror game with a protagonist unable to defend for himself, we aint some weak bitch and we can apply the hammer of leave me the fuck alone with a small selection of weapon to defend ourself, ranging from a basic piece of wood with nail to the much more heavy duty STICK to a more traditional handgun, shotgun, rifle etc.. Because darkwood is also about crafting but.. crafting isn't here to build a world full of wonder like a new game of minecraft 10s before doing a peen with cobblestone but more as a way to gain tool to survive. With basic lockpick to torch and bandage, there's quite a small list of item with the right quantity of elbow grease that can help you figure out more of the intriguing story and creepy world that is Darkwood.
•Graphism wise, the game is gorgeous in its genre. Dont expect super fancy 3d effect explosion and top quality color, it's a horror game not happy land and shooty bang bang. The grim, colored and dull environment push forward the dying and creepy feeling of the environment, the character design enhance the weird decrepit and disease feeling of the darkwood.

All in all, it's quite a fun game, give it a try i highly recommend it and the dev even pushed so far for promotion that they uploaded, by themself, a copy of the game for dem pirate yarr to give it a try and enjoy it before buying.
I highly suggest supporting the dev, they've been working for so long on Darkwood that they deserve the praise.
Bought the game day one it landed on steam and at time regretted it but in the end i kept with and i must say im quite happy that AcidWizzard manage to do it and hold on their creation till the end. 

Enjoy the game, bash some savage with some stick and set fire to their evil monster doggo. And stay safe in your hideout

34499480.review:
If this game were made in the 90's, it would be the standard for all survival horror to come, like the original Fallout 1-2 and Wasteland games did for the post-apocalypic genre.  Maybe if it were the first survival horror game, the genre would be more well manicured and intelligent.  Even with all the games that have come before it, Darkwood has an exquisite sense of menace with music, tone, atmosphere and especially the relatively primitive 8-bit combat mechanics.  (You get your timing wrong and you die fast.)  Especially with your first play-through (you can easily do several), the game will have you walking backwards, nail board ready to swing at unseen noises in the forest.  Nights are deeply terrifying with a variety of threats, both imagined and real, and you can opt to patrol your base with a risk/reward of extra goodies at the expense of possibly dying with no recourse.
I think my favorite aspect of the game is that despite it's 90's feel, it has a deeply sophisticated morality, both in mechanics and at a player level. On my first playthrough, I actually started to feel remorseful for what I did without even knowing I did anything bad in the first place, but I had to continue shaming myself just to stay alive.  You're allowed to make all your own choices in the game.  You have the option to kill everything in sight without any karma or alignment scale telling you if what you're doing is right or wrong on a HUD level.  There is no menu to look at that's frowning on you for helping or hindering anything.  The HUD is incredibly basic, which adds deeply to the menacing nature of the game.  Have I become a monster?  Am I still a good person?  It's impossible to tell until you've played the game for some time.
I cant recommend this sophisticated, yet plain on the outside game enough.  I can't wait to see what Acid Wizard does next.

34498974.review:
[h1]It's like Bob Ross had deep depression and started painting[/h1]

TLDR; Wow, just wow, I am amazed with how this game turned out to be. I've been waiting for quite a while to see the final version of this game, and I was not disappointed at all. Props for the devs for delivering an outstanding experience.

There's many different aspects to cover up, so I'll divide the review in each.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The Gameplay is pretty simple, you have a main objective to accomplish in each Chapter. The manner on how you'll do your objective will depend on the decisions you make throughout the game. You can explore different areas for items and discovers new places during the day, and you survive against attacks and supernatural events in your safehouse during the night. Everything is executed nicely. Though the constant backtracking can be quite tiresome.

[b]Graphics[/b]
Darkwood's artistic design is the most astonishing thing I've seen in a survival horror game. The artstyle alone had me convinced to purchase the game on Early Access and fund the further development of the game 2 years ago. Honestly, if it wasn't for the incredible artistic work this game received, most people wouldn't care to spend their money on it, for it is the fundamental aspect that embodies the survival horror genre within the game. Had this game been made as a walking simulator (which is fine if done right), with emphasis on storyline, I'd still be amazing, because the level of visual detail on characters, objects, and enviroment would still make a fascinating experience.

[b]Soundtrack[/b]
Well performed audio production. From the main menu theme song to the footstep sounds indoors, it all gives a feeling of suspense and disconcertment throughout the game. Excellent.

[b]Storyline[/b]
I still got to beat the game, but from what I've seen, I am impressed. The game is divided in Chapters. Each Chapter takes places in a different scenario. Each scenario is filled with characters and items you find that tell the story of the game, and it takes about 10+ hours to finish a Chapter depending on how you play. By the time I was about done with all the areas in Chapter 1, I thought the game was about the end, until I got suprised with 'Chapter 2' screen. The story goes pretty far.

For a Indie Survival Horror game, Darkwood is a work of art. It brought a unique, revitalizing style to the survival horror genre, and should be taken as reference on how to make a indie game right

What i look for in a "Survival Horror Game"
1.) Survival

34482715.review:
I'm very picky about horror games, there are so few of them that do it right. I hate cheap jump-scares, I hate having no means of self-defense and I hate even more, when the game lets you have a weapon, but it's as useful as a fly-swatter against a frenzied elephant. I hate when developers think, that mindlessly shoveling blood and gore into a game makes it horror, or they assume that dying and reloading hundreds of times is what makes it fun. I hate when developers think, that zombies are scary or when they make the main character a fragile asthmatic pansy that is being chased by dumb unstoppable monsters, oh, and I hate so much, when the playable character gets so scared that his vision gets blurry and all the sounds get muffled by his heavy breathing and heartbeat. Just because The Acid Wizards didn't choose to include any of these things in their debut masterpiece is a reason enough to recommend Darkwood!

 But there's so much more to it! It might not look like it at first, but Darkwood's world is the most twisted, sick, disturbing, inhuman, hopeless and evil place I've seen in my 24 years of gaming. And it's the most immersive one too because of how subtle it is. It doesn't start with in-your-face "you're alive because you're the main character, otherwise you'd be like super-dead or turned into a monster, y'know, like everyone else, because this place is sooooo super-fuсked, man!!!", it grows on you and when you think it's not as bad as it could've been, you just need to be brave, capable and curious to find out the deeply disturbing things the game's world and characters were carefully hiding. If you think you've seen everything in the horror genre, play Darkwood. If you're new to the genre and want the best it can offer, play Darkwood!

 It's not perfect though, the gameplay is a bit too grindy and slow-paced for my taste, if there would be less looting, hoarding, micro-managing and generally doing things that turn into time-pressured chores, and more exploring, learning the lore and story, experiencing hand-crafted events and finding heart-wrenching dark secrets of the game's world and its characters, it would be the perfect horror game, at least for me.

 Surprisingly, the top-down perspective manages to work better in this game, that the traditional, supposedly more immersive, first-person, third-person or fixed-camera views. Devs used the top-down view so cleverly and creatively, that some things they did are completely new to the genre and would never work with any other view mode, like how things change, depending on whether you're looking at them or not.

 I'd say Darkwood is worth buying for full price, not only because the game is one of the best survival horrors ever, but also because [url=http://imgur.com/a/xVhDz]the devs are among the nicest people in the industry[/url]  and they deserve to have all the means to keep making amazing games.

34479771.review:
One of the most interesting survival horror games I've ever seen. Let's focus on that.

Darkwood does not rely on the typical cliches you find in survival horror games. It doesn't even have jumpscares in its arsenal. It builds tension with its visual and audio design, and difficult gameplay. It's gone in an extremely modern pixel art direction with some relatively high res visuals which are looking remarkable even at 4k. The designs of the more "creepy" things are creative and immaculately animated, which definitely channels the aesthetic of Silent Hill at times.

The field-of-view mechanic cannot be praised enough. It's a top-down perspective and the player character can only see objects in about a 90 degree angle in the direction he is facing. The characters attention can be focused on areas to get a better view (fading out the upper layer of trees and such) which makes for a fairly realistic, immersive feel.

The combat system is simple, but feels just varied enough for this type of game. I really appreciate the use of practicality of weapon choices, as it doesn't force you to crunch damage numbers to maximize them. Got a nail board? More nails will make it do more damage, reinforcing it with metal will make it more durable.

There is an element of resource management as you will never have enough materials to barricade every single window/doorframe you come across while still having enough for your equipment. A few traders exist to exchange items for reputation, a currency for buying other items. There is also a bit of procedural generation for the map across playthroughs - map layouts and locations will change, but the layouts of locations and items inside them do not.

There seem to be several optional and mandatory events that involve choices for the player, that ultimately affect the storyline. In my experience, they are not weightless choices and have been slightly challenging to make at times.

Overall, it's been difficult for me to notice any areas where Darkwood doesn't seem completely polished. Granted, I haven't seen all the content available, but I highly recommend it anyway.

34470469.review:
[h1]Masterpiece[/h1]

I've backed this game years ago on Indigogo (never played before 1.0), and damn was it worth it. This game in the style of Teleglitch and Neverending Light (free flash game, check it out) knows what true horror is. No cheap jumpscares, but well built tension with amazing sound design, wonderfully drawn and grotesque characters, fantastic lighting, as well as an intriguing storyline. You just know that this game took a huge amount of work, especially for such a small team.

Generally speaking, I am not a fan of survival games anymore, because most of them waste your time with hunger/thirst-meters or just overall long waiting times (e.g. for crafting). This game focuses on health and stamina only, which keeps the gameflow steady and focused. Unlike other games in the survival genre, each night is a new experience with different and creative events. Crafting is quick with multiple options, i.e. weapons, traps and utilities. The game also features skills (positive and negative), that give you new abilities mostly for combat - albeit the selection is a little limited. There's definitely a huge opportunity for future updates that improve the skilltree.

The combat is in my opinion probably the worst part of this game. While it is still sufficient and not bad, it definitely feels at times somewhat clunky, especially when fighting multiple enemies at once with melee weapons. I wish enemies didn't interrupt your own attacks as easily, the dash was multi-directional instead of just a jump backwards, and the skill menu actually paused or at least didn't cover the whole screen when opened. For melee weapons a range indicator would be quite useful, at least when holding the mouse button. 

Despite my criticism, this game is well worth it and I definitely recommend it. Can't wait for future updates and games from this studio!

34452102.review:
I've only played a few hours, but I'm engrossed. Even though it is a top down 2d game, it is incredibly engaging and honestly unsettling. It's part mystery and investigation, part survival and resource management. The mood that it creates with its disturbing art style and well composed music is foreboding and ominous, and it does a fantastic job of heightening the tension throughout your gameplay.

The game does not coddle you at all, and it really harkens back to a different era of gaming. Combat is difficult and unforgiving, even on the default settings. The game takes you through a day/night cycle, exploring in the light and taking shelter in your hideout in the dark. You must pay close attention to noises and movement, anything could quite easily kill you if you aren't alert, and you can't see anything that isn't in front of your character. The entire combat and exploration style goes a long way to preserving that feeling of apprehension and fear, and I've already become accustomed to freezing and looking around whenever I hear an unexpected noise. It has truly been a delightful and challenging experience.

Even with just a handful of hours played, I can't recommend this game enough, it is well worth its modest price tag. Seriously, you should definitely buy it.

34444010.review:
So... what can I say?

Before starting I should probably mention that I'm not the horror game kind of type. At all. I'm a little crybaby when it comes to that. Not playing the game itself, but coming even close to trying it out.
This doesn't apply at all to open world survival games. I love those, and that's exactly why I thought I give this little game a try. Because it was standing out with its unique type of genre: Openworld, topdown, pixelated and obviously horror.

What makes the game so special?

To me this game is something unique, as already mentioned above these kind of genres normally don't mix well, but the developers of this game somehow managed to create a wonderful game, with a indescribable scary atmosphere. Not by using cheap jumpscares or realistic graphics (I'm looking at you outlast), but rather by using limited vision, horrific sounds and scary-ass landscapes, with scary-ass lightning effects. 
Coming to my next point: Exploration. This game is all about it, and sometimes you ask yourself wether you want to jump down that dark well, or if you want to go home and call it a day and maybe get enough courage to jump down the next day, which might reward you very well, but on the other hand can get you killed. Your choice.
Now when it comes to nighttime, you better get yourself back home and barricade yourself in your hideout, but don't think you just go to sleep and let the nighttime pass, no. I remember my first few nights hiding in a corner and scaring myself to death whenever I heard steps outside, or even someone knocking on my door. Something happens EVERY night. And you should better prepared, because sooner or later something will get in and find you.
Let's talk about the story for a second. I won't spoil you too much, but from what I've seen so far you can choose your own story and your choices matter and change the world around you. Something which I personally really like, because it's not linear (perfect for second or third walkthrough) and you have your own choices and ways to go.
Limited ressources. This aspect might repel some people, but it is meant to force you to advance to new areas, and you get enough loot by exploring. The game is kind of random generated, meaning you' will find random crates and bodies placed on the map but pre-placed buildings and story-important stuff. 
There is also a skill- and craftingsystem to help you further decide your own things, like what am I to craft and what skills should I take over the others.
Only thing which is kind of a drawback is that you can't go outside at night. You will die. No stealth, no harder enemies, no badass fighting, you will just die. Period.

TLDR.: Atmospheric topdown horrorgame with a open storyline where your choice matters, skillsystem, and a crafting system. Only minor drawback is that you can't go out at nighttime, but I wouldn't try that anyways, at least not yet (At the time of this review I have only got 13 hours playtime)

34440370.review:
[h1]Tus peores pesadillas te observan entre los árboles[/h1]

Darkwood es un survival horror independiente creado por Acid Wizard Studio. Comenzó su early access en Steam allá por julio de 2014, el pasado 17 de agosto por fin finalizó el desarrollo y tras haberlo probado no he podido quedar más alucinado con su propuesta. Todo fan de los survival horror debe tener muy en cuenta este juego.

La trama Darkwood es tan simple como retorcida, una misteriosa plaga asola la tierra, la vegetación crece sin control enterrando bajo sus raíces ciudades enteras, con ella han comenzado a aparecer criaturas grotescas y la mayoría de los seres humanos sucumben a la locura, aunque al caer la noche, entre los árboles hay algo más...

El desarrollo del juego es a priori simple, por el día recogemos recursos y por la noche aguantamos en el refugio hasta el amanecer. Pero todo es muchísimo más profundo que eso, ya que vamos siguiendo una trama principal que se va desgranando poco a poco, no es un survival como tantos otros hay. Así pues por el día aprovecharemos para ir rapiñando todo tipo de recursos, mientras tratamos de avanzar en la trama principal o en diversas subtramas secundarias que nos propondrán algunos extraños personajes con los que nos encontraremos y con los que podremos comerciar además, mientras que al caer la noche deberemos volver a alguno delos refugios que vayamos encontrando para guarecernos.

Pero aquí no se trata de luchar y defender el fuerte, al contrario, durante la noche conviene estar lo más en silencio posible, cosa que no será fácil... Estás en silencio y oyes llamar a la puerta ¿vas y abres? o ves una linterna entre los árboles ¿sales a investigar? y eso en las noches tranquilas... Porque cuando oyes pasos dentro de la casa u oyes como tratan de echar abajo la barricada que has puesto en la ventana es muy difícil mantener la calma, no diré más por que hay muchísimas situaciones diferentes que sucederán cada noche, y con el paso de los días va a más y más.... Aunque por el día tampoco os sintáis tranquilos, que los peligros siempre están ahí.

La atmósfera del juego es brutal, super opresiva y me atrevería a ponerla al nivel de los mejores tiempos de Silent Hill. Todo contribuye a meternos el miedo en el cuerpo, desde los sonidos que escuchamos mientras jugamos, pasando por los grotescos gemidos de los monstruos (o lo que no son monstruos) hasta la magnífica banda sonora que tiene. Me quito el sombrero ante el buen hacer de este pequeño estudio, la verdad.

Algunas otras características interesantes que tiene son, por ejemplo que el bosque se genera de forma aleatoria en cada partida, no es que sea procedural, pero cada vez que empecemos un nuevo juego nada estará en el mismo sitio. Los lugares de interés que visitamos son los mismos, pero puestos en zonas distintas. También podemos usar una especie de champiñones para crear una sustancia que nos da skills para darnos alguna ventaja, pero a costa de otra desventaja. Toma de decisiones que afectarán al mundo y a los personajes, osea que es bastante rejugable (la primera partida puede durar unas 25-30 horas)

La única pega es que está en inglés, aunque es probable que termine apareciendo una traducción de la comunidad (o la oficial en el futuro). Pero lo bueno es que tiene un precio muy reducido de 14€. Os lo recomiendo a todos los fans de los survival horror.

34433928.review:
The atmosphere is fantastic, the scares are real and come from actual gameplay, characters and the environment rather than cheap jump scares so many other games go for. The story, while the overall arch of what brought you to the woods in the first place is blurry, the world and what lies in it more than makes up for with with each little point of interest in the map telling unspoken horrors of what took place and the True ending brought all the strengths of the game into one fiery finale; terrifying truths, painful choices and a brutal way to end it all. 

This was the horror game I’ve been looking for, one that test your ability to solve and work around the harsh world around you, giving you freedom of choice in building your own solutions to problems, a game that gives actual scares brought naturally through its world and story telling, and gives a spine chilling, flesh burning conclusion when you see the true ending.

Shoddy melee combat and sometimes unclear objectives keep this from being flawless, but the 
story, atmosphere and overall gameplay make up for it, and then some.  

Burn them all.

34426987.review:
Let me start out by saying I absolutely adore this game. I haven't been able to put it down all day, and that ended up being 11 hours of playtime since I woke up...

It does so many things well. It invokes a sense of dread and panic I have not felt from a game in a very long time, boasting some very strong Silent Hill vibes, both visually and narratively. The story is very minimalistic, begging you to find out what's going on in this messed up place. In a way, it reminds me a bit of both Dark Souls, in how you navigate the environment, lighting ovens (bonfires) along the way; and also of Five Nights at Freddy’s, where every single night is a nerve-wracking experience where you count down the minutes left until dawn.

The top-down perspective also breaths some needed fresh air into the survival-horror genre, and the idea that only the things in your characters field of view are visible is a really nice touch. It leaves you feeling vulnerable, like someone is following you, hiding behind the nearest tree, and incredibly claustrophobic, especially in tight quarters.

My only real complaint is that the combat can feel needlessly clunky, but I feel like that was the idea that the developers had in mind. Often times, it’s better to flee rather than fight, but it only gets harder the further in you get. Trust me on this: Chapter 2 is brutal.

For now, I’m gonna need to grab some sleep and recover from this ordeal, but I very much look forward to continuing this mad venture soon.

Oh, and did I mention that every new game is randomly generated? Guess I’m gonna be playing this through many more times, if I can even get through the first run...

34425068.review:
[code]Это место, этот лес... это какой-то пиздец! Я больше не выдержу, понимаешь?
Доктор[/code]

Darkwood это инди игра в жанре survival horror, на которую собирали деньги краудфайндингом, в неё можно было играть в течении разработки, в ней присутствует крафт, открытый мир и пиксельная (слегка) графика. С таким набором остаётся только закричать «бинго!» и забыть об игре навсегда. Но не спешите.

 Darkwood позиционирует себя как "Survival horror с видом сверху, в который «действительно страшно играть". По первому пункту всё честно. Хоть пить и есть персонажу не хочется, но элементы выживания таки есть. Но страшно ли играть? Нет. Играть погано. Играть неуютно. Вы играли в серию игр Silent Hill? Вам знакомо чувство, когда в игру хочется играть, но в то же время не хочется? Когда игра больше фрустрирует, чем развлекает. Когда чувствуешь гнёт окружающей внутриигровой действительности и не хочешь открывать вон ту дверь и вообще «можно я просто тут посижу?».  Darkwood именно про это.
У вас есть глобальная задача- выбраться из ебучего леса пиздеца. Есть мир, в котором случайно разбросаны неслучайные локации с неслучайными NPC, которые могут помочь вам в вашем деле. А могут и не помочь.
Описание обещает собственную сюжетную линию, но не ведитесь. Всё как всегда- итог один (точнее, концовки две), но путей к нему несколько и от них зависят небольшие нюансы, не больше. То же самое про последствия решений. Они коснутся скорее население мира, чем протагониста. Тут даже нет вопроса «на что ты готов, чтобы выбраться?»- моральный выбор никак не облегчает/усложняет тебе путь.
На плюсах особо задерживаться не буду: визуальный стиль, всё что связано со звуками, персонажи. Одним словом- атмосфера. Отдельно стоит упомянуть, что в официальной локализации персонажи не стесняются в выражениях и не брезгуют русским матом. Довольно редкое явление.
А вот о минусах подробнее:
Я уже говорил, что эта игра треплет нервы и ты не играешь в игру, а именно проходишь её, как испытание. Так вот, когда игра выкидывает тебя во вторую главу на новую карту - ты немного офигиваешь. Геймплей никак не развивается с самого пролога и после 8 часов хочется уже какой-нибудь развязки, а игра просто кидает тебе ещё локацию и отправляет исследовать, обыскивать, зачищать. Это тот случай, когда лучше меньше, да лучше. Но игра продолжает вас мучать. Проблема в том, что открытый мир открытому миру рознь. Если в ГТА ты весело давишь шлюх (проституток), то в Darkwood шлюха это ты, а давит тебя всё что движется в этой грёбаной глуши. Исследовать лес — это не увлекательное приключение, а напрягающая рутина. Когда попадаешь в линейную локацию просто душа радуется от того, как же хорошо, как контент струится с монитора прямо в лицо и как интересно познавать этот мир. Но потом вы снова возвращаетесь в мир, где нужно оббегать сотни поганок, чтобы добраться до NPC, которому надо бы продать вот эту вот бутылку самогона. Игра сильно затянута и чтобы насладиться историей сполна, нужно слишком много беготни ради крупиц контента.
В целом это потрясающая игра, которая точно не оставит вас равнодушным. Удачно выбраться из Тёмного Леса, мясо. И передай им от меня привет!

34418664.review:
За всю свою жизнь, будучи человеком очень привередливым и капризным, я, черт побери, еще не видел такого шедеврального творения, как Darkwood. Я постараюсь без спойлеров и даже основ сюжета. Так, пробегусь по всем особенностям игры и моего личного впечатления.
Я терпеть не могу хорроры, но за этим проектом я начал следить еще с 2014-ого Года, ибо нашел его весьма любопытным. Я упорно не покупал ЕАРЛИ АССЕС версию, помня печальный опыт с DayZ. Но когда Darkwood вышла в релиз, я незамедлительно приобрел.
И НИ РАЗУ НЕ ПОЖАЛЕЛ!
Атмосфера (Особенно в первые часы игры) пробирает до костей! Цветовая гамма, звуки, пост-обработка, хардкорность... Всё это действительно создает ощущение того самого темного леса. "Это не лес, это какой-то пи**ец!" - выразился один из персонажей игры. И ты, слыша чьи-то подвывания, видя искореженные трупы и встречаясь с самой разнообразной нечестью, а то и вовсе жутчайшими явлениями, будешь вынужден дать ту же оценку этому жуткому местечку. 
Персонажи отлично проработаны, особенно в плане внешнего дизайна. Диалоги с ними - одно из лучших, что есть в игре, хотя этих самых диалогов не так много. Поляки-разработчики умело держут интригу, тайну о личности главного героя, о возникновении леса и о много чем еще. По всему игровому миру разбросано огромное колличество мелких намеков, сюжетных предметов, с помощью которых и вырисовывается более чем полноценная картина происходящего. 
Игра ставит перед тобой выборы - один тяжелее другого. Тебе кажется, что выполнив просьбу вон того-то персонажа, ты сделаешь лучше всем? Или наоборот, проигнорировав его? НИ-ФИ-ГА! У каждого выбора или не-выбора есть ощущающиеся во всем протяжении сюжета последствия, в том числе в отношении окружающих к Главному Герою. 
И это, блин, здорово. Здесь вообще нет простых персонажей. Ощущение, что у каждого есть какой-то скелет в шкафу, темная тайна, а может... Этот персонаж и правда столь мил и добр. И вот это размышление над их характерами, над их репликам и течением сюжета во время сбора всякого хлама на просторах леса - вот это просто волшебно. Игра не ведет тебя за ручку по сюжету, рассказывая все свои секреты, а заставлят вдумчиво всматриваться в предоставляемые сцены, делая выводы. 
Единственным минусом можно назвать непосредственно геймплей. По-началу, вид сверху действительно кажется чем-то интересным и необычным для хоррора, но со временем, гринд всякого хлама и отстрел монстров (Которые, к слову, до саомго конца остаются ОЧЕНЬ опасными, особенно если не подобрать нужной тактики), становятся весьма скучными. Особенно после 25-40 часов игры. В такие моменты думаешь, поскорее бы пройти это место и узнать, что будет дальше. Но сюжет, ожидание сюжета, действительно спасает ситуацию. Потому что это восхитительное вознаграждение.
Эта игра оказала огромное на меня влияние. Я впечатлен! Я вдохновлен! Я хочу еще, ПИЛИТЕ ВТОРУЮ ЧАСТЬ, УМОЛЯЮ!

Great atmosphere (think Stalker, Sanitarium, METRO, Silent Hill) but after over 10 hours, I've decided the negative aspects outweigh the positive ones. I'm just not having fun. Movement is too slow, combat is clunky, standing around waiting for the nights to end is boring. The map randomization is not enough to make a replay enjoyable.

It's not a bad game by any means, I just think there are better alternatives available both in survival games and horror games.

34415200.review:
Darkwood is a tense, immersive and unique top down survival horror game, at night time you spend your time fortifying your hideouts for potential invaders and demons. At day time you're tasked to explore the world in order to discover new locations and secrets to further progress the main story line. 

Unlike other horror games where they rely on jump scares, Darkwood immerse the players with intense atmosphere. The audio effects, the world and NPCs creates a beautiful yet creepy, terrifying world for us to imagine and explore in. I got the game when it first came out on early access, and have continously gone back to play it every major content update. The final version has come a long way and deserves to be played by anyone who is even remotely interested in the horror genre!

34411671.review:
[quote] ...слышишь?.. Они повсюду. Это их дом, в котором они заперли нас. И они придут... за мной, за тобой, за всеми, кто остался.
 [/quote]

Когда-то, будучи мальчишкой, я часто приходил сюда с своим дедушкой. Прогуливаясь меж огромных деревьев он постоянно говорил мне, чтобы я уважал лес, и вёл себя так, словно нахожусь в храме. И я почему-то верил ему. Потому что сколько раз после этого я возвращался - всегда было такое-же ощущение, что это - словно иной мир, чуждой и мистический, в котором человеку нет места.

[i] "В доме кто-то есть... Я слышу звуки медленных, тяжелых шагов в соседней комнате. Но, когда я открыл дверь, там никого не оказалось. В этот момент во входную дверь постучались..." [/i]

Подойдя к дереву, и прикоснувшись к нему рукой можно ощутить его дыхание. А если смотреть на кроны, вверху, то и увидеть его. И эти грибы... этот дар леса, который может накормить голодного... или убить его, если тот посмеет хоть на минуту забыть, где он находится.

[i] "Я чувствую ужасную головную боль. Внезапно лампа позади меня с треском гаснет. Я слышу голоса. Это они пришли предупредить меня... чтобы я уходил из их дома, пока ещё могу это сделать..." [/i]

Но сколько бы тебе не нравилось здесь, запомни - с наступлением сумерок, возвращайся домой. Слышишь?
Уходи...

[i] "Прямо сквозь дверь в комнату влетел костлявый дух с головой ворона. Когда мы встретились взгядами, он закричал так, что мои ноги отказались слушаться. От его крика лампа рядом со мной разорвалась, а сам призрак исчез в кромешной тьме. Я слышу, как за стенами щелкают жвалами те, кто пал в попытках усмирить этот лес. Теперь они знают, где я..." [/i]

Проснись...
Почему ты ослушался меня?.. 
Неужели ты до сих пор не осознал, что этот лес пожирает тех, кто пытается извлечь его секреты? Когда-то я был таким же наивным, а сейчас... посмотри, что он сделал со мной. 
Но, теперь уже слишком поздно.
Теперь ты - часть всего этого...

[i] "Треск ломающихся досок привёл меня в чувство. То, что находится за баррикадой, через секунды уже будет здесь. Я из последних сил растянул в стороны ржавый капкан и бросил его под дверной проём, затем рванулся к окну став лихорадочно бить топором по своему же сооружению. Когда брешь стала достаточно широкой, я услышал щелчок капкана позади и вопль того, кто в него угодил. В следующий момент, я уже бежал к издыхающему генератору. Спрятавшись за угол стены я замер, занеся топор над головой. Господи, вытащи меня отсюда... я больше ничего у тебя не попрошу..." [/i]

______________________________________________________________

Darkwood - это шедевр. Он цепляет за что-то внутри: эти персонажи, эти локации, эти события - давно я такой атмосферности не ощущал! Впечатлительным, таким как я, сразу ставить уровень сложности "КОШМАР". И НИ ЗА ЧТО не читать никакие гайды и прохождения. Все ужасы "Тёмного леса" нужно испытать на своей шкуре. Только тогда это будет настоящее приключение.

100 из 100 баллов от меня
