14996202.review:
Ok, I am editing my review due to some negative reviews I have seen (Not many, but for people reading those some extra information is important.). Darwood is one of my favorite games. It is atmospheric, downright terrifying at times (My original review is at the bottom of this one talks a bit about this, it contains a couple spoilers but nothing too specific and it was meant to be more on the humorous side.) and the sound design is absolutely stunning. The FOV system really adds to the tension of the game. Now this game is already amazing! I have played through the game 3 times and loved it every time! If you like the concept support the developers! There are only 3 wizards on the project right now and they can't do everything quickly. Great games take time, some of the most popular game have multimillion dollar budgets with teams consisting of 100s of people. The darkwood team is only 3 people, don't yell and scream at them for not releasing your game early, this is THEIR passion project and early access is not a "Get the game early" it is a "Play the game early, and give feedback for the final release." I think the progress they have made is amazing considering the number of people working on the game.


My original review is here if you want to read it:

Warning: Contains minor spoilers

Well I just barely finished the lynx quest, went through the doctors house and...

Holy crap the roots. The roots fill me with raw fear. I don't understand it, in darkwood there is monsters whose entire BODY is split apart to reveal sharp teeth. And the roots scare me more. Why? Because I don't understand them, I don't know where they come from. I don't know how to beat them. The entire underground is filled with roots. Thats what it means, and that fills me with fear. Going into the church basement is also scary. But not as scary as the roots, the fear of the unknown. And this is why Darkwood is my favorite horror game:









It has made me scared of trees.

14986826.review:
Dear Potential Buyer and Responsible Consumer,

Yes, yes. I understand. Naturally, after looking at this game, and inspite of it's overwhelming positive reviews, you're probably thinking, "But Sirs, yes, I want an unparrallel horror expierence, one that doesn't rely on jump-scares and instead on a purely saturated atmosphere where the dread and fear is actually palpable. BUT, does it really have to be in this..." *cough* "Top-Down-Camera view?" 

And to you, my very cautious and wise consumer, is yes. Yes it does. Before the day I played Darkwood, I never once considered or even desired what these Top-Down-Camera games were selling to me. However, one VERY LONG night I gave this game a shot and I can truly say that the entirely unique horror experience that this game provides is the result of this original game-play and it's camera perspective only empowers it. The gameplay is grueling, punishing, claustrophobic in all of the right ways. 

It's horror experience is deeply woven in it's atmosphere and you feel it all the way down the prickly hairs on your skin. Brought on by the brilliant pacing of the stressful management of time and the THREAT that misusing that time can have deep and unrly consequences. All I can say is, Darkwood's camera perspective could exist within the 4th dimension and it still would be one of the best horror games I have played since the OLD Resident Evil and Silent Hill games. 

Give Darkwood a shot and you won't regret anything but the long nights you spend huddled in a corner whimpering at the things that go bump in the Dark.

14952385.review:
A sickness plagues the land and a wood of mysteries to uncover...during your daylight adventures away from your house.  But at night, you drink from your well, and barricade yourself in as the darkness closes in, and creatures seek you out.

The night was drawing in and the woods began to moan like a corpse.  I turned on the generator, and made my way into my house.  I dragged a stool into one room with two doors, one being the front door, and no windows, and dragged a lamp into the room with me.  As I did this, I could hear things beyond words moving around the outside of the house.  Foot steps?  What is that slithering sound like something running long fingers over the outside walls of the house?

I set up a bear trap near the front door, where I think something might come from, when I hear something slither over the window sill and into the house, fromthe other room.  The sounds it makes are like a drowning man made of clay, and chills me to the bone.  I back away from the door to the other room, stool braced to keep it out.  It moves somewhere and the darkness thickens like a fog of ill intent.  I back into the corner behind the front door.  

The door rattles leading into the next room, and the nob turns slowly.  I raise my weapon and ready myself to fight and scream as madness in form that is walking in my house sets upon me.  But the door quiets.  I cannot hear it moving in the other room.  There is a slight crack in the wall I could peer through, but terror has me glued to the spot.  Is it lurking just outside the door, waiting for me to draw nearer so it can lunge against the foyer's door, swollowing me into the darkness in which it came?

Silence.  Somewhere a dog howls, in the distance.  Perhaps it is the pack of hungry dogs that gave me chase the day before?  There is the sound of dogs fighting and yelping suddenly, and I near run to throw myself against the door to keep what is lurking out.  Nearly.  

I listen as the dogs fight somewhere in the darkness.  Did it leave and found the dogs instead?  Should I brace the door?  I am frantic and torn between what I should do.  I have forgotten the front door that I am hiding behind.  The lamp is pressed against it.  

Suddenly the front door bursts open, the lamp flies back, and the door, opening inwards blocks my view from whatever stormed in to eat me.  However, it blocks it's view of me.  I can hear it growling and thirting for my very soul.  It makes a grunt like the grave, and thuds foward towards the other door, intending to throw back the stool and search the house for me, room from room with the intent of eating me howling and thrashing.

As it moves foward I hear the bear trap spring with ravenous metal hunger and the meaty snap as it slaps through monsterous flesh is sickening.  The thing unseen sreams a surprised and wet gurling scream and there is a thud.

I slowly push the front door closed again and the thing's shape begins to come into focus.  It's hairy and a lump of clay like features, and the darkness outside thickens.  Suddenly the generator gives a dying cough and I am alone in the dark with the thing.  Is it really dead?  Where is it?  I can't see but one foot infront of me.  Does it have a friend near by?  The darkness caresses my cheak as I stand blinking into the dark.  

There is the sound of stirring outside.  I hear a door somewhere in the house creak open and then closed.  I grip my board with a couple nails hammered in it, a pathetic weapon for defense, and it gives me no comfort.  There is a sound again outside, but it is just outside the front door.  It sounds like...sniffing...smelling me in the dark...

The darkness begins to receed, but whatever is outside is moving again, and I can hear it at one of the windows in the room next to mine, the one with only a door and a stool keeping me safe.  It moves off into another room and then there is silence.  

The rays of the sun peek over the horizon and I know that I have made it through the night.  But will I survive another, or another after that?  How long will my luck hold out and will I find enough supplies to fortify my home?  The thing that died is gone, except for a wet splat where it was.  I step outside and check the outisde of the house and see a couple windows that I barricaded are open to the elements.  I move off to the north towards the sounds of the dogs from the night.  Just over the next clearing are number of blood puddles.  This is all that remains of the dogs.  Something came out of the woods and dragged them dying and yelping into the woods.  This pack of dogs could have easily killed me the day before, and something easily came for them this past night.  What do I do if it comes for me tonight?

14919950.review:
The game currently is excellent in what it tries to do. In regards to other games within its category, there is still a lot to be desired. There really isn't this sense of an active world, but, rather, set pieces that are very nicely done. Characters are interesting and I enjoy the look of em, but they never really do anything within the world. Combat feels nice. Atmosphere is excellent. I do have issues with the mandatory well mechanic in which you must drink from your specific well to not die. This prevents really any long term exploration or, what i would call, travelling and living as a nomad. It also seems rather arbitrary as no one else appears to have to undergo this same process despite also having wells <all broken>. There is also the issue of having nothing to do when waiting throughout the night. My experiences have either been immense boredom <which happens when the night noises become routine> or small moments of stress at later nights. But, for the nights, there is never this sense of productivity, just waiting. 

As it stands, for what it wants to be, it is excellent. Would I play it over games like Pathologic? No.

14420944.review:
Let me first say that if you are not fond of hard games, this may not be the game for you. The game has a rather steep learning curve for first timers... But for those who brave it and learn from it, I assure you that you will thuroughly enjoy this game. Suffice it to say, your character may die in this game... perhaps a lot in your first play through. Though, like dark souls, every 'death' is a learning experience, and this game rewards persistance. 

Matched with an environment as creepy as its well-told story, the Devs have truly outdone themselves with the creation of compelling (and very disturbing) characters shown in a world full of danger. You will quickly need to learn how to survive and, for the sake of maintaining the resorces you find, find tricks to keeping your character alive. 

The fact that this game is still in Alpha is, for me, among the most exciting factors of the experience. In and of itself, the game has run without flaw from me, save a few minor easy-to-avoid/get past glitches that I have seen in many slelf-proclaimed 'finished' games. Just so, the thought of MORE being added to this game in every aspect pleases me greatly. This is a game well worth both attention and support... And heck, why not have a GREAT time playing what they have thus far while doing both of these things?

14306605.review:
I'd been following Darkwood for about six months before it was released. It looked very fun, very scary, and really hard, but not hard enough to prevent you from having fun. Man, was I wrong.

This game is obscenely difficult. Resources are scarce to the point that, if you run out of a particular item, you're basically fucked. Gasoline, arguably the most important resource in the game, is so low in number that its nearly impossible to divy it up between each gas-hungry tool that needs it.

The "scary" part of the game, i.e. surviving the night, isn't scary. It's irritating. You are forced to sit in a dark room for four minutes, and if you move at all, you get wrecked by monsters with toothed-vaginas for heads. If you don't move, nothing happens. It's either really boring or really stressful. Where's the fun in that?

TL;DR: I REALLY wanted to like this game. I played it after every update to see what new additions had come with it. But it's just not fun. It never has been, and likely never will be. Spend your money on something worthwhile, like Undertale or Dungeon of the Endless.

14271905.review:
I gotta say, this game is quite unique, its got potential to be amazing or be bad dending on what the devs do with it.

Here is a few pros and cons.


Pros: 

1: OK who ever worked on the sound for this game is a flipping genius. I'm not kidding everything about the sound for this game is 10/10

2: Its a 2D game that made me slam me knee into my desk because of a jump scare, dude bonus points. like how does that even happen?

3: An early access game that is actully fun and the devs care about so it will get better.

4: NPCs and differnt locations

5: A interesting level up system (This is also a con) with the ability to choose various perks, both negitive and positive.

6: I dig the graphics on this.

Cons:

1: Remember the negitive perks I mentioned? Well the first negitive one is ruinous to the game, it is down right horrible. If you're in the dark to long "Shadows" start damaging you. In a game where light source is limited this is a horrible idea. The looping sound effect and forcing you to be in the light completely takes away the scare factor. The devs NEED to ditch this idea.

2: Poisonous mushrooms. OK this one is right up there with the shadows in the "Devs why on this good green Earth would you do that?!" department. They are EVERYWHERE and touch them and BOOM, you're either gonna move slower or be somewhat blind. On top of that you will be poisoned, do we really need all these exploding mushrooms?

3: There is so much blur and bloom in the distance its almost light having poor vision and it kinda hurts your eyes a bit.

4: I have played this game for 4 hours at this point, so I dunno I have prolly been through I'd say around 8 nights. Never once has something tried to attack me in my hideout. No busting down doors, no running, no fighting. Although once I heard something murder a dog outside the door (Which was freaking creepy and fantastical by the way.)

5: For God sake man, let me at least punch. I mean for real, he has been given a fist for a reason, use it.

6: Not being able to harvest items is a really kind of frustrating but I would assume we would be able to in the future.

7: Due to number 6 con, the crafting system is a pain.

The Con of every horror game ever made: The protagonist being quite out of shape, only being able to run 20 feet without wanting a whopper.

Mixed feelings: The well mechanic of the... Each night you must drink from "The well" to keep yourself from decaying each night. While I like that it forces you to go outside each night I hate the fact that I have to get to it in a short time of when "The thirst starts." As I said I love that you can't be a weiner waiting for dawn inside, but I want to explore at night. Like if there was night only quests that would be awesome.

In short, its early access, its already fun. I can almost say for certain the devs will improve this game. (Step one less mushrooms and remove the freaking shadows.)

I'd recommend this game and I'd say it a good idea of how EA should work. Unlike those acursed atrocity of a game Starforge and "The tower."

6/10

14151828.review:
As many people here said this before me: THE ATMOSPHERE IS AWESOME! 
The style of this game fits it perfectly and some decisions you must make are really great and add a lot to the atmosphere (I would like more of these :)
Also I am Slavic by myself Czech to be exact (This game is made by Poland developers, we are neighbours) so the story and settings that this game has is more familiar with me, interesting and creepier and I enjoy it much more than lets say: Amnesia (don´t eat me alive, just my opinion). 
The notes and old photos, old things that people left there, that you can find are very interesting and they will drive you more into the situation of the game.
Locations are also very interesting (and dangerous) and I always felt good (I am the adventurous type, I explored few deserted locations in real life, I enjoy these things a lot) and also weirded/creeped out when I was exploring some new building or landmark. 
Just look on the web for pictures preferably (it is for your own good), but be careful this game can be easilly spoilered (or can I just say spoiled? Not a native speaker here, sorry!), so don´t look on gameplays much, if you want to buy it.

The camera from the birds point of view is also very nicely done, like for example when you are stranded in the forest, you can see the branches of the trees and fallen trees and the effects like: lights and shadows in buildings are very nice. There is also physics, that adds interesting mechanics like: pushing various objects to barricade yourself from an enemy that is chasing you,
or pushing against doors when something tries to walk in. 
Also you can barricade with planks and nails of course, when you have the time.  
Or if you throw something it will slide on the ground, so you can see the physics in action.
You can also run into the doors to break them open, when you are running from an enemy.

It has of course a good amount of bugs or glitches, like light problem when some parts of the forest will flicker for a second so you can´t see, and also dissapearing enemies, that occured to me quite often with chompers. 
To explain you the glitch/bug: Sometimes when it was chasing me it would dissapear and stopped attacking until I bumb into it accidentally or look in other direction for it, then it would quickly appear and almost kill you or start chasing you)
Also I would change the fighting system a bit (it is really hard to hit something with the axe and or shovel, because it just takes too long to ''charge'' the attack) and breaking of the melee weapons (they break unnecesearly/unrealistically often) and the crafting system is very small and simple, maybe add more variety and complexity, like new barricading structures and weapons. 

The developers are quite active and responsive also the updates are every month (more or less).
So everything will get better and the game will get bigger after some time.
The developers will have to do their best as the game is far from completion.

Also this game is rather hard and will not hold your hand. 
There is a prologue, that will teach you few things, but then you are on your own and you will have to act like you would act in that situation, you must adapt to it.

If you are searching for some new horror-survival game and if you are a fan of deep atmosphere and story games, that is not only about the blood/gore and jumpscares GO FOR THIS ONE, you won´t regret it!

13990619.review:
I'm gonna be honest, at first I wasn't so sure about this game. Due to all the positivity from reviews, I went ahead and bought it, started a permadeath file, and jumped straight in. The first thing I noticed once I booted it up was that it looked absolutely astounding for a top down game. It oozes atmosphere from literally every crevice, and darkness looks and feels like a living thing, like it's out to consume you. However, once I got past the equally atmospheric prologue and was thrown out into the world to fend for myself, I started to worry. I went out and got some supplies during the day, and once night came along, I ran back to my hideout and hid. Then I did the same the next night. And the next. And the next. By day 5 I started to get bored from the constant repetition. It seemed like the only thing I had to worry about in the day was wolves, and once you get over the initial fear of being attacked, they're pretty easy. Then I'd just stand in a room in my house for a few minutes and rinse, repeat. It seemed like as long as you hid in your hideout, you were free from harm. However, not long after, the game showed it's true colors.

              During the 2nd night of my 2nd playthrough (the 1st playthrough had ended from a moment of panic and a badly misplaced bear trap), I heard something shuffling around in a room next to the one I was in. With the only light source in the whole hideout being a flare on the ground, I decided the best idea would be to go into this completely dark room to look for it. It was so dark in there that I couldn't see anything even inches away from me, which was all the distance the zombie-like creature needed to slash me in the face and take away about a third of my health. I freaked out and ran into the other room, slamming the door right in the ugly fucker's face. It then proceeded to casually push open the door in less than a second. I had no intention of fighting it, so I ran away in a panic, not really registering that there was literally nowhere to run except past my flare and straight into even more darkness. Once I passed the flare my running devolved into blind stumbling, and before I could stop shoving my face into the wall trying to find the doorway, the monster hacked away at me from behind and and I fell to the ground. Dead on day 2.
      
  All the playthroughs after that, at least one monster got into my hideout by day 4. It's basically inevitable that something will get in, I just had literal beginner's luck, and got to enjoy a few extra days of life before my so very inevitable demise. Once you realize you're not safe in your hideout, the game really succeeds at the classic survival game goal of turning you into a paranoid schizophrenic. Even in daytime, the game basically becomes 360 turn simulator 2015, with you constantly looking around to make sure there's no bear traps or wolves nearby, obscured by trees or your own narrow vision cone. And before long (like "before the first week's even over" long), you'll start to run low on supplies in the first section of the map, and will have to venture out into the more.... unsavory areas. We're talking areas where all those creatures that hack you to pieces at night occupy the WHOLE place during the day. And this isn't a game where you can level up and laugh in the faces of the enemies that used to give you trouble. Oh no, this is one of those games where you're always feeble and weak, and you either find a better weapon so you can stand a better chance against ONE enemy, or you hide from and outsmart them. Although the combat's very fair, and gives you small openings in enemy animations to attack, it's by no means easy, and you can't just murder everything in sight once you've got their patterns down.
       
           Last, the game has an amazing sense of discovery, also due in no small part to it's incredible atmosphere. Since the world feels so threatening, but you desperately need supplies, you get a mix of elation and anxiety whenever you find a new point of interest, and exploring these new places is one of the most tense parts of the game. Whether what you find in these places want to kill you or not, you'll always find something interesting and unpredictable.
      
             All in all, if you're looking for a horror game where death is actually something to be afraid of, unlike, say Amnesia, where the murderous creatures managing to kill you only lowers your immersion, then this game is a gift from the heavens. And don't let the early access label scare you away, this is the most complete feeling early access game I've ever played. As it is, the game could be released right now and feel complete. It's definitely worth the buy.


               And yes, it is scary.

13922722.review:
I love this game.
It's something I've never played before: top down+horror=unique gameplay.
Nights are scary. Not only must you hide from savages lurking around your hideout, but the shadows that want to consume you. Grab a torch and pray for the night to end!
There are three sections in the map: Meadows, The Forest and The Old Woods. Each of these zones are harder than the other, and the farther you go, the more interesting locations you can find.
After strolls around the woods harvesting odd mushrooms and meat, you can return to your hideout and cook it into a liquid substance and inject yourself with a dose. This lets you choose one skill from the first tier, however, each tier has its negative skills aswell, such as the shadows, mentioned before.
You'll find yourself dying alot, the map may be hard to use as it doesnt show where you exactly are unless near a certain location, but worry not, it shows where you died and lost your inventory, so you can try to retrieve your precious loot.

I definitely recommend this game to people who want some hardcore horror survival!

It won't. You don't get a lot of supplies, you have limited time to wander from your safehouse to find new locations and your map is elementary at best. You'll often be completely lost wandering around the woods, and that's part of what makes the game so scary, especially when the sun is going down and you can't remember where your safehouse is.

My lights went out, i turned on my torch, and this shambling dude comes up to me with a stick, moaning. I got a couple of good hits on him and he ran, while shadows suddenly surrounded me in my lack of light....and then bam. Morning.

I like this game. I really do. So I'll give ya the long and short of it.

SHORT:

-Not scary like, "BOO! Ha ha." This is Scary like "................*muffled growl*................................*cracked stick*.........."

-Hard. Really hard.

-Lots of fun

LONG:

-=This review is published Dec. 12, 2014. It has to do with the major update, Alpha 3.0, and the gameplay changes made.=-

Alpha 3.0 made it impossible to last more than 1 day without crawling everywhere and checking every square inch of land infront of you before allowing even a single foot fall. It's a perpetually white-nuckled crawl.

Alpha 2.9 had mushrooms randomly in the woods. If you stepped on one, you'd be poisoned. Those were annoying and occasionally fatal. But you could harvest them and not have to worry about stepping over it. That was too easy and leisurely. Alpha 3.0 places these mushrooms everywhere the light fails. It puts you on edge and forces your gaze forward, like reality (nobody walks in the wilds without checking the forest floor constantly)

-= CONTEXT NOTE: I previously reviewed this patch and complained about it. I gave it a negative review. Then I immediately started playing again. That should say something about the game and me. =-

The devs have contacted me. I feel special. Anyway, the way they read through comments shows that they really care about this game. Again I really do like it, but it got alot harder with the last update. I guess that just came as a shock to me. I was too used to strolling through the woods with my eyes crossed, swinging a board with nails at everything that moved, but... I can't anymore. I must meticulously scan all around me.... Looking for the next enemy.... the next trap.... the next pair of eyes searching my face for signs of confusion, just waiting for the right moment to knock me out with a 3 meter pole and leave me in the middle of nowhere missing my gear and possibly my virginity.

It's a horror game. Don't complain. 10/10

13220977.review:
Started this gaming dying over and over continually. I was being killed going outside the house and at night by savages breaking through my "fortified" windows. I was becoming severely frustrated. However, I found out hiding in a corner behind my wardrobe protected me, if anything got inside. That's when the game took a turn from frustrating to addicting. I started traveling only in cardinal directions, in that way I never got lost again. A few days surviving, turned into weeks of surviving. After not dying for nearly 40 days, I was full level, was in hideout 2, had an arsenal of weapons, supplies, and enough gasoline to light up my place forever. Around day 55 I decided it was finally time to venture to the Old Woods. It had taken a lot of grinding and sleepless nights, but I felt ready to finally embark on the quests I had received months ago now. My nights in the meadow and the forest had spoiled me once I finally arrived in the Old Woods. I had weapons and ammo galore, but I was thoroughly unprepared. Nightmarish creatures chased me the minute I arrived. I don't know how to describe them, but I know I'll never forget the terror they instilled. They were blood red with enormous black teeth. They were much faster than me, but I had a gun. It took some effort, but i managed to kill them both. I had low health at this point and it was about 6:30pm. I was a tad lost, but knew I had to try to make it home. I ate a mushroom and rushed home at top speed. By the time I made it to the threshold between the Forest and Old Woods it was about 8:30pm. It was very dark and I was beginning to grow concerned. The noises in the Forest at night are enough to worry any man... I raced to the chicken ladies' house and made it there about 9pm. I had a half an hour to make it to the well before the thirst set in. About halfway between my house and her's, a monstrous version of the nightmarish creatures I had encountered in the Old Woods began to persue me at great speed. It had a dark, foggy-like miasma all about it and it was much faster and stronger than it's counterparts. I tried to get away, but it was too fast for me. I could see the lights of my house on in the background. I was so close... I fired a few shots at the creature as I backed up toward the light. The creature proved to fast for me and dodged my shots. I could see the front door now of my generator shed, but the creature was relentless. The creature attacked, I dodged, and in the lull, rushed for the shed. I busted through the door and the creature took a bite as I made it through the threshold. I was low on health and the creature was much too fast for me to attempt to bind the wounds or take one of those magic heal-all pills. I rushed through the shed to the second room, the creature tried to take it's last bite, but it missed. I rushed around the corner trying to make it to my wardrobe. I thought that, maybe if I could get behind it, maybe I could hide out until morning. I got behind the wardrobe and almost got it in front of the creature, but the creature proved much too powerful. He wouldn't be impeded by a mere wooden wardrobe like his weaker counterparts, or the measly savages. In an instant, the wardrobe was thrown across the room. There was nothing between the creature and I now. I had no bullets left for my pistol and only one shell left in my single-shot shotgun. I took my shot, Then everything went dark. I woke up next to my oven the next day without a scratch, but I no longer could "see" as well as I could before. I needed more of the precious "essence". I decided instead of venturing to the Old Woods and risking death again, I would venture around the "much safer" Forest. Within the hour, I ran into two savages and a huge dog. In my scuffle with them, I killed one of the savages and severely wounded the dog. I attempted to run away from them, in the hopes of healing myself and returning, and ran right into a bear trap. It snapped.... and sealed my doom. 
So, the moral of the story, is this is one of the greatest games I have played in a very long time. There's a lot to see and do, interesteding story premise, quests, and its incredibly addicting. I can't wait for this game to be completely finished, but even in this early Alpha state, I haven't even begun to explore the Old Woods and complete many of the quests. I didn't expect much out of this game, what with it being early Alpha release, and me knowing nothing about the game. I took a chance and bought it, and I can say that it was entirely worth it and I look forward to the future of this game. Good job devs, I hope to see even more cool features implemented into the game and can't wait for the official release.
My one criticism would be the absence of a save function :/
Otherwise easily 11/10 (Extremely addicting) :D

13172954.review:
Now that I've had this game for quite some time, I think I can offer a better insight into it than before.

GAMEPLAY:

Good. The devs are excellent about fixing any bugs that are found, as evidenced by the flurry of hotfixes immediately after the official release. Combat is tough to get the hang of, but satisfying when you finally land a powerful blow right on that annoying mutant wolf's snout. The game doesn't force you to explore off the beaten path, but it rewards you greatly for doing so (if you can handle the dangers, of course). Your character's vision is represented by a cone of light in front of you. Anything outside this cone is gray and blurry. Also, enemies and NPCs do not show up unless they are within your view. This adds danger to any encounter, as there could be something sneaking up behind you when you least expect it.


GRAPHICS:

Excellent 2D graphics that add even more to the game's already gripping atomsphere. I was surprised at how suspensful a top-down game like this could be.


ATMOSPHERE:

Superb. The eerie sounds of the forest blend with the crunching of leaves and snapping of twigs beneath your feet to form a permating feeling of spookiness. The enemies are a perfect mix of weird and downright freaky, and I found myself fighting the nearly irresistable urge to turn around and flee while exploring some areas. I jumped at nearly every out-of-place sound, especially at night.


STORY:

Very interesting and appropriately twisted. I won't spoil anything, but I will say that this game's narrative is on a level of its own. Sadly, a few misspellings in the text take away from this a little bit.


In other words,
A GUD GAME

13128296.review: I bought this game during the Autumn Sale and I am very pleasently surprised. When I first got into the game it was a little weird to be because I've personally never played a game with this perspective before, but once i got the hang of it and found myself venturing into the creepy woods, I saw how immersive this game was. With the creepy noises of stepping on branches and the barks of rabid dogs I found myself scared for my life. This game also has a really nice crafting system where you can find abundant items like clothe and wood and mix it with some more rare items found in chests to make very useful items to use to your advantage or sell to the wolfman for ammo or other items. The lighting sysetm in this game is genius as well, where in a house your flashlight only shows a little of the room but when u turn on a lamp it brightens most of the room where you are looking. And when you explore the woods your light grows dimmer and dimmer the further you go until you need to craft a torch to see anything. some minor bugs were found in the game but you must expect that from a Early Access game. With all this in mind I give this game probably a 9.5/10 in its current state because of how amazingly done this game was. The immersion effect of this game is close to if not better than the Amnesia series and even the Slender games. Thanks and I urge you to pick this game up while its still on sale.

12995928.review:
Such a romanticly erotic masterpiece, kidding. This game takes an underrated perspective, and makes it work well again. Most games that have been released with such an art direction as well as perspective have been highly lack luster. this game marries the concept of ambience(via lighting, audio and environment generation) with the idea of having a false sense of awareness in the space that you currently occupy to create a sense of fear that has been hard to find since the original resident evil games. notably, this game is a true Survival Horror game with a psychologically engaging story told in the most spectacular way. The story is told in a very david lynch~ish style, similar to hotline miami.... but lets not make that mistake and get the two mixed up as they are both two extremely different game.

to cut everything else I would say short... because there is plenty I can say about this game...
Get it... It is definatly worth its price tag in its current state... the story will build an anxiety that will make you beg the developers to some how travel into the future, steal the finished copy... and release it now... which would cause some sort of crazy ass paradox. the gameplay is soooo solid in its current state... I wonder what else they will add as I am quite satified with it as is. and last... The sense of fear and just truely feeling lost at times in the forest is truely nerve racking especially as night fall comes.

Key Elements:
~Intense Combat Mecanics which are also used to interact with the environments in various ways.
~Object interaction... Multiple options to interact with objects via "drop Down menu" like most D&D games.
~Lighting, Creates a horrifying tone espeially when the developers literally take all light away during the night... Insanely scary, dont change that.
~Atmosphere, The sound creates a dread that will haunt you and keep you on edge for your entire play through.
~sense of exploration, The map system is actually an interesting one as you have no idea where you are until you discover something aside from your hideout... giving you a "sense of direction, It totally works for this game. 

Get this game... its worth yur time and money..

~Mike.M

p.s.
sorry for the late review, I bought the gae over the summer... looooved it... and played it recently and just... WOW!

12852340.review:
Darkwood has real potential to revive its genre.

I am a huge fan of older survival horror titles including the original Resident Evil and Silent Hill games and have watched the genre die with every new release. Modern day 'survival horrors' have this awful habit of spoon feeding players with abundant resources and frequent saving opportunities. This isn't the case with Darkwood; you have to scavenge for what little you can and you will struggle. The devs have done a brilliant job of balancing this game and ensuring that, all the while, you are absorbing the creepy atmosphere.

The style and overall feel of the game is a real tribute to old-school survival horrors. The visual effects are dark and gloomy; the music and sound effects are eerie and build the perfect amount of tension. Hearing an enemy breaking your barricades in the silence of the night is truly terrifying. The controls are a refreshing change and combat is challenging, but engaging and actually quite fun.

Although at the stage of posting my review we're only able to play the first chapter of the storyline, I can confidently say that you are immediately drawn in to the true spirit of the survival horror genre. Yes this game is challenging and yes you'll probably die a few times on your first try, but it's a welcome change.

I'll be keeping a close eye on updates to Darkwood. The devs are actively improving this game and I can't wait to see what else they have in store for us. Even from playing just the first chapter I am intrigued to know more about what happened in Darkwood.

12795142.review: RECOMENDADO!Darkwood é certamente um jogo em que você vai ficar vidrado do começo até o fim, se tiver coragem claro.O jogo é muito misterioso e te revela poucas informações sobre o que está acontecendo á sua volta, assim te deixando com vontade de descobrir cada vez mais coisas sobre o mesmo.A jogabilidade é muito boa e responde bem aos comandos, o sistema de combate é um pouco complicado no início mas depois de um tempo acostuma.Os gráficos fazem a sua parte no jogo, com ambientações escuras e mórbidas, a iluminação do jogo é a sua chave também pois é dela que você depende no jogo praticamente.Da história sei realmente pouca coisa, pois é um jogo relativamente fácil de morrer e os momentos reveladores são raros, devido ao mapa que não vem revelado, nos forçando assim a vagar por ai para tentar achar algo útil, até a noite cair claro.Na noite o mal vem a tona e é ai que as coisas ficam realmente tensas, se você não conseguiu voltar ao seu escoderijo até essa hora, você pode se considerar morto...se conseguiu voltar apenas tente sobreviver e tente não morrer de sede(A sede é sanada com água de um poço que fica fora do seu esconderijo e sim o jogo te força a sair do esconderijo para bebe-la).O sistem de Crafting é bem simples e intuitivo assim facilitando um pouco a nossa vida, o problema está em conseguir material para craftar itens, pois são escassos e difíceis de se achar.Os NPC's também estão presentes e contriubuem bastante para reforçar o mistério do jogo.O áudio também é um grande pro do jogo, com músicas ambientes bem macabras e darks, o jogo também sabe explorar bem o áudio para te deixar cada vez mais tenso(do nada você escuta galhos quebrando a sua volta,vegetação balançando e afins).Resumindo é um DEVE JOGAR! e certamente vale o dinheiro investido, e olha que o jogo ainda está em acesso antecipado!10/10!

12623042.review:
There you are, alone, in your safe house with nothing but the darkness for company. Then all of a sudden, you hear a scream, and what's that? Your furniture is moving all by itself. It's ok though, you're safe, in your barricaded room and there's only another few minutes of night time left. Oh, wait, they're knocking on your door, you can see the barricade splinter...It's fine, daylight will save you. Argh, but here they come, relentlessly banging on your door and it's one hit away from being broken. Phew, daylight is here, but you have no wood left to barricade yourself in when night time comes again. You have no weapon so you need to go out into the woods to scavenge and prepare yourself, but you know they're lurking out there too.

Darkwood does this brilliantly, it builds up so much tension that even when nothing is going on, you're still on edge. Sure, there are a few bugs still in the game, but it's an early Alpha release, and the devs have acknowledged that a few things here and there need to be fixed.

Don't let the bugs take away from what is a stunning survival game, and a survival game that builds up the horror through it's atmosphere like no other that I've played recently. Reminiscent of the old Silent Hill games in the way that it builds tension, it builds you up and then knocks you down but it's not frustrating.  You don't mind meeting your maker, even though you lose your precious mushrooms, because you learn a little each time you die.

The game looks beautiful, the lighting is glorious and really helps set the tone when you're out to discover new things.  Your cone of vision can either help you out or destroy you if you're not vigilant enough, but it's something you get used to after a while.

The crafting system works nicely, and is clear and easy to use, but sometimes the amount that you can carry becomes a little bit of a problem, that said, it doesn't take away too much from the experience.  If anything, the frustration is outweighed by the fear that you won't have enough to survive the night, making the game more tense.

The world is randomly generated on each play through so you will never get tired of exploring the same old places again and again.

The characters in the game thus far have enough depth to influence how you behave toward them, but enough mystery that you never really know what to expect from them the NPCs are great fun to come up against whether you're ready to fight them or not.

Darkwood is something that any survival horror fan should try out and if at first it seems a little slow, I'm sure that it will grow on you and eventually you will approach each night filled with terror and worry that you've missed something and they can get in your safe house while you're completely defenseless because you didn't have time to craft a new weapon before you had to lock yourself in.

If you're still unsure whether to get the game or not, then please check out my playthrough and see how I experienced the night terrors (and the day terrors for that matter) and then form your own opinions, and hopefully learn from my mistakes if you do decide to get the game!

12516481.review:
It’s 2:30 AM and I had myself backed into the last small and desolate room of my home base.  My flashlight trained, not on the sounds of wet acidic undergrowth that has taken over what used to be the foyer to my hideout, but the splintering door hanging to its frame on the far side of the room from me.  The only taste for flare in this room is a stool I have jammed against the door as one last final barricade.  This was my last stand and I’m ill equipped to face the horrors that have been tearing their way after me all night.  
In Darkwood, the night is a stressful 5 minutes of gameplay where you shore up your defenses and hope that the creatures of darkness don’t tear you to pieces before day breaks and you are once again free to unravel the mystery of the plague afflicting these lands.  Your only clue, a doctor who still lives somewhere nearby with the forlorn mission of curing the local villagers of their blight. The most respectable villagers’ bodies have rotted and their minds have frayed.  Their gruesomely drawn images are ghastly warning s of what happens to those who linger in the Darkwood too long, a thought that scratches at the back of my mind with each passing night spent in your hideout.  To survive you consume odd mushrooms and tainted meat which granting powers to cope with the cruel forest in which even the trees seek to claim you by clawing at your line of sight with crow laden branches.  Your tainted new powers come with a price, nauseating side effects and warped hallucinations that could be clues to what went wrong in these woods or signs that your mind is decaying like those around you.   Darkwood is a cruel game but no more than a true horror game should be, it challenges the player with every encounter but if you really want to get the full effect play on permadeath.
Dawn is almost here now, I think that I should be able to make it through the night when the doorknob turns and the door creaks ever so slowly open and rather than raining open in a hail of splinters like the horrors have done to the rest of my house.  Monsters are wiggling their way through the crack and pushing my barricade effortlessly to the side I aim my pellet gun in hopes that I can survive through one more night in the Darkwood.

12016222.review:
Paranoyak biriyseniz Darkwood oynarken kafayı yememeniz pek de mümkün değil. Paranoyak değilseniz, olmaya hazır olun!

    Uyurken bile yüzlerini görüyorum, bana güvenle bakıyorlar.
    Onları iyileştirebilirmişim, onları bu vebadan kurtarabilecekmişim gibi bakıyorlar bana.
    Topraklarını, vücutlarını ve akıllarını yok eden bu vebayı durdurabilecekmişim gibi bakıyorlar.
    Buradan çıkış yok ve bense onlarla birlikte burada tıkılı kaldım.
    Onların bitmek bilmeyen yakarışları, ağlamaları ve fısıldadıkları dualarla geçiyor günlerim.

Bağımsız yapımlar son zamanlarda oyunculara gerçekten istediklerini verebilen yapımlar haline geldi. Erken erişim ile birlikte oyunları yapım aşamasındayken oynamanın verdiği heyecanın yanı sıra daha yerine oturmamış mekanikler biraz can sıkıcı olabiliyor. Darkwood şu an erken erişimde olmasına rağmen öyle göze çarpacak derecede hatası yok açıkçası.Darkwood Consept Art

Hayatta kalma oyunlarını genelde FPS olarak oynamışızdır. Gerçekçilik açısından her ne kadar FPS tercih edilse de Darkwood’da bu söz konusu değil. “Kuşbakışı bir korku oyunu bizi ne kadar korkutabilir ki?” demeyin sakın. Hikayesi ve etrafta gelişen olaylar ile oyun sizi içine çekiyor.

Darkwood roguelike tarzı bir oyun diyebiliriz. Sizi görevlerinize yönlendirecek herhangi bir işaret bulunmuyor. Oyun sırasındaki diyaloglar size ne yapmanız ve nerelere gitmenizi söylüyor fakat bunları yaparken tek başınasınız. Oyunda bir harita mecvut fakat gittiğiniz yeri, bulunduğunuz noktayı göstermiyor. Harita işlevini ileride anlatacağım, öncelikle biraz hikayeden(!) ve oynanıştan bahsederek başlayalım.

Oyunun atmosferinden ve hikayesinden bahsetmek gerekirse, oyunun açılışında bize bir vebadan bahsediliyor. Hikayenin geçtiği bölgede bir veba söz konusu ve buna neyin sebep olduğu belli değil. Açılışta bizlere vebanın bölgenin halkının topraklarını, vücutlarını, akıllarını götürdüğü söyleniyor. Öyle bir salgın ki, cesetler bile kısa zamanda kök salıyor ve mantarlanıyor.

Yapımcılar oyunun hikayesinin anlaşılabilir bir yanı olmadığını söylüyorlar. Oyunu bitirseniz bile hikayeyi tam olarak çözemeyeceğinizi belirtiyorlar. Gerçekten de öyle. Oyun esnasında etraftaki diğer insanlar ile kurduğunuz diyaloglar size hikayeyi anlatmaktansa kafanızın daha çok karışmasına sebep oluyor. Fakat diyaloglar o kadar iç karartıcı ve anlamsız ki, olur olmaz gerilmenize sebep oluyor diyebilirim...

... incelemenin tamamı için: http://8piksel.com/darkwood/inceleme/

Darkwood için 8piksel puanı: 7.9/10

11943326.review:
Despite being early access, this game already has a lot going for it. The oppressive atmosphere really helps to immerse players into the game, while the overall difficulty really cements the fact that here in the forest the player is not the most dangerous thing lurking in the darkness. The gameplay is fairly simple at the moment; from a top-down view the player walks around the game world, their line of site represented by a visual cone, when the character is not facing something like, say, a searchable pile of rubble or a wandering enemy or NPC, they disappear from the game map, though you can still hear them. This is used to quite terrifying effect if your power goes out and a monster breaks into your home, as your field of view shrinks tremendously, or when you need to craft a weapon or use something from your inventory, as your field of vision disappears while your character has to rummage around inside his pack. Melee combat is fairly simple but rewarding, and good timing is key to surviving any unavoidable confrontation. I've seen gameplay of firearms, but have yet to personally acquire one myself.

The story, at this point, isn't all that clear to me. The bare bones of it is that the player character is stranded within a forest of the Soviet Block, apparently after some form of horrific mind and body altering plague outbreak, however, this is certainly not just another generic "and then zombies" story. The creatures and characters you will meet have been transformed or changed in very strange and terrifying ways. The current goal of the player seems to be to find their way out of the forest, a task that will take them quite some time as they must survive multiple nights, hidden in their homes as they are set upon by monstrosities from God knows where.

The game, being in early Alpha, does have its issues though.

As stated before, the game is quite difficult. Extremely so, to be honest. Chances are very high that, like myself, players will not find any remotely decent melee weapons for the first few nights at best, and will be forced to either run around their home all evening to flee from any intruding monsters or waste precious limited nails and wood boards used to barricade doors and windows or repair doors or windows to make what is essentially the crappiest weapon you can have; board with nails. This is accentuated by the fact that the map is randomly generated, with locations being spread out across different areas each time. Only once have I ever found an Axe within the first two nights, and that was pure luck.

Currently there is no difficulty option, and so players will constantly come face to face with extremely powerful and fast monsters. You can outrun most of them, but many can easily keep pace with the player, who will eventually run out of stamina when sprinting. When the player dies, they lose the remainder of the current day they were on, unless playing in Permadeath, as well as any collected items such as Mushrooms, while also taking large damage to any item with a durability meter, such as weapons, gas cans, or flashlights and lanterns. The game essentially punishes players for dying multiple times over, as the only way to repair melee weapons, for instance, is to find Repair Kits, which so far have been few and far between at best, which more or less forces one to make the decision of whether it's even worth it to bring a weapon or durability item with them outside of Permadeath because should they die it loses something near half of its durability, and every single bit is precious in this game where virtually everything you cannot speak to is trying to eat your face.

Hopefully in a future update, the durability of items will either be raised or the health of enemy monsters will be lowered, or some form of difficulty option will be implemented. I truly enjoy this game, but having all of my items breaking because I'm trying to explore to find objects to PREVENT myself from having my items breaking gets quite tiresome. Finding an Axe and Repair Kit only to have your house randomly besieged by a bird-headed beast and something that resembles a Schism from Silent Hill: Homecoming on the second night, dying, and then having to use that one precious Repair Kit just to ensure I can fix up my axe and try to not die the next night is not what I'd call fun, but tedious.

The game could definitely benefit from some more crafting options, such as  more traps. So far the only traps I'm aware of are Bear traps, which the player finds strewn about in the forest or in crates and such, or smashing some bottles to make broken glass. I'm surprised there's no option for, say, using some nails and a board to create a nail strip to put on window sills or something to that effect. Perhaps some wooden stakes the player could place outside of doors or windows to damage enemies that walk through them.  These do not need to do ludicrous amounts of damage, I just thought it would be a nice touch, seeing as how it's odd your character only seems to have the intelligence of nailing boards to door frames and windows, and not building much of anything else with them. They could even make the costs for such craftable things rather high, such as requiring 15 nails for one nail strip, or 10 boards for a single set of wooden stakes. Seeing as how these resources are fairly limited anyway, I don't see much issue in alloowing more options for people to use them on.

In the game, you can actually smash down doors and windows if, say, they are barricaded or locked. This offers another method of getting into locations should you lack a key or lockpick. However windows, and even when unbarricaded, doors have a ludicrous amount of durability. I'm not sure what those Soviets made their bedroom doors out of, perhaps reinforced concrete? Most weaponry, besides an Axe, breaks before a door or barricaded window is even at a third of its overall durability. These are, for all intents and purposes, old wooden doors with some old wooden boards nailed behind them. Why then does it take roughly a third of an axe's durability to chop one down, even when it's simply locked?

There's no way to attack without a melee weapon. The player cannot swing a punch or anything of the sort. While this does make the game more challenging, I also find it incredibly strange when facing another human enemy or wild dog that we cannot at least throw some exceptionally weak punches to fend them off. In most cases this would be suicide anyway, as once again, the enemies can take a fairly ridiculous amount of punishment while also dealing well over the damage the player deals in many cases, but it would still be nice to even have the option of being able to pathetically defend ourselves. I'm fairly certain if a naked man cornered me inside my home and began hurling rocks at me, I would at least try and defend myself, not continually run around the room.

Perks at this point in time are somewhat pointless, unless you can survive for exceptionally long periods of time you will simply die and lose the perks you just wasted some of the limited number of mushrooms you've gathered on. I've simply taken to storing the mushrooms in hopes of selling them later. Once again, a difficulty where the player could actually keep the perks to see the actual fruits of their labors would be nice. 

Every night at the start of the night cycle, the player must drink from the well outside their home, or else die from...whatever sort of plague or disease is currently ravaging their body. This is an interesting feature, however it requires the player to remain soleley at their beginning house where the well is located. There are a number of other "friendly" NPCs around the map whom are most likely suffering from the same ill-effects as the player character, and yet you are the only one with a well outside of your home. It'd be cool to be able to set up shop at other homes with wells.

11885736.review:
Update:
And so, after four years of development, the game has finally left Early Access and it was well worth the wait.
The game is still as terrifying as it was during the development period, if not even more now, and its great we've gotten a survival horror game that's able to make you feel on edge constantly because of the weird and sudden noises you might hear while out in the woods or huddled up in one of the hideouts at night.
One very interesting thing to note is that the main character doesn't need to eat, drink nor sleep due to some "accident" he's had not long ago which has left him with a craving for the strange red mushrooms that he can "cook" into a substance, along with other objects which also can be turned into the same substance, which can grant him new abilities, however this also comes at the cost of adding negative traits that will make things tougher, like the very first negative mutation is that the darkness at night will become dangerous and you need to stay in the light.
As for the combat, its all about timing and watching the enemies' attack patterns, plus you're not able to attack enemies with your fists even as a last resort, at least not at the time of this writing, so you have to rely on whatever weapons you either find, craft at one of the workbenches or simply just try to outrun the monsters while dropping something to distract them.
I can without a doubt recommend this game to those who enjoy horror games with outstanding sound design along with those that like to uncover the mysteries within a game, of which there are plenty of here in Darkwood.

Full Release

This is true survival horror, and I highly recommend this title.

11758406.review:
Type of Game:

Top-down horror survival PDL with crafting elements

Version Played:

Early Access PC version through Steam

Similar Games:

Teleglitch, Don’t Starve, the Silent Hill series, and to a lesser degree Hotline Miami

The Good:

A truly intriguing storyline filled with mysteries around every corner. It feels like you’ve stepped into a Silent Hill storyline, but crafted by David Lynch.
This makes exploration a much more enjoyable experience as uncovering parts of the story really add depth to the game
The game is really difficult, which adds A LOT to the tension of each decision you make. The lack of resources and constant sense of dread creates an experience similar to playing Dark Souls, except just way scarier (quite a feat, I know).
Randomly generated maps help with the sense of disorientation each time you play and adds to the replayability of the title.
The crafting aspect to the game is very deep and intuitive. As I mentioned before, resources are limited, so finding a stockpile of items is a very rewarding experience.
Crafting also lends itself to the defense building that needs to occur every game night, which if you find yourself itemless during well… just make sure you have plenty of wood and nails.
The music and ambient noise is appropriately creepy and adds to the horror of playing.
Combat is easy to grasp and works very similarly to Hotline Miami, which can lead to some frantic combat scenarios.
The intentional lack of hand-holding in the beginning of the game can create a constant sense of discovery not unlike Don’t Starve.

The Bad:

As expected for an early access title, the game has bugs and glitches which can ruin the immersion at times. Though definitely not as bad as other early access titles.
One example of a bug was a loading problem, which caused some difficulty picking up where I left off when trying to access a saved game. This has since been addressed.
Another bug (as the dev team has referred to it as such in the forums) is the excruciatingly long initial world generation time. I had thought that the game had crashed the first time I played, though stuck around luckily due to the music still playing. This is something they are working on. 
Currently only Chapter One is available, which is bad only because I want more of this amazing game!

Can you play it while the children are awake?

No… Just no.

Did I make time to complete it?

I finished what was currently available, which was Chapter One.

Redlight or Greenlight?

This game is currently at a greenlight.

The content that is currently offered is well worth the asking price of $14.99. The experience is a horror game fan’s terrifying bliss. Darkwood has mysteries around every corner, frightening sounds you feel like you imagined, fearsome creatures that don’t relent, frenzied combat that leaves you breathless, and panicked defense building which all come together to create a phenomenal gaming experience. Knowing there is more to come is just icing on the cake.

A Quick Look at Those Games You Might Buy:
www.gamersglance.com

11732638.review:
You're huddled in the corner, with you bowler cap down and your trench coat pulled tight. The inky darnkness surrounds you as if it were a physical thing that you could reach out and touch. Its cold, sinister, and evil. The sound of your own heartbeat is the only comfort that presents itself. Everything is silent, until now. The sound of breaking glass is heard somewhere in you house, and the sound of something hitting the ground. The something is heavy, wet, and... alive...

Something is in your house.

As quietly as you can, you pull your crude weapon out of your backpack lying on the floor next to you. It's a lowley 2x4 board with nails protruding from the end. It won't last in a fight, but its better than your bare hands. You can hear the sound of moist shuffling feet and dripping moving throughout your house. You dare not make a sound, with the risk of the... thing... finding you. You clutch the pathetic weapon as if it were a priceless object, and stare at the door. The creature begins to grow louder and louder. You can hear it breathing, snapping, drooling, growling. It begins to walk past your door. You dare not breath, or even blink. The whole world seems to stand still, waiting, and watching. The creature is right outside. It goes silent. Your heart stops. You hear sniffing. You've never felt so scared in your life. You can hear it turning towards the door.

It knows your there. And its already bashing down the door.

Darkwood is an incredible game, even in alpha. It's the first game that has ever felt genuily scary for me. There is no *intentional jumpscares and no cheap scares either. It's all horrifying visuals and terrifying atmosphere. It's also incredibly challenging and fun. The game could still use some work, and is missing a lot of pieces to the puzzle, but i believe, that with the right tools, features, and people, Darkwood could be a game that would be remembered as one of the better survivial horrors..

11681555.review:
Darkwood é um jogo de survival horror, com a camêra vista de cima e com uma história macabra e muito estranha. Você tem que sobreviver, coletar itens, enfrentar monstros e o pior, na minha opinião, passar pela noite. A noite é muito escura e dá medo! Barulhos são feitos fora da sua safe house, indicando monstros, e a medida que passa os dias fica pior, fazendo o monstro a invadir sua safehouse, que provávelmente deve estar barricada. O jogo conta com skills que devem ser upadas com a seringa, que enche com cogumelos e algumas carnes!

A história segue diante de diálogos que fazem parte de conversas com npc's e notas, que falam sobre algo ou imagens. Você tem que explorar a ''floresta menos densa'' e a mais densa, que fazem parte do mapa, junto do subsolo. A ''floresta densa'' me dá muito medo, pois é mais escura que a menos, e ainda tem grande chances de aparecerem mais monstros!

Lembre-se Darkwood está em Alpha, portanto bug's podem ser encontrados, e mais coisas podem vir! A história já tem um final segundo os criadores. O jogo irá te prender na história, fazendo você querer avançar cada vez mais profundo!

Muito bom! 10/10

11680550.review:
je vient de débuté Darkwood, et aprés mes premieres heures de jeu, mes impressions est que c'est prenant, immersif, bien glauque (ça me rapelle diablo 2, dans la prison sous le monastaire de l'Act I mais encore pire :p), j'ai des frissons dans le dos^^, beaucoup de choix interactif avec l'environnement que ce soit pour ouvrir ou fermé une porte, ramassé du stuff ou des éléments de l'histoire du jeu. La prise en main est rapide, on comprend vite comment crafté et avec quoi et savoir comment utilisé ces objets de base grace au didactitiel au début qui est bien expliqué au rhyme de chacun, le cycle jour/nuit avance fur a mesure dans la mission didactitiel. Aprés la première nuit à Darkwood, un homme surnommé "Wolfman" raconte de ce qu'il m'est arrivé et ce qu'il se passe dans les environs, j'ai vu aprés qu'on pouvait troc avec lui, le troc dont la monnaie d'échange est la réputaion pour acheter ou vendre les items, il donne également 2-3 conseils de survie qui est interressant, le systeme de progression est vraiment sympa avec la cuisine, (ceux qui aimes les champignons vont etre content :D ) où on peut choisir des talents différents une fois que la seringue a atteint son maximun (on peut voir sa jauge de couleur bleu turquoise en haut a gauche en dessous de la barre d'endurance(gris)), beaucoup de combinaisons de compétence possible que si l'on veut rejouer son personnage on peut choisir une voie différente, les premiers ennemies dans la journée sont difficiles a éliminé au début mais on peut leur échappé en courant, les balades dans les arbres peuvent etre dangereux, baisse de vision et les arbres peuvent piqué et empoisonné (ils sont vivant^^, pas tous heureusement) qui peut etre soigné par un antidote ou pilules, le champ de vision est réaliste, prévoir une torche ou avoir une lampe de poche la nuit, difficile de voir dans la foret et les rencontre avec des animaux sauvages est plus élevé, voir des mutants pendant l'exploration en journée.
Un autre élement vital a la survie du héro ou survivant^^ est l'eau du puit qui se manifeste que la nuit seulement qui l'obligerait a revenir a la planque du début au crépuscule (en essayant de ne pas se perdre :D) sauf s'il y'a d'autre puits, ce qui serait plus pratique, dans le sens que tu doit amélioré tes défenses sur cette position en barricadant les portes et fenetres, posé des pieges pour survivre la nuit et priez dans un coin pour pas qu'un de ces monstres s'invite dans vore maison de fortune dans le noir le plus total :)

Points forts de la premiere mission : 

- bonne narration (peut etre en ajouté plus ?)
- Prise en main rapide grace au didactiel pour les bases de survie
- Immersif : bonne qualité du sons : bruit de pas, grognement, porte qui grince (on s'y croit vraiment :p) et de l'environnement ombres et lumière trés bien réussi (non, je ne sortirai pas blanc comme un linge a la fin de ma partie :) ).
- exploration, monde ouvert, interaction avec l'environnement.
- Générateur de monde (vraiment génial, chacun vit sa propre expérience du jeu dans l'exploration).

Points faibles :

- difficile de se repéré sur la minimap et de prendre des repères même avec certains éléments indiqué par un point noir sur la minimap pour aidé a s'orienté, une boussole serait la bienvenue (en UI ou en item) .
(- les PNJ n'ont pas de voix mais je peut comprendre, c'est une alpha, MathasGames me semble qualifié pour ça^^).

Pour la cuisine une bonne omelette de champignons avec les oeufs de la dame au poules avec des champignons ramassé fraichement dans la foret en espérant que ça aura pas le goût de pied de mutant :)

11680246.review:
Darkwood is a top-down-perspective survival thriller(?). The epilogue (which is absolutely brilliant) gives you some basic hints as to how combine items, interact with the environment, swing an axe and that is basically it. Then you wake up in a shabby old house with one wall missing, meet a mysterious wolf-man and head out to explore. 

And you die.

Then you wake up again, make a mental note not to piss off any dogs, and set out again. 

Then you die once more – another note made – and you already know it’s going to be one hell of a ride.  
Thing is, the game is rather difficult and at times can be truly challenging and unforgiving. However, If you die, you die because you made (a) mistake(s), because you were unprepared or just because you lacked experience (and I don’t mean leveling your character). It takes time to get the hang of it and actually start surviving for a change, but then again this learning process is damn rewarding  – no one is holding your hand, nobody tells you where to go and what to do. Thus, every little accomplishment feels good. Really good.  

Darkwood is all about exploration, survival and atmosphere. The world is a twisted, dream-like place (partially randomized) where you’re bound to get lost. There is a map,  yes, but your current location is not marked on it. You have to pay attention to landmarks, remember where you’re going and where you came from. Otherwise you won’t be able to make it home before nighttime. And, believe me, you don’t want to be out when the night comes. You want to barricade yourself at the (not-at-all) safe-house, set some traps, hide in a corner and hope to gods the monsters leave you be. And perhaps cry a little as you hear scratching, howling, barking and what not coming from the other side of the wall. If the monsters do get in and you find yourself poorly equipped, you’re dead. You feel surrounded and helpless, and yet ready to try your hardest to make your stand until morning when all the horrors disappear like a bad dream. Sometimes the nights can be soothingly calm, but you’ll keep sitting in that corner of yours all tense, anticipating the worst. Sometimes a banshee just walks around your hideout, opens doors and move pieces of furniture around, not doing much harm (unless you attack) and still scaring the living crap out of you. You never know what to expect and it makes the whole experience even better.
   
If you happen to survive the night, you’ll wander off again to replenish resources (which are scarce and don’t respawn), eventually venturing into darker, more dangerous parts of the forest. There are guns (some are difficult to find though) but don’t get trigger-happy as ammo is hard to obtain and expensive. You’ll be forced to go melee most of the time. And, don’t get me wrong, you’ll probably try to avoid fighting all together anyway. This is NOT a beat’em up kind of game. Dying is easy.

It is also NOT a horror game as such. The mood is heavy but don’t expect cheap jump scares. There might be some, as your cone of vision (another sweet idea) allows you to see only a bit of what’s in front of you and leaves you exposed to all sorts of dangers lurking in the darkness, but it is not scripted. If you get jump-scared, it’s because you were not careful enough. Most of the times. 

The game in its current version (1.3) offers only the prologue and the first chapter but it is a fairly long trip and holds great replayability value. Also, it might be the most polished and bug-free alpha game I have ever played and I have played quite a few. Give it a try and see for yourself.

11670649.review:
I recently moved into a new home about 2 weeks before the Darkwood alpha was released and I was not quite used to the sounds that my house or my cats would make at night yet.

On my first night in Darkwood I backed into a corner of a room and nervously clutched a wooden board with nails. Standing there, all I could do was shift my vison around the room in a vein attempt to spot the source of the noises which I could not identify. Luckily nothing broke in and I continued on, repeating another uneventfull but nervous night in a corner listening to the creaks of wood floors, the sound of a struggle ending with a dog's whimper, and a deep gurgling sound that seemed to be moving around my dilapidated sanctuary.

On my third night in game I had found a few bear traps and placed them around my hide out in the hopes of killing anything that would be foolish enough to ambush me. Lo and behold, something started to beat down my door and I sat there clutching my half broken board hoping it would be enough to protect me from whatever was coming to get me. Just as the last sliver of life was torn away from my feeble defenses one of my cats burst thru my door and jumped onto my shoulder. I cried out and knocked the cat to the floor who then bolted out of the room.

I sat there staring at the screen, still breathing heavily, while my groggy eyed wife slowly pushed open the door to my study to ask what had happened. I turned off my monitor, reasured her nothing was wrong, and followed her to bed. I then stared at the ceiling with my eyes darting around our darkened room at every unfamiliar noise.

10/10 - I will continue to lose many nights of sleep over this game. I advise you to lock your door before playing.

11624559.review: "What is this top down crap?" you ask yourself as you examine the store page. "It can't actually be scary." You're wrong. Very wrong. This game is one of the most immersive I have ever played. It brutally grabs you in the gut with its hellish claws and never intends on letting go until your sanity has snapped. 11619908.review:
This is gonna be a long one so I'm gonna summarize here. If you're looking for a perfect blend of sandbox and horror then this game will definitely tickle your fancy. I highly recommend it even if it is early access. Normally I hate early access. People throwing out unfinished games to the masses. This is the one exception. Don't hesitate in getting this now if you're interested. It's damn good and feels like a finished game.

[h1]Day one[/h1]
First day of the game I was terrified. I had no idea when night was coming. My inventory was full and I quickly realized my map doesn't show my exact position. I had to figure it out on my own using landmarks I've located. This was my first major mistake. I was lost. I could see the sun was beginning to set and I was still lost deep within the woods. I was so cocky. When I first booted the game I turned on permadeath thinking I could ace this game like any other horror or sandbox game I've played. None of them set the atmosphere quite like Darkwood did. Nothing frightened me more than seeing the sun come down. I began panicking, sprinting my way through the forest hoping for any sort of shelter. Of course I didn't find any. I did find the road however and with it, eventually my home. It was pitch dark outside and I made the huge mistake of leaving the generator on. I was so stupid. I assumed the gas I put in it would last longer or it'd just stop using fuel during the day. The typical gaming conventions I was used to wasn't present in this game. Not even the sight of my own home made me feel any relief. I'd made another horrible mistake. I hadn't had time to barricade the windows during the day. I shut myself in one of the rooms and pushed all manner of furniture in front of the doors and windows, hoping it'd keep whatever was out there away. I had no idea what I was up against. But I could hear them. I had run out of furniture to push against any openings. There was one window I had to keep open and for the rest of the night I stared at it from across the room. I spent the whole night, weapon raised, staring out that window terrified for my life.

[h1]Review[/h1]
I've watched this game in development for a while and I was pleasantly surprised to see a developer actually deliver an amazing game for early access. I had my doubts. I really wanted to get this game when it was finished so I could get the whole experience but I couldn't resist any longer. Boy was I impressed though. It felt like a complete game. Of course I bought it shortly after most of the bugs had been squashed so I didn't really get to see how buggy it may have been early on. They've already thrown out so many bug fixes in the short amount of time it's been released that I definitely have high hopes for its development. 
A lot of "survival horror" game developers just don't get what makes a horror game truly terrifying. I've seen countless of these horror games that rely solely on jump scares or just putting the character in a dark room with a flashlight. And what few games have that right kind of atmosphere have shitty game-play. Darkwood does this flawlessly. Not only is it in a terrifying setting, but it's also fun to play. The most important thing to any horror media (be it a movie, book or game) is setting the tone. You need the player to feel immersed in this atmosphere or they won't give a damn about the character's well-being. I was genuinely scared I wouldn't be able to make it home the first night. I had absolutely no idea what I was up against and I didn't want to know. All I knew is that it wanted me dead. I wasn't even sure if the dressers I pressed against the doors and windows would even protect me from them. Its that mystery that makes the game so effective at being scary. Not once did I feel like I was truly safe. Even as the sun came up. 
All in all this was definitely one of the scariest experiences I've had with a game. I highly recommend it to anyone with a taste for horror. Darkwood will forever be my measuring stick for judging what a true survival horror game should be.

11610180.review:
One of THE most atmospheric games I have ever played. Day five found me locked in my hideout, thinking I was safe, only to have a beast round the corner and rip out my throat. I lost everything, my skills, and my mutated items. 

This game is brutal and unforgiving. And I love it. 

Now there are a few things, seeing as it is an alpha. 

Sometimes, this game is TOO unforgiving. Dying means you do lose everything, without the chance to get it back. And because resources don't respawn, you're gimped for the rest of that section if you ever die in the middle of the night, making it increasingly harder to restock and regain your footing. You also take ALL ITEM DURABILITY DAMAGE which is mean on top of losing all of your skills. 

It needs a few balancing tweaks, but other than that, this game has major potential.

11608769.review:
Darkwood is by far the most interesting game I've played since Project Zomboid. It's creepy, thick atmosphere is only outmatched by it's simple but complex mechanics. With a different game world generated for each playthrough (and perma-death as an option for the true rogue player), terrifying creatures, barricading system, survivalist mechanics and it's eerie and very much fleshed out characters, this is definitely one of the true old-school hard and scary games out there.

You might not like this game if you are into constant firefights, being an OP character, or a lot of in game guidance.
This game tends to drop you right into it and you have to figure out the best way to survive for yourself.

10/10 and I NEVER give these ratings
