11551940.review:
[b] My review to Darkwood [/b]

So what makes Darkwood different from other games that strive to unsettle you? Well, for starters, Darkwood doesn’t hinge on jump-inducing surprise-scares for its sense of tension (though it promises its fair share of these moments, anyways). Instead, Darkwood places you in a procedurally generated forest in a deeply twisted perversion of Soviet Russia. From there, the game’s dismal lighting, grotesque ambiance, and overall eerie atmosphere create the horror themselves.

darkwood horror survival game gameplayIn other words, Darkwood doesn’t rely on cheap scare tactics and bursts of adrenaline to generate its terror. Darkwood’s brand of fear is the type that starts as a knot of unease in your stomach, a knot that grows tighter with each door you push slowly open, with every backwards glance and each spectral groan that floats out of the fog. Darkwood doesn’t try to scare you in the traditional Western sense – it tricks you into scaring yourself.

Of course, we can’t talk about innovation in the genre without looking into the very thing that made the game stand out to me in the first place – its choice of perspective. Where most horror games seek to attach you to the protagonist by making you look through their eyes, Darkwood is the embodiment of detachment. You look down on your character from above, your line of sight limited to the swath of your flashlight beam.

This means that behind you, inside buildings, anywhere that your light can’t reach, is blanketed in darkness. Nightmarish things lurk outside the light, things that you will be forced to encounter as you drift through the corrupted forest. Whether or not you survive these brushes with the frightful unknown is entirely up to you.

[b] What Else? [/b]

In addition to the top-down view, Darkwood introduces some more interesting ideas. Its design has been inspired by rogue-like, adventure, and role-playing games alike, giving it a unique and nuanced feel that it seems only indie games can achieve these days.

Its diverse inspirations give Darkwood a well-rounded approach to the genre, providing something enticing for every flavor of gamer. Its RPG roots have inspired the developers to include a skill-tree to the game, allowing character diversification and specialization. The looting and crafting systems are reminiscent of many survival games, from Minecraft to Fortnite, but are presented in their own uniquely gritty ways.

[b] My Rating [/b]

8/10

11549606.review:
This may update as time goes on.

1st impressions (way before this came to steam); it looked brilliant. First time into the game before literally moving about in the tutorial; incredible. I had honestly never been so terrified in a 2D horror game like this in a long time. It is old school horror, something I praise so much to see and you absolutely feel frozen fromthe sounds, atmosphere and the unknown this game offers (I literally was pulling my hair during my first night, screaming "what the hell are those sounds, is it coming, please don't let it get me!") 

Playing into the game; the tutorial helps you a lot with the rope and it's straightforward. It even allows some freedom on experimenting before continuing (had fun testing out some items before the tutorial ended). First time playing, you have the freedom to follow the story (which I have to say is very interesting and I am curious just to go through it completely) and/or survive as long as possible in the Darkwood. The more you play, the more you learn how to adapt to survive. That hasn't frustrated me at all and with each death I endure by whatever is roaming the forest, I come back wanting to do better in survival. And mind you, this is still an early access game and there is a lot more I believe I'll be learning from this game. 

Darkwood, hands down, is by far for me, the best survival horror game I've ever played. If that alone isn't enough, here is a list of what happened to me and what's cool to me:

* The characters you meet, are brilliantly designed and creepily cool! Every one I've met so far, I really like them! Especially the guy who you can give parts to (exhaust plug, wheel, etc)! :D
* I tossed a flare onto some posionous, flammable vines, caught on fire by it, bandaged myself quickly to dull the burn effect, went in to jump in my seat to see a rabid dog inside the very room the vines were protecting. BEAT IT TO DEATH in a panicked state.
* One night, I thought I heard someone was WALKING INSIDE MY SAFEHOUSE. Next morning, I look around to find my windows still barricaded and nobody around. I KID YOU NOT!
* Another night, some BIRD SHADOW CREATURE appeared right in front of me. I screamed so hard in my seat and whacked it with my nailed plank to see it reduced to ashes. Since then I have been ramming my brain how it got inside.
* Longest time: 5 days. Had some ravenous antlion thing coming through my barricaded window and just waiting in front of me, taunting me first before the kill. I just begged it to get it over with it!

10/10. Death galore. :D

11528575.review:
This game is scary! It has a dark atmosphere and is terrifying when you encounter an enemy. Playing it in the dark with the sound makes this game just horrifying. I had to take breaks from it because of the suspense. It definitely gives you an old style horror game feel with some modern mechanics. You can craft but the system is not as intuitive as it has been planned to be (they plan to make it much more fun and interesting to where you can experiment. It is randomly generated (except for the main house). The top down view does not detract from the horror. In fact it adds to it! the game play feels solid but the combat does have a little of a learning curve. My bigest and probably only complaint besides a lack of loot variety (<-- I like lots of different items) is that every night you have to drink from a well at your hideout. I think this restricts the game and makes exploring dangerous in the wrong ways. I want to be able to barricade myself in any old place i find during the night. Also be warned, permadeath makes the game very hard. you WILL die.

Overall, I give this game an 8.5/10 just because of the current lack of items and the restriction of the well. But that is just for the current version. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes horror games or anyone wanting to be scared during the middle of night.

11528572.review:
C'est dans le noir, le casque vissé sur la tête que j'affronte pour la première fois le monde malsain de Darkwood. 

Premières impressions : 

- Sombre, oppressant, dérangeant, terrifiant. 
Le jeu fait réellement peur et ne s'en cache pas un seul instant. Chaque coin et recoin de la forêt peut être source de dangers mais également de surprises... 

- L'envie d'en découvrir plus sur ce monde qui ne nous laisse pas de temps mort. Un cycle jour/nuit très intéressant, 2 gameplay complètement différents. 

- Un jeu soigné autant au niveau du chara design que de la map elle même, on oubliera rapidement les pixels un peu baveux. 

- Una BO bien sympa et crispante, je me suis surpris à rester planté dans le sol après plusieurs bruits plus que suspects. 

- Des effets de lumières et d'ombres bien gérés. La vue a beau être différentes d'un FPS ou TPS, la surprise est très présente et il est plus que facile de sursauter en détournant le regard de quelques centimètres apreès quelques mouvements sur l'écran.

En bref, ce jeu est un must have pour tout fan de survival, dans la droite lignée d'un bon Silent Hill et d'un Evil Dead. Vous ne serez vraiment pas déçus du voyage !
En souhaitant courage à tout ceux qui se lanceront dans l'aventure, vous en aurez plus que besoin, croyez moi...

11528108.review:
Darkwood is probably the favorite game I own, I love the atmosphere, the constant tension, having to check behind yourself constantly, the enemies, how unforgiving the game is, and pretty much every part of the gameplay. Darkwood is also one of the single most complete early access games I have ever played. The gameplay is stellar, I love the controls, and the atmosphere of the entire game. It suffers at the moment from small glitches, and slight balancing issues, however these will presumably be fixed in future updats, and you are so quickly wrapped up in the game that you forget about the minor issues. 

Overall I would strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys survival games and great atmospheric gameplay.

11526140.review: Good game, the scares are pretty good and the mysterious houses always get me exicited. However its pretty hard to find items before dark and getting poisoned happens way to often to the point where it just gets annoying. This game reminds me of The Forest but in third person, I just hope theres more objectives than just surviving in the woods for constant days

11525961.review:
I've been waiting to play this game the moment I watched the first trailers when it was posted on Greenlight, and while I am disappointed that it's in Early Access now, I am happy to say that it's well worth the money even to play the alpha. 

The atmosphere is thick and tense, aided by detailed graphics and terrifying sound design, the interface is smooth and intuitive, and the setting and characters are both unnerving and interesting to the point of keeping you coming back for hours.

The only complaints I have with this game as of now is that there are at least two progression-blocking bugs I've come across, as well as some dodgy optimization issues dealing with level generation and fps, but I understand that Early Access leaves some room for improvement, and I'm actually pleasantly surprised that the game is as polished as it is currently.

11524149.review:
2014/08/13 - 최종 수정 날자

현재 다크우드를 좀더 오랫동안 해보면서 다시 판단해봤습니다

- 장점들

- 음울한 배경과 그에 어우러진 일러스트

- 탑뷰의 플레이 방식 : 보통 탑뷰의 공포게임은 그다지 공포감이 느끼기 힘듭니다. 하지만 시야각의 제한을 두고 음울하고 어두운 배경과 함께 어우러져 공포감을 자아내며,  보이지 않는곳에서 들려오는 소리가 플레이어를 긴장시킵니다(사운드 후술)

- 사람을 아주 크게 긴장시키는 사운드 : 사운드가 사람을 아주 놀라게 만듭니다. 아주 긴장한 상태에서 뭔가 밟는 소리 하나에 놀라기도 하고 여러 생물이 내는 소리에 긴장하기도 합니다, 하지만 무섭다고 또 끄면 이 사운드가 게임 플레이에 크게 영향을 끼치기때문에 사운드를 끌수도 없게 만들어 긴장감을 붙잡아두는 좋은 요소로 생각됩니다. 이 요소 또한 탑뷰 플레이 방식임에도 불구하고 공포감에 일조합니다

- 전략적으로 행동해야함 : 단순히 적을 때려잡기만 하는것이 아니라 어딘가에 숨던지, 장롱을 옮겨 문을 막음으로써 최대한 시간을 벌고 도망을 가던지 등 단순히 적을 때려 눕히거나 잘 도망가기만 하면 되는게 아닙니다. 말그대로 '살아남기 위한 모든 방법'을 써먹을수 있게끔 되어있습니다.

- 아이템들간의 상호작용과 전술적 행동 : 여러 아이템을 잘 쓸수있습니다. 덫을 쓴다고 그냥 말그대로 덫으로만 쓰는게 아닌 집을 방어할때 바리게이트를 설치함으로써 시간을 벌고, 덫을 설치할 시간을 벌고 거기에 추가적으로 화염병을 쓰거나, 기름을 부어 불을붙일수 있습니다, 단순히 조합 아이템의 용도가 아니라 좀더 어떻게 쓸수있을지, 창의적으로 쓸수있게 잘 만들었다 생각됩니다

- 스토리 텔링 방식 : 다크우드엔 분명히 스토리가 존재합니다. 하지만 너무 스토리에 얽매이지 않게 스토리를 이어가게끔 만드는 아이템들이 존재합니다. 플레이어는 스토리와 별개로 게임을 즐길수도 있고 자연스럽게 스토리 아이템을 얻을수 있게되서(그렇지 않을지도 모르지만), 어느정도 스토리를 억지로 진행하려는 그런 고생을 하지 않아도 됩니다

이러한 장점들이 있고 특히 사운드에 대해서 크게 호평을 해주고싶은 바입니다
다만, 아직 알파라 그런지 약간 여기저기에 문제와 게임의 단점이 보입니다

- 초보자에 대한 툴팁이 심각하게 부족 : 이점의 경우 어느정도 튜토리얼이 설명을 기초적인건 설명을 해주지만 말그대로 '조작법'과 간단한 조합법만 알려주고 끝입니다, 그리고 게임을 하다보면 처음 하신분들 대부분이 아마 첫날밤 한번 게임오버(갈증으로 인한)을 겪게 될겁니다, 그리고 또 버섯같은걸 실수로 건드려 중독되거나 그런걸 한번식 겪으셧을겁니다

- 근접 전투가 너무 심할정도로 힘듬 : 이점또한 문제입니다. 물론 생존 게임이니만큼 근접으로 무쌍을 찍으면 안되겠지만 근접전투가 난이도가 제법 있습니다, 게다가 그마저도 근접무기가 잘 나오는것도 
그냥 마우스 클릭하면 휘두르는게 아니라 힘을 모으고 , 다시 클릭해서 휘두르는 방식입니다, 문제는 이걸 한다해도 맞추기가 힘듭니다. 대부분 한대 먼저 맞고 그다음 휘두르게 되는데 한대 맞으면 맞고 밀려나서 헛휘두르게 되고 또 한대 맞고 헛휘두르고 다시 반복되다보면 스태미나가 다되서 휘두르지도 못하고 맞아죽지요, 이점에 대해서 약간의 조정이 필요할것 같습니다

- 버그 현상 : 아직은 알파버젼이라 그런지 여기저기서 버그의 흔적이 보입니다. 특히 변이 2,3단계때 꾸게되는 악몽에서 가끔 버그가 일어납니다.

(업데이트로 해결된 단점)

- 짧은 하루 : 활동 가능 시각을 오전 3시에서 오후 10시로 조정(시계 아이템이 있으면 정밀한 시간을 알수있습니다)

- 너무 희소한 자원 : 좀더 초반을 견디기 쉽게 집 주변에 자원이 좀더 스폰되게 변경, 그리고 자원을 '반드시'구할수 있는곳이 있습니다.(표트랙의 집, 치킨 레이디's 하우스, 빈 집, 돼지 농장)


그외 아이템 정보나 간략한 팁이 필요하면 위키
(http://mirror.enha.kr/wiki/%EB%8B%A4%ED%81%AC%EC%9A%B0%EB%93%9C) - 지속적으로 정보가 추가되고 있습니다

11521939.review:
Darkwood - это инди survival horror с видом сверху. Здесь нас не собираются пугать скримерами. Нет, это сделает мрачная атмосфера. Отличное звуковое сопровождение заставит вас вздрагивать от собственных шагов, скрипа половиц, хруста ветки. Особенно, когда выше перечисленное слышится у вас за спиной, заставляя озираться по сторонам. Да, кстати, как в и реальной жизни у вас нет глаз на затылке, так и герой может видеть только то, куда повернута его голова. Причем, здесь это выполнено весьма интересно. Пока вы не посмотрите куда-нибудь вы не сможете увидеть некоторых деталей. Ну, например, вы знаете что у вас слева поваленное дерево, но пока вы не посмотрите налево, то не увидите что там может стоять какая-нибудь тварь. Разве что услышать.
Окружение тоже заставит вас чувстовать себя не уютно. Вы только представьте себе: мрачный лес, из которого нет выхода; разрушенные здания и гниющие трупы, бродящее по округе зверье. И темнота ночи, да такая что не видно ни зги. 
А то, что выползет ночью на охоту уж точно заставит вас вжаться в угол убежища и молиться.
Но вы же не хотите умирать? Хех, я так и думал. В игре имеется система крафта, чтобы жить вам стало чуточку проще в этом мрачном и жестоком мире. Также собирая кое-что, вы можете состряпать себе дозу какой-то дряни и прокачать себе навык. Правда, с каждой дозой этого кое-чего нужно все больше и больше, поэтому не следует расслабляться. Ведь умирая вы будете пробуждаться в убежище(конечно если вы не включили Permadeath, тогда это будет конец игры) и обнаружите что навыков нет. Это хорошая причина не умирать.
Что еще нужно мне сказать, что покупка этой игры хорошая идея? Хм... Знаю. Она еще находится в раннем доступе(02.08.2014-дата написания данного обзора), поэтому нас ждет еще много контента(надеюсь). Также мир здесь генерируется каждый раз по новому.
Вывод из всей этой писанины? Вот он: купив сей продукт, я не жалею потраченных денег. Получил то, что ожидал. Страх. Мрачную атмосферу. Вызов моему скиллу геймера. И я его принял.
И по некой традиции, отрывок из моего личного дневника:
[i]Day 3[/i]
Я завершаю последние приготовления к ночи. Уже расставлены медвежьи капканы, раскиданы по ним приманки. Надеюсь, что утром что-нибудь в них найду. Подошел к колодцу. Вгляделся в окружающий меня лес в лучах заката. Это можно было бы назвать романтичным, если бы я не знал, что под тенью деревьев уже начали собираться твари, которые как-только солнце уйдет за горизонт окончательно, пойдут к моему убежищу.
Ночь наступила.
Я быстро выпил воду из колодца, даже выудил из ведра пару грибов, и, запрыгнув через окно в дом, отправился к своему углу. Подвинув поближе к себе комод и лампу, я стал выжидать. И они не заставили себя ждать. Через несколько мгновений раздал собачий лай, но быстро затих. Вдруг рядом скрипнула половица. Я чертыхнулся и покрепче сжал палку с гвоздями, единственное оружие, которое у меня было. Дом заполнили шорохи. Да к тому же началась гроза. Вот кто-то( или что-то) подвинуло лампу в соседней комнате. Щелчок в другой. Капкан сработал. "Отлично, осталось дождаться утра" - подумалось мне, как вдруг... комод слева от меня слегка пошевелился. Я сглотнул. Но комод больше не двигался. И через несколько минут взошло солнце.
Praise the Sun.
[i]Day 4[/i]
Аккуратно выползая из своего угла, осмотрелся. Никого. Вздохнул с облегчением и пошел проверить капканы. Так, 2 не сработали и в 1 какой-то хлам. Не то что я ожидал. А ведь приманку всю съели. Ух, гады! Подойдя к столу и, используя грибы, состряпал себе дозу. "Мы еще посмотрим, кто кого" - сказал я, и ввел себе изготовленный препарат.
...
P.S. Тем кто дочитал до конца - спасибо и низкий поклон.

11509032.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BurJqrbU-lw

First off, I was apprehensive purchasing this game in Early Access; however, I am not disappointed in the slightest. This game has a lot of content for being just recently greenlit. It's very hard, which provides the challenge that I love. It includes the ever growing genre of survival, where you have to collect and craft items in order to continue. 11507438.review:
[b]Darkwood[/b] — это survival-horror, где действия происходит во времена «социалистического содружества». Скорее всего где-то в Польше.

Чем примечательна игра? Мощнейшим сюрреалистичным сеттингом (чего стоят одни только персонажи, с которыми приходится иметь дело) и какой-то [i]болезненно-мрачной[/i] атмосферой. [strike]А ещё тем, что здесь можно варить дозы из грибов и употреблять их внутривенно.[/strike] В этом неприветливом мире придется выживать, днём скитаясь в поисках полезных предметов и оружия, а ночью, включив генератор, забаррикадировавшись в небольшой освещенной комнате, держа топор на изготовке, ждать пока к тебе наведаются «местные жители» твоего колодца.

Не смотря на то, что это лишь ранний доступ контента здесь предостаточно. Для любителей хорроров это отличная находка.

11506843.review:
О господи ! Я даже не помню когда я в последний раз видел такую шедевральную игру ! 
 Отличная смесь хоррора и сюрвайвола ! Музыка соответствует ее непревзайденной атмосфере ! Да что уж говорить о атмосфере , если я когда в первый раз зашел в игру не успев пройти по лесу , услыша хруст... ЭТОЙ ДОЛБАНОЙ ПАЛОЧКИ !!!!!!!!!!!! Да да да ОДНА ПАЛОЧКА !! А имоций полные штаны! Да же не хочу рассказывать о моей первой встрече с свиноматкой ! 
 Ха ха ха ... да это она это - "DARKWOOD" !

11506718.review:
I really want to enjoy this game, but I can't. 

It is very atmospheric and does a really good job making you feel creeped out.  The character designs are so bizarre and disturbing; they fit perfectly with what this game is trying to accomplish. The mysterious and fragmented storyline will make you immersed in the Darkwood world. Exploration is extremely exciting because you never know what you will find and the constant looming threat of The Thirst and the creatures of the night will always make you feel rushed

Where this game fails is the combat. Weapons are not easy to find and tend to break too quickly. You will more than likely be forced to craft your own weapons which will consistently deplete your resources, but you need these same resources to build barricades to protect yourself at night because fighting during night is near impossible. When you do manage to craft a weapon, good luck trying to use it. Your attacks have to be extremely accurate in order to hit anything. Here is how most combat situations will go for you: You aim your attack. The enemy jumps at you, attacks you, and jumps back in half a second. You swing your weapon and miss. The enemy jumps back in, attacks you, jumps back out before you can even aim your next attack. Before you know it, you are dead and could not even land a single hit with your useless weapon.

This game seems to have so much potential, and I am excited to see where this game will go in the future, but the combat feels so broken, it isn't worth playing at the moment. I'm tired of being killed by the first enemy I encounter every time because the broken combat system doesn't give me any chance to protect myself.

11505942.review: 창문 부수고 있는 이형 크리쳐들의 소리에 심장이 쫄깃 ....  현제도 재미나지만 앞으로가 더욱 기대되는 수작 +_+

11504575.review:
Darkwood is a little rough around the edges, but it’s still in alpha stage and that just adds to the overall charm for me. It is a game deep in atmosphere and tension and has a fantastic visual appeal and design, one that takes its influences and plays them well. Acid Wizard Studio are a team that have taken Russian fiction and folklore, along with surrealism, to make a deeply evocative title that not only met my expectations but rose above them and offered me plenty of surprises. But to tell you the surprises would spoil the experience and, after all, the forest is waiting…

Find the full review over at [url=http://1001-up.com/2014/08/01/close-up-darkwood/] 1001-up.com [/url]

11504545.review:
My hands were cold and clammy as I gulped silently. My watch starterd beeping. 12:00 it said, midnight. The tv screen was glaring at me for some time with the only vivid colours I can remember. My heart started to race as I was a few minutes away from my home base. I thought to myself that right now would be the best idea to trod back. Nightfall emergers and my breath becomes a bit more shorter than the other breath. I can't contain myself, I'm very anxious about this event. I doubt I'll even make it through. 

The well has prompted me to drink from it, I tell myself, close the curtains and put some headphones on, it'll be fun. I did as what my head told me to do. It begun, I cornered myself on one end of the room with all beartraps hanging about. I feel nervous at the sight of these things as they might turn against me at one point and time. The growling begun. My heart was pacing faster, I mean, what could go wrong right? Well the barricaded door north of me corrected that sentence as something is chomping it's way through my doors. "BANG BANG BANG" It went.

The growling was louder than before. I can't help but to hold my breathe as the events unfolded in front of me. I decided to position myself as far away as possible from the door, but guess what? It's not over. Just south of me the door started to get attacked. It felt weird, I was feeling neither fear nor anxiety. The mix of horrible emotions was too difficult for me to handle. "BANG!" The door on the north gave way, gave way to something so terrible words cannot explain. But alas, the bear traps teeth GRISLED the thing. By the grace of god, I cleaved the infernal being in half with my axe, surprisingly with one blow it faltered, embracing the cold planks which I stood in. As the southern door broke, I see a faint light fill my room. It was daybreak. 

Waking up knowing tomorrow is going to be a more horrible day, I start my daily cycle. I'll push through this.

11500171.review:
The game is fairly simple, and very interesting, reminiscent of old flash games, but much more polished even for an alpha. While some have complained about the game not giving you any sort of direction or instruction, I find that to be the farthest thing from the truth. The game tells you exactly where to go. Loot is abundant, objectives are clear, and enemies are not too many but not too few (until night). The game is definitely worth a play, and as it sees updates, it looks like it can only get better. The game does present some major issues so far, however. 

You cannot escape dogs. They are too fast. Either you fight them or you die, or avoid them if you have the skill. Fighting them can prove difficult early on as it may be easy to make nail boards, but those nails and boards are also important for barricading your home's windows, which keeps you safer longer and reduces line of sight, keeping you hidden easier. It would make a lot more sense if we were at least able to use our fists. If any of us were to be attacked by a dog, I feel like we'd fight back. Most of the enemies are extremely tough as well. Natives have obscene reach that is very hard to counter. Best to just find a gun, which can take some time. You're best taking on enemies (if you really have to fight) one at a time, as the majority of the enemies are more than twice as fast as you, have superior reach, and an infinite amount of stamina, while you can only sprint and swing for so long before they're chewing your heels off.  Most natives can, however, be outrun. Stamina conservation is key.

Speaking of fighting back, it cannot be done at night, plain and simple. You can barricade everything in your house, everything, and sit quietly with the lights off, not making a sound. Eventually, a big baddy is gonna knock down your doors/barricades, let a pack of wolves in, and eat you for a midnight snack, as if it knew you were there the whole time. Alternatively, you can use what precious fuel you find to fuel your generator, to keep your lights on. While this offers amazing lighting that rivals even daytime light, it only makes it easier to watch yourself get eaten by the mob of enemies. While I understand the game is meant to make you feel unsafe, alone, and scared, it's very frustrating when fighting back is so hard.

Aside from these issues, I can't think of anything else that's wrong with this game. Maybe the economy needs some balancing, or perhaps combat needs to be tweaked, reworked a little even, but otherwise the game at its best moments is fun and genuinely challenging. The atmosphere is terrifying, which is difficult to achieve with a top down game. 

Play it, help further development.

11483114.review:
Пиксельный инди-хоррор. Сейчас это звучит как диагноз, как приговор, безапелляционно заталкивающий игру в специально предназначенную нишу. Упрощенная графика, большой акцент на звуки и атмосферу, скупой, но интригующий нарратив - новые произведения по этим лекалам выходят едва ли не ежемесячно. Darkwood полностью выдерживает недавно появившиеся каноны и прибавляет к ним богатое наследие survival horror прошлых десятилетий.
Выживание в темном лесу, баррикады и заколоченные окна, фонарик и радио, два слоя реальности, сбор записок, крафт и прокачка героя, квесты с вовлечением искаженных гостей (или хозяев?), охота, загадки, выборы, надвигающееся сумасшествие - узнаваемых компонентов насыпано с избытком. И они работают. Все они работают. 

Игра с непревзойденным коварством скрывает свой потенциал, давая в прологе лишь немножко походить по карте, создать пару вещей и отбиться от одного противника. Истинные масштабы становятся ясны позже - когда игрок откроет журнал и увидит, сколько же там предусмотрено вкладок, когда начнет собирать ресурсы и знакомиться с миром. Честно слово, ощущение такое, будто в баночке из-под кофе совершенно неожиданно обнаружилась дверца, ведущая в битком набитый холодильник.
Ладно. Нужно выбраться из этого проклятого леса. Ключ уже был в руках, да только какой-то пропитый безумец успел его забрать, немало попортив здоровье. Как дьявольски жаль, что пойти напролом не получится: лимит удачи давно исчерпан. Что же, для начала неплохо бы построить колодец, собрать доски и гвозди, вооружиться светом и нехитрой дубинкой, а заодно и совершить пару сделок с волкоголовым торговцем. 
Он называет меня Мясом. Спасибо, что с большой буквы?..

Проект находится на стадии доделки и полировки. Контента будет еще больше (хотя, казалось бы, куда уже), в полную силу заиграют последствия принятых решений, а ужас обещает выйти на новый виток. Не то чтобы Darkwood был действительно панически страшен; со скорбью приходится признать, что 3D-игры в этом аспекте даруют куда большую степень погружения.
Но темная ночь, хорошие наушники и готовность довериться сеттингу творят чудеса. За часами игры стираются из памяти и мелкие баги, и не всегда интуитивная модель применения предметов, и спорного удобства навигация по карте. Когда под ногой в очередной раз хрустнет ветка, а где-то за спиной алчно взвоет рогатый люд, пиксели отойдут далеко на второй план.
Что же, этот проект уютно устроился в своей нише, заграбастав в жадные лапы все, что жанр вообще когда-либо мог предложить. Если придирчиво подходите к пополнению коллекции, лучше погрузиться в один цельный, филигранно выписанный Darkwood, чем в десяток любых других одноидейных инди-хорроров.

11480884.review:
Где-то здесь умерло множество людей и животных.
Кажется, что можно различить запах гниения, смешавшийся с запахами старой листвы, мокрого дерева, пыльных, заброшенных комнат. Его чуят странные, мутирующие существа, живущие в этом мире. Им питаются огромные, уродливые грибы, растущие в темных углах. Особенно силен он ночью, пробуждая жажду, заставляя мучительно страдать оказавшихся слишком далеко от спасительного колодца.  

Игра божественна и гениальна, игра наполнена жутчайшими и атмосферными локациями, игра в раннем доступе и полна багов и проблем с загрузкой сохранений, недовольные игрой должны сдохнуть, сгнить, непохороненные, забытые.

Потратьте десять баксов на это великолепие. Это же совсем немного, все равно вы проебете их на пиво и фисташки, на мороженное, на поездку на такси, на шмотки в дотке, на какую-нибудь раскрученную говноигру с миллионным маркетинговым бюджетом.  А разработчики потратят их на то, чтобы доделать свой шедевр.

11471240.review:
Let me draw a scenario here, based on the experience I've had.


It's the tenth day surviving in this scary, haunting world. Monsters are everywhere, and gathering firewood becomes a frightening task. By now, you'd suspect I'm getting used to nightfall. This day I'm more prepared than any other. I've found a fireaxe on the floor of a crazed pig lady's house, and all I had to do is kill her to keep it. In this world, I'm growing used to not have sympathy for anything. In her house, I loot a bear trap still in good condition, some empty bottles, and mushrooms growing in the corners. I know by now that it's more useful to leave broken bottles on the floor as traps than thinking of carrying water. With a few belongings, I head back to my home, where the story requires me to drink from a fountain before nighttime if I am to survive.

I begin preparing for the eventual nightfall. I had half a gasoline jug left, and I pour it into my generator, only for the comfort of light and electricity during the night. As for defense, I keep a room fully barricaded to keep myself safe. There are three windows, and a doorway to the rest of the house. All the windows I have covered in wooden planks, but the door I leave open, if I need to make an escape. To keep the doorway defended, I dragged over a filing cabinet from another room and placed it in front of the doorway. In front of two of the windows, I have other things blocking the way along with the wooden barricade; that being a stool and a safe. Not the best at blocking the way, but it's all I have. I scatter broken glass in front of two windows, and the bear trap on the third.

Dusk is now turning the world red, and I begin the final steps of preparing for the night. I turn on the generator and the lamps inside all switch on. As of now I'm still uncertain if light attracts the monsters or not, but I feel safer if I have a lamp with me. The night comes, and the well water level has risen far enough for me to take a drink. As soon as I drink, I run through the now dark house and bunker myself in the room. I push the cabinet in front door, turn on the lamp, and begin to wait in the corner. 

At first, the night is quiet. I believe that this may be a safe night, and no curious monsters will want to come for me, but that soon changes. I can hear creaking coming from the hallway, and then, a knock on the door. It starts to bang, the whole room shaking, and I run as fast as I can to push against the other side of the cabinet and begin to push. Wood starts to splinter off from the door, again and again, until the door bursts open. The cabinet is still in the way. It begins to push as I push, me trying to keep it steady. Then I start to hear another windows barricade getting attacked as well. I lose control of the cabinet, and it begins to slide sideways, as I push too hard on one side and it pushes on the other. It's now in the room. I back up, turning towards the bear trap in hopes to get it caught. Then I see it, a humanoid beast split down the center, from the head to its belly, filled with blood and teeth. It's the first night that I see these types, and my strategy for them has to be learned on the spot. I raise my axe and get a direct hit. Then another hit, but this time it knicks me too. I step back, and as it leaps to me, it falls into the bear trap and gets itself killed. I didn't feel safe just yet, as the crashing from the window was over, and as I looked to the side of the room, all I could see was a broken, open window, and my piles of glass, now filled with blood, with no dead monster. It jumps me from the side, taking out half of my health. As I turn around to fight it, there turns out to be not one, but two humanoid split beasts, too much for me. By now, my heart is pounding out of my chest. I run out the door, trying to shut doors that I can, some sucessful, some not. Outside is pitch black, thundering and raining, and hopelessly I try to reach the shack with the generator. 

I manage to shut the door behind me. I'm bleeding out, and I left all my bandages in the room. The generator turns off. A monster hiding in the room kills me from behind. 

I wake up.

Day 11 begins.




Every single day of this game is a thrilling nightmare. From exploring and trying to survive, you're always on the edge of your seat, worrying just how you're going to get killed this day, and how far can you push along the so far intriguing story. It's the first early access game that I can truly reccommend, and it is totally worth buying today.

11464842.review:
Darkwood is a top down survival game that plays like an old school GTA or Hotline Miami ableit much slower. You are a greasy hobo living in a shack and your goal is to navigate a randomly generated verdant plot of land and eventually escape it. 

The games prologue is a short tutorial but frankly it doesnt do a good job of preparing you for the game. Many mechanics such as cooking, leveling up and using perks is not explained.  

Visually the game is simple and draws alot of inspiration from Slender and Silent Hill for tis spooky atmosphear which it pulls off pretty well. 

The sound minimal however it effectively punctuates the highs and lows of the game. The sound effect are really well done and go a long way to enhance the atmosphere. 

As nice as it all sound the game is still an alpha and after playing for 11 hours it still needs a long way to go before being anywhere close to enjoyable. 
While the ideas are solid the game suffers from quite a few game game breaking bugs. Crashes and black screens are common and so are various glitches which you should familirise yourself with if you intent of getting anywhere in this game. 

The odds are stacked heavily against you and dying is a common and costly occurence. You are defeceless when unarmed and unless you restarded the game a few times it will a be a while before you get your first weapon.  Sadly even then your chances of remaining unscathed are pretty slim. Most enemies have either a longer reach a lunge or plain old stunlock though a flurry or blows so getting to know your enemies is important and in most cases you cant take on more than one baddy at a time. 
Your weapons seem to be made of styrophoam since most of them break after every fight and rapairs or resupplies are very costly. Despite te starting vendor selling ammo for various firearms I have yet to see most of them. I have only used the double barrel shotty and the pellet gun both of which were jaringly inferior to the axe. 
If you are getting the jist that this game is hard you have heard nothing yet. The game uses a day and night cycle ( aprox 15/9 irl min) During the days you forrage and complete quests and during the night you fend off baddies enmasse. 
Problem is if you play the game as intended you wont last more than 2 days so you have resort to an exploit of hiding in a corner under total darkness in oder to skip the nighttime assaults.    

Exploring during the day is equaly agonising because of your characters speed and stamina you barely have enough time to explore one location before heading back to your shack. Sprinting all the time is also unadvisable for the woods are densely populated by bear traps and poisonus fungi ( which you need ot harvest to level up) and if you want to venture deeper into the woods you are required to have a light source of a kind. Issue is some of the most uggliest baddies and lot interesting quest set pieces are located in the deeper woods. This leaves you spirinting though the woods blind triping over traps or takign and slow and takign a beating from a pack of hungry mosnters. 

All in all after 11 hours the end is nowhere near in sight and I barely have any progress on my first quest. Before commiting yourself finnacialyl to this game the needsto be a lot of bug fixing and rebalancing done. I also urge the devs to do away with the random world generation since it add nothing to the game but frustration. 

Verdict: wait for it to get better. Hopefully this will grow into a nice gem

11455759.review:
Very Creepy and Atmosphereic. Hard as hell though, the only weapon you'll have most of the time playing being the infamous plank with nails, while having to face monsters that can two hit kill you. Only complaints I have with the game: weapons are too hard to find along with sources of illumination.

BUT hell man this is an AWESOME game, totally worth the money for me right now. Ive had plenty of scary moments, one of which I will share with you now...

Night of the 2nd day. Doing pretty good. Got myself a alcohol bandage, a savage's twig, plenty of nails and boards, and some gasoline for the generator of the safehouse. I had just finished barricading the last window of the house when I see the well activate, telling me that night has offically begun. I quickly run outside via the side door and take a drink, then go back inside and barricade the door with my last remaining nails. I stand back to admire my haniwork, but my bright mood is cut short by the blabbering of a savage approaching the house. I snap out of my "safe" feeling and run back to the kitchen oven and sit in the corner to await the arrival of daylight. 
I sit there, my twig in hand, regretting that I did not have enough time to refuel the generator in my haste to barricade the safehouse. I hear a feral dog in the distance, getting closer. Angry growls are heard, and soon I hear the savage outside my house getting attacked by the dog. A few seconds later, I hear only the dog making any noises, and I can conclude who won the struggle. I feel relieved that the barricades are keeping them out of the house, and feel as if I might just survive the night. Then I hear something else approaching the house. But this wasnt a dog or a savage, it was a new monster. It had ghostly moans and wails that make chills run down my spine. I hear the whelp of the dog, and then, silence. I sit there completely still as I concentrate all my mind on the sound of this new threat. It's moans re-emerge, and it is right outside the kitchen window. "Please go away" I plead in my mind "Please go away". Then, I remember the only place in the house that I couldnt barricade, a hole in the side of the house that I blocked with a wardrobe. 

I hear the squeaking of the wardrobe's legs against the floor as it is moved. 

I light a few matches and drop them on the floor as the thing bashes through the kitchen door. It stares at me with glowing white eyes and lunges towards me. I frantically swing my stick in front of me, only to see that the blows are near harmless to the creature. I desperately try to escape the room as the creature bashes away at my health. I make it to the doorway as I hear a bone crunching sound, and my character falls. I am dead, and soon the creature stands over me, its pure white eyes the only thing amist the darkness of the night...

Another great aspect of this game is the fact that they are updating it. 11446675.review:
ALPHA 1.1 Review

I normally refrain from buying Early Access titles these days, you never really know what state the game is in or even if it will be finished ever. In this case, wanting to support the studio and having followed development for a while I took the plunge and bought it. And even it's current state I'm not disappointed but there's ample room for improvement.

The game evokes feelings that I haven't felt since my first playthrough of the original silent hill, the atmosphere is thick and unsettling, the player character is a little helpless but not defenseless (sometimes) and just around every corner lurks the threat of the unknown. The game succeeds in building tension and the narrative is sublimely creepy. If you like horror, the kind that creeps up your neck and lurks just outside your vision but with it's claws embedded firmly in your neck then you'll find a home in Darkwood

11445331.review:
Take your worst nightmares of plant mutation, genetic mutation, and monsters from The Thing, splash it up against Don't Starve. 

Darkwood dosent hold your hand at all, you will die, you will run, and you will feel scared when night approaches. You can barricade your shelter. you can smash bottles to alert you of enemies when they walk on them and set traps to keep them from getting you for only so long. But what you WILL do is wish for night to end, pitch black, noises rustle in the darkness as things bump in the night. The game gives you a perfect sense of living in a nightmare and needing to keep yourself in check at every twig snap and distant growl. And when things are quiet the twistedness of the game never ceases, you will be forced to take companionship (or not) in the few mutated characters that remain "sane" and friendly towards you allowing you to trade and share gossip about the world you will be staying in. Of course you can kill these people at you leisure, but it never realy helps to kill the few things that seem sane, if not ever so slightly. The game allows you to choose how you wish to handle things.

Durring the night sagments the character must go home to not only seek shelter from the chaos of the night but to drink from a well to stay alive or they will die slowly and painfully from "the thirst", the well however is a mystery as to why your character needs the water from it. While you're at the house you will be able to combine the mutated mushrooms you find in the wild to inject yourself with mutations to give you new abilities (and weaknesses later on) that allow you to pick and choose what you think will help you best as your body changes for the "better".

The crafting system is pretty deep even for Alpha, allowing yout to craft molotovs, pellet guns, laterns, torches, bandages, The typical survival stuff. oddly enough the character dosent need to eat so cooking food and crafting that isent a thing. (Yet?)

My first time playing was pretty nerve destroying, I ended up getting attacked by an enemy (You're no tank of course) and going into a bleeding state, so my first instinct is to run the hell away leaving a massive blood trail as they swarmed me. Some sort of mutated crab things. Paniced I ended up running through some poisonous mushrooms to further add insult to injury. Coming up upon the games starter house I took a sharp turn around a tree, got caught in a bear trap. My character freaked out and tried his best to remove his foot from the thing, Night time approached as my characters vision cone was gone, busy looking at his feet to get the trap off. Before I knew it I was swarmed in the darkness. 

And thats the end of the first time I played.

11445302.review:
Before I start, I want to say that this review was written during Alpha Build 1.1, and there are still quite a few bugs. The developers gently suggest against loading a save, and you get massive FPS drops when you get near areas- ESPECIALLY the Pig Shed, or whatever it's called.

THAT SAID.

I am SO glad that I bought this game. It is SO scary. 

You're probably thinking, "How is a top-down game scary? You can just see everything."

No. No you can't.

This game is top-down, yes, but all you can see is that hey, there's grass and not metal thingies. You can't see ANYTHING until your line of sight, much like the beam of a flashlight (NEVER EVER MISTAKE IT FOR THE BEAM OF A FLASHLIGHT, it is NOT a flashlight), alights on whatever is there. This includes mushrooms, traps, monsters, chests, and other forageable items. You will not know it is there unless your line of sight, flashlight, flare light, torch light, whatever is covering whatever it is you're looking for.

The game is HORRIFICALLY frightening. You hear things way before you see them, and at night, you hear them and- hopefully, if your windows are boarded up and your back door blockaded- never see them. The prologue had me tense and on absolute edge, nearly driving me into insanity at the very end before dumping me into the actual game- and while the prologue is skippable, don't play until you've gone through the prologue. It REALLY sets the mood for the game and isn't a tutorial... Which is actually what I think it's supposed to count as. 

Tl;Dr: It doesn't show you diddly-squat despite being a top-down, the game is dark as BALLS and likes to throw monsters at you, and you never know what's coming at you until it's in your face. When I walk into a building, I walk into it with a weapon held high over my head and my pants soiled in terrified tension. I screamed when I walked into a chicken. A NORMAL, NON-MONSTER CHICKEN. It clucked and followed me, so I named it Kevin.

Buy it. I highly recommend it. This game is good right now, which is why I was okay with buying it. I hope it gets even better down the line! Especially with that FPS drop thing.

11444053.review: Not many games have the ability to disturb me. Sure, I can fall for jumpscares sometimes, but this game... this game isn't about jumpscares. In this game, all of it's scaring-ability is directly presented to you with a build up, which is most evident when night comes. This is one of those rare games where nighttime is actually terrifying like they claim (looking at you Minecraft and Don't Starve). During the night, you have to hunker down in your little log cabin and essentially pray for the morning light. Problem is that when the sun falls, demons come from the darkness and you're able to hear them as they attempt to penetrate your shoddily-crafted barricades. In one situation, I had barricaded a window and blocked off the two doors with a stool and a dresser, thinking that was sufficient. However, as I passed time in the pitch blackness of my room (generator had gone out), listening to the hellish shrieks, moans and snarls of the hunters lurking about outside, I encountered a new sound. A door opening and the sound of an object being shoved. The hairs on my arms stood up straight, my pulse quickened, chest tightened, and, in the darkness of the room, something else was with me. Going against everything my common sense was telling me, I lit a flare to get a look. When I spotted that disfigured demon casually shambling into my sanctuary my heart skipped a beat. Luckily, he hadn't seen me and I was able to quickly dispatch of him. This is how the scares in DARKWOOD are presented. You know they're coming, and the buildup to them is just as painful as the climax. Other than that, DARKWOOD presents a very intriguing plot and contains some of the coolest and most stylized NPCs around (I stared at the wolf merchant and the violin boy for a good five minutes). Overall, DARKWOOD shows great promise in its early access stage, and from this point, there's no where to go but up. Buy it if you don't mind the bugs that comes with early access or put it on your wishlist for later, because this game is 100% fantastic.

11443640.review:
Darkwood was released recently for early access as an early alpha build. However, I was impressed by how not-early-access it felt. Many games these days are released as early access, people pay money, and they get a messy incomplete game. Like The Fifth Day for example. Darkwood is not like these games that just seem like a cash-grab for developers. The game thus far is very well made. I don’t recall encountering a single bug, there’s actually story, and there are things to do! I was really impressed by how well the developers, Acid Wizard, captured a creepy, eerie, dark essence to the game. It really immerses you into this freaky, weird place. The game is also very challenging, it is not a brainless walk in the park by any means. In fact, I struggled to even get much of anywhere into the questing and story in the six hours I played. I am not sure why but I could not find the violin boy’s parents house at all. The “not far” part of the message is misleading because I searched everywhere the entire time I played (two different games) and never could find it. Perhaps it is just the luck of the randomly generated world, a feature I think makes this game fun and adds a lot of replay value.

Overall, the game in its current state is solid and worth the $15 price tag. If you’re a fan of darker survival games, I recommend giving Darkwood a try.

11442891.review:
Every time I play this game, I run the intro. And it scares me every time, even though it's scripted and I know every second of it by heart.

Don't let the weird top-down aspect turn you off of this one, or the Early Access tag, either. The actual game may often put more emphasis on survival in this survival horror, and YES, it has CRAFTING too, but it is still easily of of the best actually scary horror games to date  ( though it could be said that it has an edge, what with so many horror games today not being even slightly scary ). 

Despite the Early Access, there is still a solid game here, even in its Alpha. These guys aren't showing any signs of leaving this game in the dust either, but I personally would happily pay what they're asking just for the game they have now.

11440765.review:
Darkwood is a deeply atmospheric, punishing adventure survival game, with a surreal and dark Eastern European theme. For being a top-down game, it has gorgeous graphics that make the most light and shadow to give the game world texture, and the visuals are backed up by excellent and skillfully used sound effects that give you a reason to turn up your speakers. Gameplay is harsh, and random, and a healthy dose of caution is required doing most anything. It's a good game to play around in the sandbox or pursue the story elements, but which ever you do, it will be a shadowy and blood-soaked nightmare of an experience. I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes horror, adventure, survival or RPG games, or any mix of them. The difficulty IS an acqired taste though, be forewarned.

So far in Early Access, I've experienced no crashes and only a few minor to moderate bugs. Darkwood is up there in the ranks of Early Access games who had their shit together before they came on Steam.

11438185.review:
Хорошо, начнем с того что это мир пост-апокалипсиса в СССР. 
Игра не дает полной картины происходящего. Что заставляет самому познавать мелкие детали мира и его обитателей. 
Это хардкорная игра, она с самого начала игры говорит вам -Тебе здесь не рады, хочешь жить? Учись на своих ошибках.
Ощущение что кто то стоит за вашей спиной никогда не пропадает, особенно если ты на неизведанной территории. Скрип или ломка палки под ногами бросает в дрожь сразу-же. А музыкальное оформление поддает атмосферы темного и неприветливого леса который хранит в себе кучи секретов. 

Мой вердикт: Это интересная и завораживающая своей атмосферой игра которая испытает вашу смелость и навыки выживания. Мимо такой игры проходить не стоит, таких игр очень мало. Особенно которые заставляют по настоящему посмотреть на лес как на нечто жуткое и опасное, а имея такой интересный сеттинг. Как: "Темный лес на территории СССР" который имеет в себе кучку секретов и опасностей. 

Однозначно 10/10! 
Надо брать!

11436737.review:
I'm alone in a wood house that somehow lost its front entrance. I push a cabinet on the passage, to block any of those things from coming in at night. Then I lock myself in a room I previously barricaded the window, and put broken glass outside, in the living room, to hear when something is attempting to enter. I hold my plank with nails as if it was a saint.

The night is alive, the house creeks as it breathes the unnatural night wind, a feral dog that almost killed me during the day is barking outside, as the devil himself was smiling to him. Then the dog dies with a loud screech. Something otherworldly feminine screams...  The cabinet is pushed back with a loud noise. And the only sound that will make me lose it is the broken glass being stepped on. 

I can't see anything in the dark, but I desperately try to, with my back to the wall to avoid unnecessary danger. Then I hear the door opening, and my hair follicles erecting on my arm tell me that something is in the room with me. It didn't make any noise on the broken glass, because it floats. It's a ghost, and its scream is hellish.

Darkwood is one of those rare games, that when you purchase, you will feel an experience you'll never have, to be in another world, to suffer things that don't exist. You will suffer physically, your heartbeat will go up, you'll get goosebumps and curse outside noises for interfering with the game.

11434289.review:
At first some points and after that a retelling of an awesome ingame night.

The game is early access and thus has some issues here and there. One that happened the most to me was getting stuck in the inventory animation, not being able to move anymore and one time the only control it accepted was moving, with everything else not responding. So be advised about that if you buy it right now.

Other than that: It's great. I can't remember what other game nailed the sounds that good and was able to get the creepy athmosphere across from a top down 2d perspective.

Another thing that might turn people off is the difficulty:
Lots and lots of dying. Be it animals, monsters, stepping into poisonous areas or mushroom patches and so on.
Your accessibility to weapons is limited and to good weapons even more.
It doesn't help that every time you die you lose all your food (which is used to progress your skills) and every equipable item loses durability with most of them being either rare or frail to start with.


Now to my story inside the game:

 Stumbling around in the dark, hearing wooden doors in the distant creak or small twigs in the wood snap, only to turn around and see that there is allready a birdheaded monster standing behind you.

Rain and Thunderstorms with different sounds depending if you are inside or outside and a view cone that adapts to the light (ie. if you are in a totally dark room, you basically see shit).

I was in the room of my HQ cabin, stood in a corner to wait out the night, one single light in front of me that could always turn off if the generator outside loses fuel and aside from the 3 barricaded windows there is one door, which I barricaded with a crate. Distand wolfhowls (that originate from actual NPC wolves) and then the horrifying creaking of the floor in the next room....something is inside the cabin.

I waited it out but then it happened, the crate moves. someone pushes against the door, slowly but steady and moves the crate with that. Then silence, the door opened and one of the birdskullheaded monsters walks into the room towards me. stops, looks around, seemingly doesn't see me and turns around, walking up and down the room, repeating the same routine 2 more times before FINALLY leaving.

Pretty fucking intense and the amazing part: It's top down 2D graphics that are able to build that kind of athmosphere.

11431592.review: That game is awesome! It is a combination of Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl, Amnesia and Hotline Miami. It is so atmospheric and immersive. Not only that, it is damn scary at times. I screamed more than once and not because of carefully crafted jump-scares either; these were emergent and organic scares with plenty of build-up in a distinctly non-linear world. Brilliant. The story is intriguing too. The difficulty however is the great part for me. No handholding (a decent tutorial in the form of a prologue but that’s it) and lethal enemies. It is extremely hard, which makes every victory, no matter how small, seem immense. Seriously, buy this game. There are $90 AAA titles without even a tenth of this game’s great design.

11428938.review: My first horrifying experience in Darkwood happened on the second or third night. I had just sprinted all the way back to my some-what fortified base, took a drink from a well, and made my way inside. I began shutting all the doors I could, and got into a room I had began to call my safe-haven. The two windows in that room were boarded up, but there was one thing I had left untouched... the door. The previous nights had shown me, or I had thought had shown me, that I could just push a dresser infront of it and it would all go peachy. So I left it that way. But little did I know, it wouldn't go as planned on this night. About halfway through the night, as I'm backed into a corner scared half to death of all the noises coming from outside, I begin to hear, "rrrrrrrnnnnnnnn!" It sounded like the dresser I had infront of the un-barricaded door was being pushed. So, on instinct, I whipped out my flashlight, and shown it at the door, and in mid struggle, there it was, this creepy black creature, pushing the dresser out of the way. I was terrified, all I could do was hide, so I turned off my light, took out my only weapon, (a board with a few nails in it) and backed myself into a corner. I couldn't see anything, I sat there, scared half to death, with my board ready, for the rest of the night. Then, when the sun began to rise, I heard the dresser slide across the floor once again, as the creature left. ~ABSOLUTELY FUCKING TERRIFYING!~

11424553.review:
Крутая игра. 
В первый день собрал досок и гвоздей для минимальной защиты и заколотил входную и верхнюю(которая ведет во вторую комнату) дверь. Вход организовал через дыру в стене, которая по ночам задвигалась шкафом.
Первые две ночи прошли довольно спокойно, правда в кромешной темноте. Я сидел в маленькой комнатушке и смотрел на  входную дверь. Утром третьего дня я увидел, что шкаф отодвинут от прохода, значит ночью черти были внутри.
К третьей ночи я подготовился хорошо - заколотил все окна и двери, до которых мог добраться. В этот раз мне начали ломать все подряд, но я выжил, заперевшись в главной комнате. Проверив утром дом, я понял, что снасли входную, и следующую прямо за ней дверь. Окна там тоже уже не было.
В пятую ночь я как обычно стоял возле шкафа, подпирающую дыру. Я расставил капканы, в руке у меня был молотов, я был готов ждать гостей. Это был первый раз, когда шкаф начал двигаться...

11424515.review: Если у вас повышенное содержание кирпичей в организме, то Darkwood поможет вам сбросить лишний вес. Запросто.

11424196.review:
Day 1...

I have awoken in a room with a wolf, but he is a friendly wolf. He has given me some insight on the situation and told me about a crazy chicken lady who I shall seek out later but first I decided to look around my hideout to hopefully find a weapon.

10 Minutes have passed and no weapon or anything useful. I hopped out my window to look for the well. I found it moments later but something else appears to have found me, something terrifying began staring at me with it's cold bloodshot eyes. We stared for what felt like hours until it scurried in my direction. I did the only thing I could...Turn and jump through the window. I thought I would be ok but I was wrong, it followed me so I jumped out the window to the outside and hurried into the generator room. I turned it on hoping it would deter the beast...It did, or atleast my hiding skills had made it loose track of me.

A while past and I noticed it was getting dark so I headed back inside where I waited till the well was ready to be drunk.

Finally the well was drinkable so I drunk as much as I could when suddenly I heard a loud noise so I hopped back inside, ran to the generator and switched it hoping to deter whatever it was.

It's pitch black outside but my lamps are doing ok at keeping it lit inside. For safety measure I have placed a stool next to the window to make sure no one could possibly get in. I waited...And waited...

I walked around the house aimlessly when suddenly I noticed the worst thing imaginable...The lights went out...I heard some inhuman laugh or noise, whatever it was I knew it was now coming for me, in hopes my hiding skills would once work again I hid in a corner... *Creeeeeeeeek* The door went as someone entered my house. *Cshhhhhh* went the stool as someone or something walked past it. The footsteps got louder AND louder AND LOUDER until they were inches away from me. *Shinkkkk* went the blade that cut, piercing my skin. I screamed and ran for the window where I hopped out and closed the door hiding myself once again inside the generator room. 'I'm screwed' I thought as I listned for any movemnt...



I waited and waited until I noticed light beaming lightly through the hole in the wall. I went to the door and opened it...It was day...I survived...'But wait!' I thought. 'What if it was still out here?' And as thoughts raced through my mind I did the only thing I thought I could do. I ran for the chicken ladies house. I remembered it was east so I ran as fast as my shaking legs could carry me. But without focusing properly I heard the worst noise imaginable...'Cshhhh' went the sound of a few mushrooms crushing beneath my feet. 'No......' I thought. I almost began to cry but I thought that if I got to her house maybe, just maybe she will have something to help me. So I ran once again as fast as I could. I saw a structure. 'Yes YES!' I shouted. As I closed nearer my heart stopped...It was the pig place...I looked left and right furiously as I felt my legs about to give way. I turned and ran north as fast as I could but it was to no use. Within seconds my legs gave way and I fell flat on my face where I layed...To die....

11421752.review:
I don't usually write Reviews for Games, but I had to make an exception for Darkwood. I backed this title on Indigogo originally, and early on was drawn to the idea. Every other game I have backed was a disappointment but not this one! Even for being in alpha state, the game already succeeds at drawing you into the creepy and somtimes terrying world of Darkwood. My review follows, but for those that do not wish to read TL;DR: A monster started chasing me, so I sprinted towards my house. I lost him, but ran into a mushroom and died. 10/10

[u]Gameplay[/u]
You wake up in your safehouse after the prologue. A man with a dog face waits for you, and gives you some basics. He gives you some clues about the mysterious Dogtag you have on you, and points you towards the "Chicken Lady" to the west. From here you're on your own. Your main objective is to follow the clues, but along the way you may follow a trail or a strange noise and before you know it you're exploring the world. Littered along the woods are items and crafting supplies, letting you make some basic survival supplies. When it starts to get dark, the thirst comes forcing you to return to the safehouse where a well keeps you alive for another day. But the day doesn't end here, now you can cook the items you found infected with whatever is eating up the woods. This results in essence, which act as experience points. When you've collected enough essence, you get to select from a list of skills. They range from nice to incredibly useful, but somtimes a player must also take a downside to balance out the power. When you die, you return to your home with your equipped items slighty damaged, all your essence items stolen and back at level 1, so you should think twice before storming into a fight. Health is pretty basic, but there is also stamina which is used by using items or running.

[u]Controls[/u]
The controls are interesting. Most of the game is played with the mouse and WASD. Items that have more than one action accessible to the player have a context menu that is brought up. You can sprint with shift and open the inventory/crafting menu with tab. There is also a map (m) and a journal (j). For me the controls felt fairly smooth and natural.

11417445.review:
I've been waiting for this game for oh so long and now I've finally gotten my hands on this.
Darkwood's a top down, rogue-like survival game with overencumbering horror elements and by overencumbering horror elements I mean the proper ones. No ridiculous jump scares, no overused appearances. Just amazing atmosphere and the fact that once you die, it's all over, just like in most rogue-likes. It's unforgiving and punishing, challenging and at the same time very immersive and eerie. Every house you go into is a possible death trap for our dear, faceless protagonist and the game lets you know that very well. You are not the hero here, you're not the tough guy. Every single enemy poses a threat and no, not the type that scratches a tad of your HP. I'm talking about killing you easily, from simple wild dogs to deformed walking monstrosities. 
Even though the game is 2D, the artwork is wonderful and the characters you meet and engage in dialogue with feel very alive. The writing is good and the animations, both while in dialogue and in combat/walking/inventory management and so on are of high quality. Even though it is 2D, do not be tricked, you know nothing of what is going on and it will take keen and careful observation of your surroundings in order to live to see another day.
The story is very interesting and can easily catch your attention, although progressing through the story is not easy, as the tasks to success are packed with things you'd rather not see.

The developers have done a truly amazing job and even though the game is currently in alpha, it is very much playable. I can only imagine what they have in store for us with the finished product.

Premetto per chi leggerà questa "recensione" che  come si può notare dalle ore di gioco non ci ho giocato  a fondo,però voglio in ogni caso dare la mia prima impressione riguardo Darkwood.Partiamo con l' analisi per quello che ho potuto provare del gioco:
Il gioco è un Survival/Horror in 2D,con generazione casuale del mondo però con una storia ben definita, per quanto ho potuto capire  il posto dove ci troviamo a subito una sorta di Infezione e noi dovremmo scoprire cosa è successo.a livello di giocabilita(Gameplay)posso dire che già dall' inizio ti butta in una situazione angosciante e non sai cosa ti aspetta,abbiamo un sistema di costruzione e potremmo interagire con l' ambiente circostante in vari modi,(spostando mobili per magari barricarci in una stanza esempio,scassinare porte ,creare barrricate)c' è un sistema di interazione con i vari NPC che i quali ci affibbieranno varie missioni,La difficoltà del gioco è soddisfacente per quanto ho potuto constatare la morte sarà la più facile e ovvia delle conseguenze in Darkwood.Il sistema di Illuminazione è veramente ben fatto,ti constringerà a costruire fonti di illuminazione sempre più potenti per poter avanzare in certe zone più buie,quando arriverà la notte dovremmo tornare la nascondiglio per bere (altrimenti andremo inesorabilmente verso la morte) e per nasconderci dai pericoli della foresta che di notte si faranno più aggressivi che mai.Tirando giu due somme allo stato attuale per quello che ho provato Darkwood è un gioco di orrore veramente ben fatto nonostante sia in 2d e con un prezzo più che ragionevole,per chi fosse indeciso consiglio vivamente di guardare qualche video cosi facendo si toglierà ogni dubbio.

11408475.review:
Few games have been able to invite the sheer terror that this happens to provoke. The sound design is fantastic, and it helps to convey a sense of impending doom during the night sequences, when you're hunkered down in your choice of shelter. You can hear the beasts skulking around in the rooms around you, banging on barricades, stepping on creaking floorboards, and howling into the dead of night, while you remain huddled in a corner, wishing for the light of day.

It's the night sequences coupled with the pitch black segments that really make this game for me. The lack of light, and the removal of your field of view really makes every moment incredibly tense. Coupled with the hectic, brutal combat, moment to moment decisions are crucial to your survival. 

For an early access alpha game, Darkwood has an incredible amount of potential. I'm truly looking forward to what the devs have to offer in future iterations.

11407635.review:
EARLY REVIEW (Subject to change)

Update: 4/10/2015 build 4.1 Alpha

The game is coming along nicely. With each build come new improvements to everything across the board. By now it can be hard to tell that this is not a finished product! Please help fund it. Buy it now while it's "finished" but under construction and help a cult classic come into being.

---

I waited since this was announced on Greenlight, and boy was it ever worth the wait. 

First off, the ATMOSPHERE. It is amazing. I didn't think a top-down experience could really capture it so well, but it does because you can see the environment around you, sometimes eerily twitching or waving if you aren't looking at it directly. You can hear the wind, an occasional shriek, eerie ambience and the occasional crunch of a branch that might make you jump. Be careful, the noises you make can attract horrifying things, and the oppressive environment makes that delightfully clear the moment you see it. Who knows what might be hiding behind those wavy branches in the background?

Next comes the exploration. Getting lost is VERY easy to do, so once again the location and feeling of real fear is stressed by this risk. You must make it back by dark or you will die, so be sure to know your pathway back, and hope to high hell there aren't any -things- to block your path on the way back. Look for materials for crafting, barricading, repairing or boiling mushrooms into a drug of sorts that gives you skills (A sort of leveling system). Craft a weapon immediately when you find what you need. But even with that, you're bound to want to run and hide from most threats.

The characters that I have seen so far have also been extremely interesting. Well designed, excellent art illustrates them and unsettling dialog helps highlight what remains of the populace in this story.

HOWEVER, there -are- bugs, as to be expected from an alpha, and the best way to play is just to expect the unexpected and report something if it blocks your progress, quit and reload. The dev team is very on top of everything and listens well to the playerbase. With the arrival of Alpha 2.0, it's clear they love their game and are serious about making things better for the players.

Ending thoughts - Worth a buy if you like to support indie development and love a good, unique horror game, because there really isn't anything else like it out there, and you'd be supporting something great.

NOT worth a buy when not on sale if you can't tolerate bugs and would rather have a finished product, but this one's going to be a hit. Grab it if it happens to be cheap at the time.

This is something worth supporting. There aren't many indie teams out there with such passion for their product, and I believe it's already showing with each small patch.

So far: 8/10, and only because of bugs and missing features.

11406268.review:
The Darkwood forest is infested with all sorts of vile creatures, mysterious friends and foes, an eerie atmosphere, and a sense of dread like you drank contaminated water out of desperation and regretted it instantly afterwards.  

You are alone, but you are not truly alone.  All of the inhabitants are after you, want something from you, or haunts you with their presence.  All are ravaged, infested with darkness, except for rabbits that hop in front of your path, scurrying away because they know too well that Darkwood is not a safe place.  It is not something you have figured out yet, but soon, you will become one with Darkwood and all of its manifestations.  One nightmare after another, you wonder if this is all a nightmare that you manifested in your mind, or is it all real?  You embark in this dark journey to put the pieces together, scavenging to survive through the night and one night only, because that is your main fear.  

Darkwood is a survival-horror, roguelike, sandbox game with a story.  The player can choose to venture into Darkwood using permadeath or no-permadeath.  It is highly recommended to play Darkwood with permadeath.  It increases the tension, vulnerability, and sense of dread which all add more to the atmosphere and overall experience.  Darkwood is unforgiving, merciless, and it is not for players with a weak heart.  

It is important to note that Darkwood does have a story.  The player can explore, unravel secrets, and the other mysteries in the dark forest.  In your dark journey, you will meet the inhabitants of Darkwood.  The residents of Darkwood consists of different, unique, twisted individuals.  You will meet characters that you would never expect to meet in all shapes, sizes, and forms, equipped with unique personalities.  Some are informative, some of them may want or demand things in return, and some work on incentives.  They make some of Tim Burton's creations seem tame.  

The visuals, art style, and graphics in Darkwood are easy on the eyes and they lend themselves to the atmosphere. The visuals are up to standard for an Indie game and especially for this particular type of game in this genre.  While walking through the forest, the shadows create imagery that look almost like hallucinations.  "Am I really seeing this? Or is that a corpse that I am seeing?"  In Darkwood, trust your instincts more than your vision.   The color palette suits the environments and the atmosphere.  It creates a dark tone and an overall sense of dread that looms over you.  Dark areas can be lit up with a light source such as a torch, a match, or a flare (items so far in the game).  They light up the path for you to explore and gain access to new areas.  But explore with extreme caution - you do not know what is around the corner.  You may step on troop of mushrooms and become poisoned.  Wander too far and you may become lost, run out of any light sources, and distance yourself further away from your base and safe haven.  But is it really safe?  

Darkwood is played from the top-down point of view with a cone of vision.  While the cone vision is not a light source, it does show the player what you "can see."  If a "horror" is chasing you and you are running away from it, your cone of vision will be in front of you because that is what you can only see while you are running away.  The enemy that is chasing you from behind will not be visible to you; not until it is inside your cone of vision.  Even if the foe is out of the range of the cone of vision, it will not be visible either.  This adds suspense and it makes it more challenging when you must "fight or take flight."  In Darkwood, you will need to pick your battles.  You may wonder: If it is from a top-down perspective, wouldn't you be able to see everything?  And wouldn't that reveal all of your surroundings and everything in it?  No, that is not how it works.  Your cone of vision gives you some visibility, but you will need your light source to penetrate the darkness and light your path.  The rest of the areas that is not within your vicinity will be dark.  It is not as dark as an auditorium with a spotlight on a person, but it is really dark.  Often times, you will not see an object until you get really close to it, even with a light source.  

So far, there are several items that you can loot, a few weapons, and crafting recipes in Chapter 1.  I have found three weapons so far - plank with nails, an axe, and a shovel that are melee weapons.  Other helpful items that could be used as weapons or hunting, is a bear trap.  You can also make molotovs.  And with glass bottles, you can break it into shards and use it as an immobilizing trap.  One of the coolest game mechanics that I found very interesting was the use of mushrooms or cooking mushrooms turning it into a drug/chemical substance.  When you explore the forest, loot all the mushrooms that you find.  Gather them and you may have enough to fill a syringe.  Once the syringe is filled up, use the injection and it will grant you a new skill.  I thought this was a really unique game mechanic and I cannot recall it ever being used before from my knowledge of many years of gaming since the 90s.  It certainly took me by surprise and I just loved it.  Further, there are recipes hidden throughout Darkwood like a recipe to make a "lantern" that I found along the way.  This of course will require you to explore and search for the materials to craft and make a lantern.  In your inventory, you can experiment and try to combine items together to create a new item from that combination.  Just a tip:  you can eat mushrooms!  They heal you.  Also, drinking water from the well at your base will heal you as well.  Some of the most essential items are wood logs and mushrooms.  Loot them all the time.  If you find yourself running out of inventory space, craft what you can craft, and store away items at your base in the crates that you do not need at the moment.  

The movement, movement speed, and combat feel fluid and responsive in Darkwood. If there is one gaming pet-peeve, that is clunky controls. You can sprint, but your character uses up stamina or endurance.  In combat, you can hit harder by simply holding the right mouse button (RMB) to pull back and swing harder.  It uses stamina as well.  You can click LMB without the hold to make a light attack.  With careful timing, while strafing, you can time your attacks while dodging attacks (there is no dodgeroll, don't worry!).  So far, I have only used melee weapons and the bear trap, although I have found a gun clip and materials to make a molotov.  Combat was surprisingly satisifying for a top-down game.  

You can hear (audio, sound) every thump with every hit you land on an enemy.  Weapons do deteriorate indicated by the item going from white to red on the weapon icon.  I have found one NPC that you can trade items with and make deals.  Since there is no money currency, because why would you have any, trade is on a barter system.  For instance, if you find a piece of valuable jewelry, you can trade that for an item that you may need, or you can trade it in for information.  Other NPCs will want information as well, so you may have to search and uncover information that you could trade for an important item that may be of aid.  

Darkwood works on a level design system of randomly generated levels.  

The audio, sound design, and soundtrack are fantastic.  The music sets the dark mood and tone.  And every crack of a melee weapon can be heard with authority. 

There is so much to talk about and Darkwood is barely in Early Access with only one chapter!  As you can tell, I am very pleased with the content that is available at the moment.  It not only has surpassed my expectations, it already has me hooked with its dark charm and vast potential. I genuinely hope that they continue to support and add content to the game well after the final release.
